Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for him as with what preceded, until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in aegritudinibus Pulmonis, et Tussi.	On the manner of cauterization in diseases of the lungs and coughs.
Caput XXVI.	Chapter XXVI.
Quando Tussis et aegritudo Pulmonis sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, et infirmus non habet febrem, neque phthisim, et aegritudo antiqua: tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis supra furculam in locis depressis, lenibus, uacuis.	When cough and lung pain are from cold humidity, and the patient has no fever, nor consumption, and old pain: then cauterize him with two cautery instruments above the fork in the depressed, soft, places.
Et cauterio alio in medio pectoris inter duas mammillas: et sit cauterium cannulae secundum formam quae praecessit.	And with another cautery in the middle of the chest between the two nipples: and let the cautery be a tube according to the form which preceded.
Et si uis sit cauterizatio tua punctando cum cauterio, quod nominatur Punctum, cuius forma praecessit in punctatione doloris aurium: et sint puncta ex triginta punctis usque quasi ad alia.	And if you wish to cauterize with a point using a cautery, which is called "Point," whose form precedes in the piercing of ear pain; and let there be points from thirty points up to almost others.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod praecessit, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with what preceded, until he is healed.
Et iam sit cauterium habens tres ramos: secundum hanc formam.	And now let there be a cautery having three branches: according to this form.
Quare alleuiatur cum eo cauterizatio, quando tu facis cum eo uice una tria Cauteria.	Therefore, when you are doing that with him using a vice and three cauteries, the cauterization should be eased.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Titillico, in dislocatione Humeri.	On the manner of cauterizing in a wound caused by  Titillico, in the dislocation of the humerus.
Caput XXVII.	Chapter XXVII.
Quando dislocatur caput adiutorii caussa humiditatum, et nonfigitur in hora reditus sui a dislocatione sua, donec sit illud ei consuetudo reditionis, deinde dislocatur a paruo motu, qui accidit sicut nos iam testificauimus illud, tunc oportet ut reducas dislocationem in primis.	When the head is dislocated due to moisture and does not return to its place within an hour after dislocation, until it becomes accustomed to returning, then it is dislocated with a slight movement, which happens as we have already testified, then you must reduce the dislocation first.
Deinde resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, aut super latus sanum.	Then the sick person is laid on his back, or on his healthy side.
Deinde eleua cutim, quae est in interiori Titillici ad superiora cum digitis manus tuae sinistrae: et si iunctura dislocatur ad interiora.	Then lift the skin which is in the inner Tilici to the upper part with your left hand fingers: and if the joint is dislocated inward.
Deinde igni Cauterium habens duo uerua.	Then cautery having two handles, of fire.
Cuius forma est haec.	Its shape is this.
Deinde cauteriza cutim, donec penetret eam usque ad latus aliud, et ueniet figura cauterizationis cum quatuor cauteriis.	Then cauterize the skin until it penetrates to the other side, and the figure of the cauterization will come with four cauteries.
Et quandoque fit cauterizatio cum cauterio habente tria uerua, quare fit figura cauterizationis tunc sex cauteriorum: et sunt uerua secundum subtilitatem tentae.	And sometimes cauterization is done with a cautery having three handles, so the figure of cauterization then becomes six cauteries: and the handles are according to the fineness of the thread.
Et haec est forma cauterii habentis tria uerua.	And this is the form of a cautery having three handles.
Et quandoque additur super hunc modum unum, quare sunt cauteria octo.	And sometimes one is added above this way, because there are eight cauteries.
Deinde pone super cauterium porros contritos cum sale.	Then place over the cautery chopped onions with salt.
Deinde fac adhaerere infirmum tranquillitati, ut non moueatur membrum tempore aliquo, donec confortetur.	Then make the injured person adhere to stillness, so that the limb is not moved for some time until it has been strengthened.
Et si dislocatio est ad superiora, et raro fit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super humerum cauterio clauili, aut cauteriis multis punctando.	And if the dislocation is upward, and this rarely happens, then cauterize it above the shoulder with a single cautery or with many cauteries puncturing it.
Nam iunctura firmatur, et remouetur humiditas: et sanatur infirmus.	For the joint is strengthened and humidity is removed, and the weak one is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Stomachum.	On the way of cauterizing the stomach.
Caput XXVIII.	Chapter XXVIII.
Quando accidunt in Stomacho frigus et humiditates multae, donec extrahant ipsum a complexione sua, et multiplicentur catarri ad ipsum, et assiduas modos curationis, et non confert: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum, et extendat crura sua, et manus suas.	When coldness and much moisture happen in the stomach until they draw it out of its composition, and catarrh multiplies to it, and continuous modes of cure are applied, and it does not help: then it is necessary that the sick person be laid on his back, and extend his legs and hands.
Deinde cauteriza cum tribus cauteriis, cauterio sub cochleari pectoris quantitate digiti unius cum cauterio clauili, et duobus cauteriis inferius a duobus lateribus cauterii unius, donec ueniat figura cauteriorum triangulata.	Then cauterize with three cauteries, a cautery under the concavity of the chest the size of one finger with one cautery, and two cauteries below from both sides of one cautery, until the figure of the cauteries becomes triangular.
Et elonga inter utraque ut non coniungantur, quando facient pus.	And lengthen between the two so that they do not join when they make pus.
Et sit profunditas cauterii quantitas duarum tertiarum grossitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be the quantity of two thirds the thickness of the skin.
Et sit figura cauteriorum secundum hanc formam sine additione: et si uis cauteriza cauterio magno in medio stomachi secundum hanc formam: et sit cauterium quo fit hoc cauterium unum secundum figuram circuli secundum hanc formam.	And let the figure of cauteries be according to this form without addition: and if you wish to cauterize with a large cautery in the middle of the stomach according to this form: and let the cautery used for this cautery be one according to the form of a circle according to this form.
Et cauterizatur stomachus punctando ei qui terretur ab hoc cauterio: et est, ut signes super stomachum punctum secundum quantitatem, quam uis cum encaustro: deinde cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio puncti: deinde cura ipsum cum curatione, quae praecessit donec sanetur.	And the stomach is cauterized by pricking it with a burning iron for those who are afraid of this cauterization; and let signs be on the stomach according to the quantity that you wish with the cautery; then cauterize it with the cauterizing iron, and after that treat it with the treatment which preceded until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Epar frigidum.	On the manner of cauterizing a cold wound.
Caput XXIX.	Chapter XXIX.
Quando accidit in Epate dolor ex frigiditate et humiditate, aut ex uentositate grossa, donec egrediatur a complexione sua naturali egressione superflua, et curatur infirmus, cum eo quod diximus, et non proficit in illo: tunc oportet ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam, et signes cum encaustro tria cauteria secundum hanc figuram, et hanc quantitatem eandem super Epar inferius ab hypocundriis, ubi peruenit cubitus hominis: et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium secundum grossitudinem digiti: et sit cauterium secundum longitudinem corporis rectum: et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio multum.	When there occurs in the Liver pain from cold and moisture, or from a coarse wind, until it goes out from its natural composition by superfluity, and the sick person is cured, with that which we have said, and does not profit in him: then it is necessary that the sick person be laid on his back over his neck, and signs with encaustrum three cauteries according to this figure, and this same quantity below the Liver from the hypogastrium, where the arm of a man arrives: and let the space that is between each cautery be according to the thickness of a finger: and let the cautery be according to the length of the body straight: and do not press your hand with the cautery much.
Et sit quantitas eius quod aduritur ex spissitudine cutis, quantitas medietatis eius non additum: et sit infirmus stans super pedes suos.	And let the quantity of that which is burned be equal to the thickness of the skin, and the quantity of half of it not added; and let the patient stand weak on his feet.
Si autem non est stans, tunc sit iacens, qui iam extendit crura sua, et eleuauit brachia sua.	If he is not standing, then let him be lying down, who has already extended his legs and raised his arms.
Haec est forma cauterii.	This is the form of the cautery.
Et tibi quidem possibile est, ut cauterizes ista cauteria cum cauterio cultellari, quando tecum est subtilitas et prudentia in arte.	And it is possible for you, that you cauterize these wounds with a knife cautery when you have subtlety and prudence in the art.
Et custodi te, ut non ultime procedas in cauterizatione, et aduratur spissitudo cutis totius, quare aduratur corpus totum, et perueniat ad intestina: quoniam cutis illic est subtilis, scias ergo illud.	And guard yourself so that you do not go too far in cauterization, and the thickness of the skin is burned throughout, because the whole body is burned and it reaches the intestines: because the skin there is thin, know this.
¶ De modo cauterizandi apostemata Epatis.	On the way to cauterize abscesses of the liver.
Caput XXX.	Chapter XXX.
Quando accidit exitura, et uis scire, si illud apostema est in carne Epatis, aut in tunica eius: tunc si est in carne Epatis, inuadit infirmum dolor, et grauitas absque acuitate: et si est in tunica Epatis, cum dolore est acuitas uehemens: et uides iam, quia fatigauit medicos eius curatio.	When an abscess occurs, and you wish to know if it is in the liver flesh or its tunic; then if it is in the liver flesh, a dull pain invades the sick person, and heaviness without sharpness; and if it is in the tunic of the liver, with pain there is vehement sharpness; and you see already that it has fatigued his physicians with treatment.
Oportet ergo ut resupinet infirmus super ceruicem suam.	Therefore, let the sick person lie upon his neck.
Deinde figura locum apostematis cum encaustro: deinde ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	Then the figure of the place of the abscess with an encasing; then fires cauterium which is assimilated to a ray.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its shape.
Et cauteriza cum eo cauterium unum, donec comburatur cutis tota, et perueniat ad siphac, donec egrediatur sanies tota: deinde cura ipsum curatione exiturarum, donec sanetur.	And burn it with one cautery until the whole skin is burned and it reaches the fascia, until all pus comes out; then take care of it with ointment treatment until it heals.
Et non oportet ut hac cauterii specie utatur, nisi cuius studium in arte medicinae prolongatur: et per cuius manus concurrunt aegritudines istae cum experimento aliquotiens: tunc enim audeat super huiusmodi operationem.	And it is not right that this cautery be used unless the one who studies the art of medicine has prolonged their practice, and through whose hands these ailments have frequently occurred with experience; then he may dare to attempt such an operation.
At uero dimittere ipsam, apud me est melius.	But in my opinion it is better to discharge her.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Pleuresi.	On the manner of cauterizing in pleurisy.
Caput XXXI.	Chapter XXXI.
Dixerunt antiqui, cauterium cum radicibus aristolochiae ad Pleuresim frigidam secundum hunc modum.	The ancients said that a cautery with the roots of asarabacca was applied to cold pleurisy in this way.
Et est, ut recipias ex radicibus aristolochiae siccae longae, radicem unam longiorem, quae ex ea inuenitur, et sit sicut grossitudo digiti.	And there is, that you receive from the roots of dried and long birthwort, one root longer, which is found in it, and be like the thickness of a finger.
Deinde submerge eam in oleo: et accende ipsam in igne.	Then immerse it in oil: and set it on fire.
Deinde cauteriza cauterio uno in eo quod est inter continuationem furculae cum collo, et duobus cauteriis paruis sub guidezi parum decliuibus ad partem, quae est sub barba.	Then cauterize with one cautery where the fork is joined to the neck, and with two small cauteries under a slightly sloping guide on the part which is under the beard.
Et duobus cauteriis etiam in eo, quod est inter costam quintam et sextam decliuibus ad posteriora parumper: et cauterio alio in medio pectoris, et alio supra stomachum.	And with two cauteries also in that which is between the fifth and sixth ribs sloping to the rear a little; and one cautery in the middle of the chest, and another above the stomach.
Et tribus cauteriis a posterioribus: uno in eo quod est inter duas spatulas: et duobus cauteriis a duobus lateribus pectoris, inferius cauterio quod est inter duas spatulas.	And with three cauteries from behind: one in that which is between two spatulas; and two cauteries from the two sides of the chest, lower cautery which is between the two spatulas.
Et non oportet ut comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit in manifesto cutis odorando.	And you must not press your hand with the cautery, but rather let it be on the manifest skin smelling.
Et iam dixerunt quidam antiqui, quod ex hominibus sunt qui utuntur cauterio ex ferro simili radio: et igniunt, et intus mittunt ipsum in eo quod est inter costas, donec perueniatur cum eo ad ipsum apostema, et egrediatur sanies: sicut diximus in apostemate Epatis.	And some ancients have said that there are men who use a cauterio made of iron like a rod: and they ignite it, and put it inside where the ribs are, until it comes to the abscess, and pus flows out: just as we said in the case of an abscess on the liver.
Sed in hac perforatione cum cauterio est ex timore, quod aut moritur infirmus statim, aut accidit in loco fistula, cui non est sanatio.	But in this perforation with a cautery there is fear that either the weak one dies immediately or a fistula occurs in its place which has no healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Splenem Caput XXXII.	On the manner of cauterizing the spleen.  Chapter XXXII.
Quando tu curas aegritudinem splenis, cum eo quod diximus ex curatione in diuisione aegritudinum, et non confert curatio tua, tunc cauterium in ea est secundum tres modos, qui omnes sunt recti.	When you treat the illness of the spleen, as we have said from the treatment in the division of illnesses, and your treatment does not help, then cauterization in it is according to three ways, which are all right.
Quorum unus est, ut facias tria cauteria, aut quatuor lineando secundum longitudinem splenis secundum figuram cauteriorum Epatis, quorum praecessit figura.	One of these is that you make three cauteries, or four, by lining them according to the length of the spleen, according to the figure of the liver cauteries, which preceded in figure.
Et sit inter omne cauterium quantitas grossitudinis digiti, aut plus parum.	And let there be among all cautery a quantity of thickness of a finger, or a little more or less.
Et sit modus cauterii, quem diximus in cauterio epatis aequaliter.	And let the mode of cautery be as we have said in the cautery of the liver.
Et non comprimas manum tuam cum cauterio: et sit infirmus resupinus super dorsum suum.	And do not press your hand with the cautery: and let the weak one be lying on his back.
Et modus alius de cauterizatione est: ut ignias cauterium habens duo uerua, quod diximus in capitulo dislocationis humeri: et eleua cutem, quae est in directo splenis, ubi peruenit cubitus infirmi sinister: et sit eleuatio tua qua eleuas cutem secundum latitudinem corporis, ut cadant cauteria secundum longitudinem corporis.	And another way of cauterization is: that having a cauterium with two handles, which we said in the chapter on dislocation of the shoulder; and elevate the skin, which is directly on the spleen, where the elbow of the left arm arrives; and let your elevation be as you elevate the skin according to the width of the body, so that the cauteries fall according to the length of the body.
Deinde intromitte duo uerua ignita ualde, donec cum eis penetres cutem a parte altera: deinde extrahe cauterium: fiunt ergo cauteria quatuor.	Then introduce two burning rods, until with them you penetrate the skin from the other part: then remove the cautery: therefore four cauteries are made.
Et si uis cauteriza cum cauterio alio habente tria uerua.	And if you wish to cauterize with a cautery having three handles.
Deinde cura cauterium postquam dimittis ipsum emittere pus diebus multis: est enim magis conferens quamque reliqua quae praecesserunt ex curatione.	Then care for the cauterization after you let it discharge pus for many days, for it is more healing than all that preceded from the cure.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Hydropisi.	On the manner of cauterizing in dropsy.
Caput XXXIII.	Chapter XXXIII.
Cauterium non cadit in Hydropisi, nisi ascliti proprie.	A cautery does not fall upon a hydropic condition unless it is properly applied.
Quando tu curas Hydropicum cum modis curationis, quos diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, et cauterio uno super stomachum, et cauterio alio super epar, et cauterio super splenem, et cauteriis duobus post dorsum inter spondiles, et uno in directo pectoris, et alio in directo stomachi: et sit quantitas profunditatis cauterii propinqua spissitudini cutis.	When you treat Hydrops with the methods of treatment which we have said in the division, and the treatment does not help, then it is necessary that you cauterize it with four cauteries around the navel, and one cautery on top of the stomach, and another on top of the liver, and one cautery on the spleen, and two cauteries behind the back between the vertebrae, and one in a straight line across the chest, and another in a straight line across the stomach: and let the quantity of the depth of the cautery be near to the thickness of the skin.
Deinde dimitte cauterium apertum, ut emittat pus tempore longo.	Then release the open cautery so that it may discharge pus for a long time.
Et non euacues infirmum a curatione post cauterium cum eo: quod oportet ut aggregentur ei duae intentiones: et festinabit ad ipsum sanatio cum auxilio Dei.	And do not remove the infirm from treatment after cauterization, for it is necessary that two intentions are brought together to him: and healing will hasten to him with the help of God.
Forma uero cauterii cum quo cauterizatur uenter, sit clauilis: secundum quod praecessit forma eius: et illius cum quo cauterizatur dorsum, sit oliuaris secundum quod praecessit eius forma.	The form of the cautery with which the abdomen is cauterized should be a clamp, according to what precedes about its form; and that with which the back is cauterized should be an olive, according to what precedes about its form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Pedes, et Crura.	On the mode of cauterizing feet and legs.
Caput XXXIIII.	Chapter XXXIV.
Quando apostemantur in Hydropico, et replentur aqua citrina: oportet ut cauterizes super dorsum Pedis in nocrati, quae est inter auricularem et anularem: et eleua manum tuam cum cauterio, et non torqueas ipsum: deinde eleua manum tuam: et non iteres ipsum omnino.	When boils are treated on the watery [skin], and they are filled with citron water: it is necessary to cauterize over the top of the foot in the night area, which is between the auricle bone and the ring bone: and lift your hand with the cauterizer, and do not twist it: then lift your hand: and do not repeat it at all.
Resudet enim aqua citrina, et sit cauterium secundum hanc formam.	The acid water will suffice, and let the cautery be according to this form.
Deinde fac super duo crura duo cauteria in omni crure, et fiat cauterium cum extremitate cultellari cauterii: et fiat cauterium secundum longitudinem cruris, unum sub genu, et alterum inferius eo, circiter medium cruris: et super omnem coxam cauteria duo: et dimitte cauterium apertum absque curatione tempore longo: ut resudet ex eo aliquod aquae: deinde cura ipsum cum reliquis quae diximus.	Then make on each leg two cautery incisions, and let the cautery be made with the sharp edge of the knife, and let the cautery be made according to the length of the leg, one below the knee, and the other lower in it, about the middle of the leg: and above each hip make two cauteries. And dismiss the open cautery without treatment for a long time, so that water will flow from it: then treat it with the rest which we have said.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in solutione Ventris.	On the method of cauterization in the treatment of an abdominal wound.
Caput XXXV.	Chapter XXXV.
Quando est solutio uentris ex frigore et humiditatibus, donec debilitet uirtutes retentiuam et digestiuam, quae sunt in stomacho et intestinis: et curatur illud cum modis curationis, et non sanatur: et uides infirmum tolerantem cauterium exuberantis uirtutis, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio magno super stomachum suum, secundum quod praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi cum cauterio circuli, et quatuor cauteriis in circumitu umbilici subtilibus, cum cauterio clauili subtili: et cauterio super alcatin supra alhosos magno, aut duobus cauteriis.	When there is a solution of the belly from cold and humidity, until it weakens the retaining and digestive powers that are in the stomach and intestines: and it is cured with modes of cure, and it does not heal: and you see the weak one enduring the cautery of exuberant virtue, then cauterize him with a great cautery over his stomach, according to what preceded in the cauterization of the stomach with a circular cautery, and four subtle cauteries in the circumference of the navel, with a subtle clauili cautery: and a cautery on the alcatin above the alhosos with a great one, or two cauteries.
Et si uides humiditates exuberantes, et infirmum tolerantem illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cauterio super pectinem, et cauterio super omne ilium: et fortasse addes duo cauteria parua super stomachum prope magnum.	And if you see abundant humidities and the weak one tolerating it, then cauterize him with a cautery on top of a comb, and cautery on all of it: and perhaps add two small cauteries near the stomach by the large one.
Est enim curatio proficiens, cuius iuuamentum non errat.	It is indeed a healing treatment, whose benefit does not fail.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Hemorroidas.	On the manner of cauterizing hemorrhoids.
Caput XXXVI.	Chapter XXXVI.
Quando in ano sunt Hemorroides antiquae multae, aut una, et sunt ex humoribus grossis, frigidis, aut humiditatibus corruptis, et curantur cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio: tunc cauteriza tribus cauteriis super inferiorem spondilem dorsi sub almeidati parumper triangulatim, et cauterio sub umbilico quasi duobus digitis.	When there are many old hemorrhoids in the anus, or one, and they are from thick humors, cold ones, or corrupted humidities, and they are treated with what we said in the division, and the treatment does not work: then cauterize with three cauterizations on the lower spine of the back, under a little bit shaped like a triangle, and with a cauterization under the navel, like two fingers.
Et si cogitas, quod stomachus eius infrigidatus sit, et cibus eius non digeratur, et faciem eius uides apostemari, tunc cauteriza eum super stomachum cauterio magno, secundum quod praecessit: et cauterio super Epar eius, et alio super Splenem ipsius, cum cauterio clauili: et dimitte cauterium apertum tempore aliquo: deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if you think that his stomach is chilled, and his food is not digested, and you see his face suppurate, then cauterize him over the stomach with a large cautery, according to what preceded: and with a cautery on his Epiploon, and another on his Spleen, with a caultery clamp: and release the open cautery after a while: then care for him until he heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi althelul post abscisionem eorum.	On the method of cauterizing a wound after its excision.
Caput XXXVII.	Chapter XXXVII.
Quando tu abscindis althelul, tunc ignias cauterium quod assimilatur radio.	When you cut the flesh, then apply fire cauterization that resembles a ray.
Deinde intromittite ipsum ignitum in ipsum althelul abscisum: et ultima manum tuam, donec perueniat cauterium ad orificium uenae, ex qua currit sanguis: fac illud semel, aut bis.	Then introduce the burning one into the cut flesh and last of your hand until the cauterizing comes to the mouth of the vein, through which blood flows; do it once, or twice.
Si ergo althelul fuerint multa, tunc cauteriza unumquodque cauterio secundum quod narrauimus.	If therefore the abscesses are many, then cauterize each one with a cautery according to what we have narrated.
Deinde cura ea, cum eo quod confert eis ex unguentis, donec sanentur.	Then care for that, with what it confers of ointment, until they are healed.
Et si cauterizas eum cauterio magno super alcatin, est magis ultimum in iuuamento.	And if you cauterize him with a large cautery on linen, it is more final in healing.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Fistulam in ano.	On the manner of cauterizing a fistula in the anus.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Quando non obedit infirmus sectioni et operi quod narrauimus in loco suo, et terretur ab illo, fortasse sanatur cum cauterio.	When the patient does not obey the incision and operation which we have narrated in its place, and fears it, perhaps he is healed with cauterization.
Cum ergo accidit alicui Fistula, et antiquatur, currit pus ex ea, et humiditates corruptae.	When therefore it happens to someone that they have a fistula, and it becomes old, pus runs out of it, and there are corrupt humors.
Dignius ergo quod oportet est, ut probes eam cum tenta subtili.	Therefore it is proper that you examine it with a fine probe.
Deinde cognosce quantitatem profunditatis eius cum tenta.	Then know the quantity of its depth with a probe.
Deinde ignias cauterium, quod est simile radio.	Then a burning cautery, which is like a ray.
Deinde intromit te ipsum ignitum in ipsam Fistulam et quantitatem in qua intrauit clauus.	Then introduce yourself burning into the fistula itself and the quantity into which the nail has entered.
Et itera super eam cauterium, donec comburantur illa omnia corpora corrupta, semel, aut bis, aut ter, secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And repeat the cautery over it until all those corrupted bodies are burned, once, or twice, or three times, according to the quantity of your necessity.
Et custodi te ab adustione nerui, si est illic, aut uenae magnae: aut si Fistula uadit ad corpus uesicae, aut ad corpus intestini, tunc custodi te ab istis locis omnibus.	And guard yourself from burning a nerve, if it is there, or a large vein: or if a fistula goes to the body of the bladder, or to the body of the intestine, then guard yourself from all these places.
Et non facias illud, nisi quando fistula est in loco carnoso: et cogitas, quia non est penetrans.	And do not do this unless there is a fistula in a fleshy place, and you think that it does not penetrate.
Deinde cura locum usquequo sanetur.	Then care for the place until it heals.
Si autem sigillatur locus, et abscinduntur ab eo materiae, et remanet sic tempore longo: tunc scias, quia iam sanatus est integre.	If, however, the place is sealed and the materials are cut away from it, and it remains so for a long time, then you will know that it has been healed completely.
Et si non abscindunt ab eo materiae, tunc scias quia est penetrans, aut in profundo eius est os corruptum, aut quasi illud ex illis: quorum rememoratio ueniet in loco suo.	And if they do not cut away the matter from it, then know that it is penetrating, or there is a corrupted opening in its depth, or like those of which remembrance will come in its place.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Renes.	On the method of cauterizing the kidneys.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando accidit in Renibus dolor ex frigore, aut ex uentositate grossa, et minuitur propter illud coius infirmi, tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum super almethenem super ipsos renes, cauterio super omnem renem cum cauterio clauili, cuius praecessit rememoratio.	When pain occurs in the kidneys from cold or thick wind, and it is diminished because of the weakness of the patient, then it is necessary to cauterize it above almethenem above the kidneys, with a cautery over the entire kidney with a cautery clamp, which preceded this recollection.
Et fortasse cauterizamus ipsum secundo in ipso almeidatu.	And perhaps we cauterize it a second time in the very wound.
Quare uenient tria lineata.	Therefore three lines will come.
Ergo erunt magis ultima in iuuamento.	Therefore they will be more useful in healing.
¶ De modo cauteritzandi Vesicam.	On the method of cauterizing the bladder.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Quando accidunt in Vesica debilitas, et mollificatio a frigo re et humiditatibus, donec non retineat infirmus urinam, tunc cauteriza ipsum in inferiori parte suminis super Vesicam, ubi incipiunt pili pectinis, et cauterio a dextra suminis, et alio a sinistra illius: et sit longitudo illius cauterizationis lateris secundum quantitatem nodi pollicis: et cauteriza ipsum cauterio inferiori dorsi, aut duobus cauteriis, si indiges illo: et sit secundum quod praecessit cauterium clauile.	When weakness and softening occur in the bladder from cold and moisture until it cannot hold weak urine, then cauterize it in the lower part of the pubis above the bladder, where the hairs of the comb begin, and with one cautery from the right pubis, and another from the left of it: and let the length of this cauterization be according to the amount of a finger-knuckle, and cauterize it with a lower cautery of the back, or with two cauteries if you need it: and let the cautery be closed as before.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Matricem.	On the method of cauterizing the Matrix.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLIX.
Quando accidunt in Matrice frigus et humiditates, et prohibetur per illud ab impregnatione, et corrumpuntur menstrua eius, et tardatur prouocatio eorum, et accidit ei apud aduentum eorum dolor, tunc oportet ut cauterizetur tribus cauteriis in circumitu umbilici, sicut diximus in cauterizatione uesicae, et cauterio super alcatim inferius dorso, aut duobus cauteriis: et sit cauterium clauile.	When coldness and moisture occur in the womb, and it is prevented by this from conception, and its menstrual flow is corrupted, and its arrival is delayed, and pain occurs to her upon their arrival, then it is necessary that she be cauterized with three cauteries around the navel, as we said in the cauterization of the bladder, and with a cautery above the lower linen on the back, or with two cauteries: and let the cautery be clauile.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Ancham in dislocatione.	On the manner of cauterizing a joint in dislocation.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII.
Quando effunduntur humiditates mucosae ad pixidem Anchae, et fiunt caussa exitus eius a loco suo: et signum illius est, quod prolongatur crus super alterum, quando comparantur adinuicem: et inuenitur locus dislocationis in eo uacuus.	When the mucus humors are poured out to the Anchae point, and they become the cause of its exit from its place: and the sign of it is that one leg is lengthened over the other when they are compared adinuicem: and the place of dislocation is found in it empty.
Oportet ergo ut cauterizes infirmum super pixidem Anchae ipsius cauterio simili circulo: postquam tu signas cum encaustro in circumitu pixidis, sicut reuoluitur: et ut cadat ipsa pixis in medio circuli.	Therefore it is necessary that the weak one be cauterized over the base of Anchae with a similar cautery circle; after you have marked with encaustic on the circumference of the base, just as it turns: and that the very base may fall in the middle of the circle.
Et sit cauterium cuius forma praecessit in cauterizatione stomachi.	And let there be a cautery whose form preceded in the cauterization of the stomach.
Quod si tibi non est praesens hoc cauterium, tunc cauteriza ipsum tribus cauteriis, cum cauterio oliuari magno: et fiat cauterio profunditas secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis totius.	If this cautery is not present for you, then cauterize it with three cauteries, with a large olive-wood cautery; and let the depth of the cautery be according to the amount of thickness of the whole skin.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of him until he is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Sciatica.	On the method of cauterization in sciatica.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Quando accidit dolor in pixide anchae, et sunt caussa illius frigus et humiditates: et curatur infirmus cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio, et antiquatur illud: tunc oportet ut soluas infirmum ab humoribus grossis cum pillulis foetidis, aut cum pillulis artificialibus, et similibus.	When pain occurs in the hip joint and the cause is cold and moisture, and the sick person is treated with what we said in the division, and the treatment does not help, and it becomes old: then it is necessary to treat the sick person from gross humors with foul pills or artificial pills, and similar ones.
Deinde cauteriza eum.	Then cauterize it.
Et modus cauterii in ea est secundum duos modos: aut cauterium cum medicinis adurentibus, aut cauterium cum igne.	And the mode of cauterization in it is according to two modes: either cauterization with medicines that burn, or cauterization with fire.
Cauterium cum igne, est secundum multos modos.	Cauterization with fire is according to many modes.
Quorum unus est, ut cauterizes super pixidem anchae ipsius tribus cauteriis triangulatis, secundum hanc formam.	One of these is to cauterize over the pyxis of the anus with three triangular cauteries, according to this form.
Et fac eis profunditatem bonam, uel malam.	And make for them a good depth, or a bad one.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne cauterium quantitatis grossitudinis digiti: sitque cauterium oliuare.	Let there be a space which is between every cautery of the thickness of a finger; let the cautery be oiled.
Quandoque autem fit cauterium in medio super caput anchae ipsius.	Sometimes a cautery is applied in the middle on top of the arch of the same (bone).
Quare sunt quatuor cauteria.	Therefore there are four cauteries.
Et si uis cauteriza cum circulo, cuius praecessit forma in cauterizatione dislocationis anchae, uno: ut sit circulus continens ancham totam.	And if you wish to cauterize with a circle, whose form preceded in the cauterization of the dislocation of the hip, one: that it be a circle containing the entire hip.
Et combure spissitudinem cutis totius.	And burn the thickness of the skin entirely.
Iste est modus cauterii in Sciatica, quando dolor est adhaerens anchae ipsi, et non extenditur usque ad coxam et crus.	This is the mode of cauterization in sciatica when the pain adheres to the hip and does not extend to the hip and leg.
Si autem extenditur usque ad coxam et crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum duobus cauteriis super coxam, super locum ad quem innuit illic infirmus, in quo est dolor, et cauterio tuo super cauillam quatuor digitis ad partem syluestrem parumper: et sit cauterium cultellare.	If it extends to the hip and leg, then cauterize it with two cauteries above the hip, above the place where the sick man indicates, where there is pain, and with your cautery on the tail four fingers' breadth to the left part a little: and let the cautery be a knife-like one.
Et sit profunditas cauterii secundum profunditatem spissitudinis cutis.	And let the depth of the cautery be according to the depth of the thickness of the skin.
Quod si infirmus innuit quod dolor extenditur usque prope digitos pedis, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic ubi innuit cum cauterio puncti, tribus, aut quatuor, aut pluribus, si indiget illo.	If the patient states that the pain extends almost to the toes of his foot, then cauterize him there where he indicates with a cautery point, three, or four, or more, if it is needed.
Et si innuit dolorem esse sub genu uersus crus, tunc cauteriza ipsum illic cauterio uno cultellari.	And if he indicates pain being under the knee towards the leg, then cauterize it there with a single knife cautery.
Et caue tibi in omni cauterizatione tua, ut non ultimes cum cauterio ad hoc ut comburas neruum, aut arteriam magnam, et attrahas per illud super infirmum nocumentum malum, aut contractionem.	And beware in all your cauterizations that you do not go to the extreme with the cautery so as to burn nerves or a large artery and draw through it an evil ill upon the weak, or contraction.
Et ego quidem iam uidi unum et alium, ex eis qui cauterizauerunt supra cauillam, et ultimauerunt in cauterizatione, et inflatum est crus, donec tumor consecutus est pedem, et perforatus est totus, et corruptus est totus pes: deinde accidit solutio uentris, et mors post illud.	And I have indeed seen one and another of those who cauterized above the groin, and continued in the cauterization, and the leg was inflated until the swelling reached the foot, and the whole was perforated and the whole foot corrupted; then there occurred a solution of the belly, and death after that.
Quod si dolor est in duabus partibus simul, cauteriza utramque secundum hunc modum.	If there is pain in two parts at the same time, cauterize both according to this method.
Et sapientes quidam dixerunt in cauterizatione anchae, cuius cauterii iste est modus.	And some wise men said in cauterization of the anus, whose cautery this is the way.
Fac simile samio ex ferro, cuius diametrus sit medietas palmi: et sit apud orificium suum secundum grossitudinem nuclei dactyli, aut minus parumper: et intra illud samium sit samium tertium.	Make a probe like a rod of iron, whose diameter is half a palm: and let it be at its opening according to the thickness of a finger's kernel, or a little less: and inside that probe let there be a third probe.
Et sit spacium quod est inter omne samium per quantitatem nodi pollicis: et sint samia aperta a duabus partibus: et sit altitudo eorum quasi nodus, aut duo nodi: et fac eis manubrium ex ferro decenter aptatum in samiis.	And let there be a space which is between every ligature the quantity of a thumb's width: and let the ligatures be open from two parts: and let their height be like a knuckle, or two knuckles: and make for them a handle out of iron fitted in the center in the ligatures.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Deinde igniatur in igne, donec rubeat, et proiiciat scintillas: deinde ponatur super pixidem anchae infirmo accubitato super latus sanum.	Then it is set on fire until it glows red and throws sparks; then it is placed upon the wax of the infirm limb laid on its sound side.
Cauteriza ergo eum tribus cauteriis rotundis in uice una.	Therefore cauterize him with three round cautery tools in one place.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus.	Then let him be left undisturbed for three days.
Postea emplastra cum butyro: et dimitte uulnus apertum diebus multis.	Afterwards apply plasters with butter: and let the open wound be left for many days.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis, hac specie cauterii o filii, parum usi sumus, propter terrorem aspectus eius: et propterea, quod paucos inuenimus qui expectent super ipsum.	Albucasis says, on this kind of cautery, my sons, we have used it little, because of the fear of its appearance: and therefore, because we have found few who await it upon itself.
Verumtamen est ex bonis cauteriis ei qui suffert, et inuenit cum eo locum eius.	Nevertheless it is good for those who suffer from it, and finds with it its place.
Cauterium autem cum medicinis adurentibus est, ut tu facias duo samia habentia perforatam armillam, in quam descendit cardo portae eius ex aere, aut ferro, longitudo parietis: quorum in altitudinem eorum sint duo nodi, aut quasi ipsi.	But cauterium with medicinal things burning is, that you make two samia having perforated armilla, into which descends the hinge of its door from brass, or iron, length of the wall: of which the height of them are two knots, or as themselves.
Et sit spacium quod est inter utraque quantitas grossitudinis digiti, et sint aperta inferius et superius: et sit quod contineant se adinuicem, secundum hanc formam.	And let there be a space that is between the two quantities the thickness of a finger, and let them be open below and above: and let it be such that they contain themselves adjacent to each other, according to this form.
Deinde depone eam super pixidem anchae, infirmo iacente super latus sanum.	Then place it over the wax tablet, with the weak one lying on his healthy side.
Et comprime manum tuam super pixidem anchae multum.	And press your hand upon the resin of the cavity much.
Deinde funde inter duos circulos ex aqua calida, quae sit calefacta cum igne parumper, et tene eam quantitate horae temporalis: et toleret infirmus mordicationem eius, et ipsius adustionem, nam ipse inuenit mordicationem sicut ignis, donec quiescat mordicatio.	Then pour between two circles hot water, which has been heated for a short time with fire, and keep it for an hour's time: and let the sick person endure its biting and burning, for he himself found the biting like fire until the biting subsides.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum instrumento, et absterge aquam calidam ab ancha tota cum aqua dulci: deinde dimitte illud tribus diebus.	Then lift your hand with the instrument and wipe away the hot water from the whole incision with sweet water; then leave it alone for three days.
Et pone super illud butyrum, donec remoueatur nigredo adustionis: et dimitte illud diebus aliquot, et curret ex eo pus.	And put butter on top of it until the blackness of the burn is removed; and let it sit for several days, and pus will flow from it.
Est enim ultimum in iuuamento.	It is indeed the last resort in healing.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it with ointments until it heals.
Quod si extendatur dolor usque ad coxam, aut crus: fac ei statuam in eo quod continet aquam, secundum quod fecisti in ancha aequaliter.	If pain extends to the hip or leg, make for him a position in that which contains water, according to what you have done in ancha equally.
Et iste est modus aquae calidae: et ego iam scripsi eam in tractatu rectificationis medicinarum.	And this is the method of hot water: and I have already written it in the treatise on the rectification of medicines.
Sume alcali, et calcis non extinctae amborum ana partem unam: tere utraque, et pone ea in ollam nouam, cuius inferior pars sit perforata foramine uno paruo, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum radius: et pone sub fundo ollae ollam aliam uitreatam: et proiice super alcali et calcem ex aqua dulci, quod submergat utraque per digitum: post quam tu comprimas ea manu tua compressione bona: et dimite ollam, donec descendat aqua acuta inferiori parte ollae uitreatae.	Take alkali and unquenched quicklime, each one part. Grind both, and place them in a new pot, whose lower part is pierced with a small hole, according to the quantity that will enter the radius: and place under the bottom of the pot another pot glazed: and pour over the alkali and quicklime from sweet water, so that both are submerged by a finger: after which you compress them with your hand good compression: and let go of the pot until the sharp water descends to the lower part of the glazed pot.
Deinde aggrega illam aquam totam, et proiice eam super aliam calcem: et cola, donec renouetur.	Then gather all that water and pour it over another lime mortar: and stir it until it is renewed.
Ipsa enim erit tunc fortis acuitatis ualde, quae administratur in multis operationibus medicinae, et in cauterizatione reliquorum membrorum.	For it will then be a keen sharpness of great force which is administered in many operations of medicine and the cauterization of the remaining members.
Quoniam efficit operationem ignis ipsius.	For it performs the operation of fire itself.
Et ex medicinis sunt, cum quibus cauterizantur ancha, etiam sicut tesisie, et mel anacardi, et calx cum sapone, ita quod utraque sint permixta. ¶	And among medicines there are those with which wounds are cauterized, even as a sponge, and oil of cashew nut, and chalk mixed with soap, so that both may be mixed together.
Et Galenus quidem narrando retulit, cuiusdam uiri ex antiquis curationem, qua curatus est dolor anchae et uenae sciaticae: et magnificauit esse eius ualde.	And Galen indeed narrating recounted, of a certain man from ancient times the cure, by which he was cured of pain in the hip and sciatic vein: and magnified it to be truly great.
Et dixit, quia non indiguit alia curatione, et quia sanatus est ex uice una, donec retulit, quia ipse fortasse intrauit balneum delatus, et exiuit ex eo iam sanus.	And he said, because he did not need other treatment, and because he was healed from one vice until he returned, because perhaps he himself had entered the bath carried in, and came out of it already healed.
Et est, ut accipiatur ex seitaragi uiridi: et si non inuenitur uiride, sumatur siccum, recens: et teratur multum cum aliquanto adipe, et ponatur super ancham, ubi est dolor, aut crus, aut in coxa: et ligetur, et dimittatur quantitate trium horarum, aut per quantitatem quod sentiat infirmus sedationem adustionis.	And it is, as to be taken from the seitaragi green: and if not found green, take dry, fresh: and arranged much with a little fat, and put upon an ache, where there is pain, or leg, or in the hip: and bind it, and let it go for a quantity of three hours, or for a quantity that the sick person feels sedation burning.
Deinde intromitte eum in balneum.	Then introduce him into a bath.
Cum ergo roridum fit corpus eius, intromitte ipsum in solium.	When therefore the body is made wet, introduce it into the socket.
Nam dolor recedit, et sanatur.	For the pain departs, and it is healed.
Et scias, quia non oportet ut utatur aliquis cauterio cum istis medicinis, nisi post euacuationem corporis.	And know that it is not right for someone to use a cautery with these medicines unless after evacuation of the body.
Et Dioscorides qui dem dixit, quod stercus caprarum, quando cum eo cauterizatur uena sciatica, confert ei: et fit cauterium secundum hunc modum.	And Dioscorides who said that the dung of goats, when it is cauterized with a vein, helps it; and the cautery is made in this way.
Sumatur lana, et imbibatur oleo antiquo, et ponatur super locum profundum, qui est inter pollicem pedis, et inter focile, et est propinquior focili.	Take wool and soak it in old oil and place it over the deep spot which is between the little toe and the heel, and it is closer to the heel.
Deinde accipe stercus caprarum siccum, et inflamma ipsum in igne, donec fiat carbo.	Then take dry goat dung, and set it on fire until it becomes charcoal.
Deinde pone ipsum super lanam, et dimitte ipsum, donec extinguatur.	Then place him upon wool, and let him alone until it is extinguished.
Deinde itera illud.	Then repeat it.
Non cesses ergo facere illud, usquequo perueniat sensus super mediatione usque ad ancham, et quiescat dolor.	Therefore, do not cease doing this until you come to a sense through mediation up to nightfall, and the pain rests.
Et iste modus cauterii nominatur cauterium Vaccinum.	And this method of cautery is called cautery Vaccinum.
¶ De cauterizatione doloris Dorsi.	On cauterization of back pain.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Quandoque accidit dolor in Dorso ex caussis multis, aut a casu, aut a percussione, aut euacuatione superflua, et illis similibus, ex infusione materiei frigidae, et humidae: et cauterium quidem non cadit, nisi in hac specie sola, quae fit ex infusione materiei frigidae.	Sometimes pain occurs in the back from many causes, either from a fall, or from a blow, or from evacuation of excess, and those similar things, from the infusion of cold and moist matter: and cauterization does not apply, except in this single kind, which is produced from the infusion of cold matter.
Oportet ergo post euacuationem infirmi cum pillulis foetidis, et eis similibus, ut fiant super Dorsum, ubi est dolor, tres lineae secundum latitudinem almeidati ipsius, postquam signas cum encaustro in omni linea quinque cauteria, aut plura secundum quantitatem quae uenit ex tolerantia infirmi uirtute eius: et fiat cauterizatio cum cauteriopuncti.	Therefore, after the evacuation of the sick person, with bitter pills and similar ones, let three lines be made on the back where there is pain, according to the width of the wound itself, after having marked signs with encaustic on each line five cauterizations, or more according to the quantity which comes from the endurance of the patient's strength: and let the cauterization be done with a cautery point.
Et si uis, cauteriza tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor, cum cauterio clauili mediali, secundum hanc formam.	And if you wish, cauterize with three or four cauteries, with a medium-sized clamp cautery, according to this form.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in incaeptine Gibbositatis.	On the manner of cauterizing in an unhealed gibbosity.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV.
Multotiens accidit haec aegritudo infantibus paruis.	This illness often happens to small children.
Et signum incaeptionis eius in pueris est: quod accidit super eum strictura in anhelitu apud eleuationem, et motum: et inuenis in ultima spondilium Dorsi et nodorum eius, quod iam incaepit eminere super reliquos spondiles.	And the sign of its beginning in boys is that which occurs upon him constriction in breathing when elevated and in motion; and you find it in the last vertebra of the back and its knots, which has already begun to protrude above the remaining vertebrae.
Cum ergo uides illud, et uis facere illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio quod sit circulus secundum hanc formam.	When therefore you see that and wish to make that, then cauterize it with a cautery which is a circle according to this form.
Et capiat cauterium super omnem partem spondilis aequaliter: et si uis cauteriza in circumitu spondilis cum cauterio puncti duas lineas, aut tres: et sint puncta propinqua adinuicem.	And let him take the cautery over every part of the vertebra equally: and if you wish to cauterize around the vertebra with a cautery point two lines, or three: and let the points be close together in sequence.
Deinde cura locum, donec sanetur cum eo quod diximus.	Then take care of the place until it heals with what we said.
Et caue, ne administres cauterium in gibbositate, quae fit in spasmo nerui.	And beware, lest you apply a cautery to the hump that occurs in a nerve spasm.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Podagra, et doloribus iuncturarum.	On the method of cauterization in gout, and joint pain.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVII.
Quando dolores iuncturarum sunt ab humiditatibus frigidis, quae effunduntur ad cuiuslibet membra corporis, tunc quando accidunt dolores in pedibus, de consuetudine medicorum est, ut nominent illud Podagram proprie.	When pains in the joints are from cold moisture which flows to any limb of the body, then when pains occur in the feet, it is customary for physicians to call that Podagra properly.
Cum ergo curatur Podagra frigidae caussae cum modis curationis, et non remouentur dolores, tune cauterium remouet eos.	When therefore gout is treated with cold causes and methods of treatment, and the pains are not removed, then cautery will remove them.
Et est, ut cauterizes eum post euacuationem in circumitu iuncturae pedum, cauteriis multis: et sit cauterium Oliuare.	And it is, that you cauterize him after evacuation at the juncture of the feet, with many cauteries: and let the cautery be Oil-bearing.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Et si indiges ut punctes super faciem pedis, tunc fac cum cauterio puncti.	And if you need to make points on the face of the foot, then make them with a cautery.
Quod si ascendunt dolores usque ad genua, aut reliquas iuncturas, et multotiens accidit illud, tunc cauteriza ipsum super omne genu tribus cauteriis, aut quatuor ab omni parte, cum hoc eodem cauterio Clauili.	If the pain rises as far as the knees or other joints, and this often happens, then cauterize the area above each knee with three or four cauterizations from every part, using the same cautery as Claudius.
Si autem necessaria sunt tibi plura hoc cauterio, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	If you need more of this cauterization, then cauterize it.
Et non submergas manum tuam cum cauterio, imo sit circiter spissitudinem cutis tantum.	And do not submerge your hand with the cautery, but let it be about the thickness of the skin only.
Si autem ascendunt dolores ad genua, et dorsum: tunc administra quod diximus ex cauterio in capitulo suo.	If however pains ascend to the knees and back, then administer what we said from cauterization in its chapter.
Quod si dolores sunt in manibus tantum, tunc puncta in circumitu focilium, sicut reuoluuntur duae lineae.	If the pains are in the hands only, then points on the circumference of the focus, as if two lines were revolving, .
Si autem remanet ex doloribus in digitis, tunc puncta eos, super omnem nodum punctum, et super pectinem manus.	If pain remains in the fingers, then prick them, above every node and on the palm of the hand.
Si autem ascendunt dolores post dies ad cubitos, aut ad humeros, tunc cauteriza utrosque ab omni parte.	If pains should rise after days to the armpits, or to the shoulders, then cauterize both from every part.
Et non euacues infirmum ex regimine bono, ex recaeptione medicinarum.	And do not evacuate the sick from good regimen, from the reception of medicines.
Nam si bonum fiat regimen, et euacuetur phlegma, sanabitur auxilio Dei cum isto cauterio.	If a good regimen is followed and phlegm is evacuated, he will be healed with the help of God and this cautery.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Rupturis.	On the mode of cauterizing in ruptures.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quando accidit Ruptura in inguinibus, et descendit intestinum, aut zirbum ad testiculum, et est illud incipiens propinquum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo dimittere comestionem in die suo.	When a rupture occurs in the groin and intestine or part of the bowel descends to the testicle, and it is beginning to approach close: then it is necessary that you order the sick person to abstain from eating on his day.
Et utatur ex lenientibus, quo descendat stercus a uentre suo.	And let him use soothing things so that feces may descend from his belly.
Deinde sedeat inter manus tuas super dorsum suum: et praecipe ei, ut teneat anhelitum suum, donec egrediatur, uel appareat zirbum, aut intestinum.	Then let him sit between your hands on his back; and command him to hold his breath until it comes out, or the appendix appears, or the intestine.
Deinde reduc ipsum digitis tuis, et signa cum encaustro sub Ruptura super os pectinis, cum signo cuius extremitas sit similis medietati circuli ad superiora corporis.	Then reduce it with your fingers, and mark with encaustic above the rupture on the bone of the breastbone, with a mark whose extremity is similar to half a circle towards the upper part of the body.
Deinde igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma, donec ueniat album, et proiiciat seintillas.	Then the fire cauterizer, whose this form is, until it comes white and throws sparks.
Deinde reduc intestinum, aut zirbum ad concauitatem suam.	Then reduce the intestine, or rectum, to its cavity.
Deinde ponat minister manum suam super locum, ut non exeat intestinum: et tu iam aperuisti inter crura infirmi, et posuisti sub eo puluinar, et seruiens alius super crura eius, et alius super pectus eius qui tenet manus.	Then the assistant places his hand over the place so that the intestine does not escape: and you have already opened between the legs of the infirm, and placed a pillow under him, and one servant on his legs, and another on his chest who holds his hands.
Deinde depone cauterium super ipsum signum, manu tua cum cauterio stante recta.	Then place the cautery over that mark, with your hand holding the cautery straight.
Et tene ipsum, donec cum eo consequaris os: aut itera cum eo uice alia, si non consecutus fueris cum eo in prima usque ad os.	And hold it so until you obtain the bone with it; or if you have not succeeded with it in the first attempt, use another tool with it until you reach the bone.
Et prudenter obserua ab exitu intestini in hora cauterizationis tuae, ne comburas ipsum, et eueniat per illud super infirmum aut mors, aut malicia magna.	And carefully observe from the exit of the intestine at the hour of your cauterization, lest you burn it, and through it there may come over the weak either death or great evil.
Et scias, quod quando tu non consequeris cum cauterio os, non confert operatio tua.	And know that when you do not achieve the bone with the cautery, your operation is of no use.
Et oportet ut sit cauterium infantium subtile, secundum mensuram eorum.	And it is necessary that the cautery for infants be fine, according to their measure.
Deinde cura cum reliquis unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care with the rest of the ointment, until it is healed.
Et sit infirmus iacens super dorsum suum quadraginta diebus, donec sigilletur uulnus.	And let the sick person lie on his back for forty days until the wound is sealed.
Et oportet, ut ponas nutrimentum eius longitudine temporis curationis eius, quod leniat uentrem eius: ut non exeat intestinum apud conamen et egestionem.	And it is necessary that you put nourishment to him according to the length of time of his healing, which will soothe his stomach; so that it does not go out of the intestine at defecation.
Deinde quando uult surgere post quadraginta dies, tunc administra ligamentum decenter factum, et teneat ipsum quadraginta diebus aliis.	Then when he wishes to have surgery after forty days, then administer a bandage made correctly and let him keep it for another forty days.
Et minoretur a labore, et repletione cibi et potus, et uocibus uehementibus.	And he should avoid labor, and overeating of food and drink, and loud voices.
Nam quando utitur hoc regimine, ita sanatur sanatione integra.	For when this treatment is used, it heals with complete healing.
Et ego dicam curationem Rupturarum cum incisione in capitulo suo.	And I will speak of the cure of ruptures with an incision in its chapter.
Quando autem Rupturae accidunt in reliquo uentre, et sunt incipientes, et uis ut non addantur, tunc cauteriza Rupturam eius cauterio rotundo secundum quantitatem eius: et sit illud quod aduritur ex tunc sicut tertia eius.	When ruptures occur in the rest of the abdomen and are beginning and you wish them not to increase, then cauterize the rupture with a rounded cautery according to its size; and let that which is burned from then be like one-third of it.
Deinde cura ipsum, cum eo quod diximus: et non addetur.	Then care for it as we have said: and nothing more shall be added.
Et iam dixerunt quidam primi: ut cauterizetur Ruptura cum cauterio triangulato, secundum hanc formam.	And now some of the first said that a rupture should be cauterized with a triangular cautery, according to this form.
Postquam signatur cum encaustro, et ponitur linea quae est per latitudinem in latere superiori Rupturae, et linea altera ad inferius.	After it is marked with wax and a line is placed which is across the width on the upper side of the rupture, and another line below.
Et depone manum tuam in medio cum cauterio clauili.	And lay your hand in the middle with the cautery closed.
Sed cauterium primum est facilius et melius.	But a cautery is first easier and better.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in doloribus propter casum, aut percussionem.	On the manner of cauterization for pains caused by a fall, or a blow.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Quando accidit in quibusdam membris a casu, aut percussione dolor: et perseuerat ille dolor tempore longo, et non confert in eo curatio cum medicinis: tunc oportet ut cauterizetur cum cauterio Puncti.	When pain occurs in certain limbs by chance or percussion, and that pain persists for a long time, and there is no help with medicine in it: then it should be cauterized with the point cautery.
Et sit cauterium omnis membri cauterium secundum magnitudinem eius, et ipsius paruitatem, et debilitatem eius, et ipsius uirtutem, et locationem torsionis, et doloris ex eo.	And let the cautery for every member be a cautery according to its size, and its suitability, and its weakness, and its power, and the location of the twisting, and the pain from it.
Si ergo sanatur ex cauterio primo, est bene.	If therefore it is healed from the first cautery, it is well.
Si non: tunc itera super ipsum cauterium.	If not, then repeat cauterization over it.
Quoniam de consuetudine horum dolorum est, ut permutentur ex membro ad illud quod appropinquat ei.	Because of the custom of these pains, it is that they are changed from limb to that which is near it.
Quare oportet ut consequaris eos cum cauterio, donec sanetur infirmus.	Therefore it is necessary that you follow them with a cautery until the sick person is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Lepra.	On the way of cauterizing in leprosy.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLIX.
Leprosi autem quandoque iuuantur cauterio iuuamento maximo.	Sometimes leprosy is helped with cauterization, to great benefit.
Et praecipue species Leprae, quae fit propter putrefactionem phlegmatis et melancholiae: cum ergo uis cauterizare ipsam considera.	And especially the kind of leprosy, which comes from the rotting of phlegm and black bile: therefore when you wish to cauterize it consider this.
Si ergo Lepra est ineipiciens, et curasti eam cum eo, quod diximus in diuisione, et non descendit, neque stat: et times super infirmum, quod comprehendat corruptio super totam complexionem eius: tunc cauteriza eum super caput quinque cauteriis: uno in medio capitis noto, et secundo inferius eo uersus frontem apud finem capillorum, et duobus super duo cornua, et uno posterius super nucea ceruicis.	If therefore leprosy is unrelenting, and you have treated it with that which we said in the division, and it has not descended, nor stood still; and you fear above the infirmity, that corruption may encompass the entire complexion of him: then cauterize him upon the head with five cauteries: one in the middle of the head noted, and a second below towards the forehead at the end of the hairs, and two upon the two horns, and one behind upon the nape of the neck.
Et ultima manum tuam cum cauterio parumper, donec imprimat in os impressionem paruam, et dislocentur ex eo cortices: ut alleuietur expiratio uaporum grossorum ex eo, et cauteriza cauterio etiam super ipsum splenem, secundum quod praecessit.	And last your hand with a cautery briefly, until it imprints in the bone a small impression, and the cortices are separated from it: so that the expelling of vapors gross may be alleviated from it, and cauterize also the spleen above it, as preceding.
Sin autem Lepra iam sparsa est super infirmum, et apparet manifeste: tunc oportet ut cauterizes cum istis cauteriis, quae diximus in capite, et cauterio super extremitatem nasi, et duobus cauteriis super duas maxillas, et duobus cauteriis super spondiles colli, et sex super spondiles dorsi, et uno magno super alhahosos apud gran caudae et uno supra ipsum, in ipso almeidati: et duobus super anchas: scilicet super omnem ancham uno, et duobus super genua: uno super omne genu, et duobus super humeros, et duobus super cubitos, et duobus super teneritudines pectoris sui: et cauteriza ipsum super omnem iuncturam, ex iuncturis digitorum manuum suarum, et pedum suorum: et cauteriza super omnem calcaneum pedum suorum, et focilia manuum suarum.	If leprosy has already spread over the infirm person and is manifest: then it is necessary that you cauterize with these cauteries which we have said in the beginning, and one cautery on the extremity of the nose, and two cauteries on the two maxillae, and two cauteries on the vertebrae of the neck, and six on the vertebrae of the back, and one large one on the buttocks near the great tail and one above it, in the very middle: and two on the flanks; namely on every flank one, and two on the knees; one on every knee, and two on the shoulders, and two on the forearms, and two on the tender parts of his chest: and cauterize him on every joint, from the joints of the fingers of his hands, and feet of his. And cauterize on every heel of his feet, and the palms of his hands.
Et caue tibi a neruis qui sunt super postremum calcanei, ut non comburas eos.	And beware of the nerves that are on top of the heel bone, so that you do not burn them.
Et quandoque cauterizatur cauterio super os pectinis, et alio super os stomachi, et alio super epar.	And sometimes it is cauterized with a cautery on the bone of the breastbone, and another on the bone of the stomach, and another on the hip.
Et scias, quod quanto plus addis cauterium, est magis iuuamentum, et magis conferens.	And know that the more you add cauterium, it is more helpful and more effective.
Et scias, quod infirmus non inuenit in cauterio dolorem, sicut inueniunt ipsum sani: propterea, quod corpus eius iam stupefactum est.	And know that the sick person does not find pain in cauterization as do those who are healthy, because the body of the former is already numb.
Et oportet ut sint cauteria ex magnitudine, et paruitate secundum membra et iuncturas: secundum quod praecessit ex speciebus ferramentorum.	And it is necessary that they be cauteries in size and shape according to the members and joints; according to what has preceded from the kinds of instruments.
Deinde cura cauterium ex farina herbi cum melle, et reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for a cautery from herb flour with honey, and the rest of the cure, until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Stupore.	On the method of cauterization in stupor.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Quando stupet aliquod membrum, et curatur cum medicinis, et oleis, et emplastris, et non sanatur, tunc cauteriza ipsum membrum stupefactum cauteriis, secundum quod meretur magnitudo membri, aut paruitas eius.	When a certain limb is numb and is treated with medicines, oils, and plasters, and does not heal, then cauterize that numbed limb with cautery irons, according to what the size of the limb or its smallness merits.
Et sit cauterium tuum intrans in spissitudinem cutis parumper.	And let your cautery penetrate into the thickness of the skin a little.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointment until it heals.
Et quandoque cauterizatur ad quiddam stuporis, qui accidit manui, et pedi, in spondilibus dorsi apud exitum neruorum, qui mouent illud membrum: et remouetur stupor.	And sometimes it is cauterized to some kind of numbness that happens to the hand and foot, in the vertebrae of the back at the exit of the nerves that move that limb: and the numbness is removed.
Verum non praesumat super illud, nisi qui est sapiens in anatomia membrorum, et egressione neruorum mouentium corpus.	But he should not presume upon it, unless he is wise in the anatomy of the limbs, and the egress of the moving nerves of the body.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Albaras.	On the manner of cauterization in Albaras.
Caput LI.	Chapter LXI.
Quando antiquatur Albaras, et non confert in eo aliquid ex ingeniis medicinae: tunc cauteriza super ipsam cauterio profundo parumper, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis cutis, donec remoueatur albedo, et mutetur color eius.	When Albucasis treats a wound and finds nothing of the medical arts in it; then he cauterizes over it with deep cautery for a short time, according to the quantity of thickness of skin, until the whiteness is removed, and its color is changed.
Deinde cura ipsum cum farina herbi, et lentis cum oleo rosa, et foliis arnoglossae, et sanguine columbae, et sanguine hyrundinis: de unoquoque sit pars una: misceantur haec omnia, et liniantur super pannum, et adhaereant loco, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound with flour of herbs, and lentils with rose oil, and arnoglossa leaves, and dove blood, and swallow blood: let there be one part of each; mix all these things, and spread them on cloth, and attach them to the place until it heals.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Cancro.	On the method of cauterization in cancer.
Caput LII.	Chapter LII.
Quando Cancer est incipiens, et uis ipsum sistere: tunc cauteriza ipsum cum cauterio circuli in circuitu eius, sicuti reuoluitur.	When cancer is beginning, and you wish to stop it, then cauterize it with a circular cautery around it, as it revolves.
Sapientes autem dixerunt, ut cauterizetur cauterio ultimo in medio.	Wise men have said that it should be cauterized with the last cautery in the middle.
Mihi autem non uidetur illud: quoniam timeo quod ulceretur: et ego iam uidi illud aliquotiens.	It does not seem right to me, because I fear that it would become an ulcer, and I have already seen this happen several times.
Et rectius est, ut cauterizetur in circumitu eius cum circulo, sicut diximus: aut cauteriis multis.	And it is better that it be cauterized around it with a circle, as we said; or with many cauteries.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Adubelati.	On the mode of cauterization in Adubelati.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Quando aliquis habet Adubelati, et tardatur in maturatione, aut propter superfluitatem facientem eam, aut propter aetatem infirmi, quando est decrepitus pauci sanguinis, aut propter tempus, et uis festinare in maturatione Adubelati, tunc cauteriza in circumitu eius cum cauteriis paruis multis punctando.	When someone has an abscess and it is delayed in ripening, either because of an excess of matter forming it, or because of the age of the patient, when he is old and has little blood, or because of time, and the desire to hasten the ripening of the abscess, then cauterize around it with small, many cauteries, puncturing.
Deinde dimitte eam.	Then release it.
Nam ipsa festinabit cum maturatione.	For it itself will hasten with ripening.
Si autem uis perforationem eius cum cauterio, tunc igni cauterium, cuius haec est forma.	If you wish to make a perforation of it with a cautery, then heat the cautery, which has this form.
Et depone ipsum in medio Adubelati, donec penetret cutem: et sit cauterium ab eo quod sequitur infirmus, ut alleuietur cursus puris.	And lay him down in the middle of Abulati, until it penetrates the skin; and let the cautery be from that which follows weak, so that the flow may be relieved by the pure.
Deinde cura ipsum donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it is healed.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in malo corrodente.	On the method of cauterizing in a bad corrosive.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIII.
Corrodens non est nisi corruptio in membro ambulans, et corrodit ipsum: sicut ignis comedit ligna sicca.	A gnawing is nothing except for corruption in a moving limb, and it gnaws at itself, just as fire consumes dry wood.
Si ergo uides corrodentem in loco qui toleret cauterium cum igne, tunc igni cauteria multa, clauilia parua et magna, secundum quod conueniet illi loco in quo est corrodens.	If therefore you see a corrosion in a place which can bear cautery with fire, then cauterize with much fire, small and large clamps, according to what is convenient for the place in which the corrosion is.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum ab omni parte donec eradices corruptionem totam, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid penitus.	Then cauterize it from every part until you eradicate the whole corruption, and let nothing of it remain at all.
Deinde dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, et pone super loca cauterizata sulphur tritum cum oleo, donec eradicentur escharae omnes, et omnis corruptio.	Then release him after three days, and place sulfur rubbed with oil on the cauterized areas until all scabs are eradicated, and all corruption is gone.
Deinde cura ipsum cum unguentis generantibus carnem.	Then care for him with ointments that generate flesh.
Si ergo uides, quod post tres dies caro nascitur natiuitate sana, in qua non est corruptio, est bonum.	If therefore you see that after three days flesh is born healthy in its birth, in which there is no corruption, it is good.
Et si non: tunc itera cauterium super illud quod remansit ex locis corruptis.	And if not: then apply cauterization again over that which remains from the places corrupted.
Et corrodens medicatur quandoque cum medicina acuta.	And it is sometimes treated with a sharp medicine when corroding.
Ipsa namque surgit loco cauterii.	For it rises in place of cauterization.
Verumtamen cauterium cum igne est uelocioris iuuamenti: et ego quidem iam dixi cauterizationem eius cum medicina acuta in diuisione: accipe ergo eam illic quando ea indiges.	Nevertheless, cautery with fire is quicker healing; and I have already said cauterization of it with sharp medicine in the division: therefore take it there when it needs it.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Clauis, et Verucis.	On the mode of cauterizing in claws and warts.
Caput LV.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit in inferioribus partibus pedum haec aegritudo: et est res grossa, filtrata, quae laedit pedem.	This pain often occurs in the lower parts of the feet; and it is a thick, purulent matter that hurts the foot.
Et cauterium quidem in eis est secundum duos modos: cauterium cum igne, et cauterium cum aqua calida.	And indeed a cautery among them is according to two modes: a cautery with fire, and a cautery with hot water.
Quantum autem cum igne est, ut ignias cauterium concauum simile pennae uulturis: quod fiat ex ferro, secundum quantitatem quod contineat clauum ab omni parte: et sit subtilium marginum.	As much as it is with fire, let the cautery be concave like a feather of an eagle; that it be made of iron, according to the quantity that it contains of nail from every part; and let it have a fine edge.
Deinde depone ipsum ignitum super clauum.	Then place the heated piece above the stake.
Deinde reuolue manum cum cauterio in circumitu claui, donec perueniat cauterium ad profunditatem claui: et dimitte ipsum tribus diebus, donec incipiat emittere pus.	Then turn the hand with a cautery around the nail until the cautery reaches the depth of the nail; and let it alone for three days until it begins to discharge pus.
Deinde emplastra ipsum cum maluis syluestribus, contritis cum sale: et dimitte emplastrum super ipsum in nocte.	Then apply a poultice of willow leaves, crushed with salt, and leave the poultice on it at night.
Ipse enim eradicabitur ex radicibus suis.	It will be removed from its roots.
Deinde cura locum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place with a generative ointment of flesh until it heals.
Quod si sunt non conuersi, et multotiens accidunt in superficie corporis, praecipue in manibus et pedibus: tunc administres in eis cauterium cum aqua calida: et est, ut accipias cannulam ex aere, aut ferro, aut ex penna uulturis: et depone eam super clauum, aut althelul.	If they are not converted, and often happen on the surface of the body, especially in the hands and feet: then administer cauterium with hot water in them: and it is, that you take a tube from copper, or iron, or from the feather of an owl: and lay it upon a nail, or awl.
Deinde proiice in cannulam ex aqua calida quantitatem paucam: retine manum tuam, et tu reuolue eam cum compressione manus tuae parumper, ut imprimatur margo cannulae in radice claui, et inueniat aqua calida uiam ad profundum, ad radicem claui: et expectet infirmus parumper super mordicationem aquae calidae hora una.	Then pour a small amount of hot water into the tube: hold your hand, and roll it with the pressure of your hand for a short time, so that the edge of the tube is impressed on the root of the nail, and the hot water finds its way deep, to the root of the nail: and let the patient wait for an hour over the mordication of the hot water.
Deinde dimitte ipsum, nam clauus eradicatur cum radicibus suis.	Then release it, for a claw is removed with its roots.
Ita fac cum eis uno post unum, donec uenias super omnes qui ex eis sunt in corpore.	Thus do with them one after another, until you come over all who are in the body from among these.
Deinde cura eos postquam eradicantur, cum eo quod generat carnem ex unguentis.	Then care for them after they are eradicated, with that which produces flesh from ointment.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in Tremore.	On the mode of cauterization in tremor.
Caput LVI.	Chapter LVI.
Quando accidit alicui Tremor ex frigore in neruo, aut ex febre quartana, aut alio: tunc oportet ut cauterizes ipsum quatuor cauteriis, aut quinque super spondiles dorsi, et inter omnem spondilem cauterio, et in pectore eius cauterio, et super stomachum eius cauterio.	When someone has a tremor from cold in the nerve, or from quartan fever, or from another cause: then it is necessary to cauterize it with four cauteries, or five over the vertebrae of the back, and between every vertebra with cauterization, and in his chest with cauterization, and over his stomach with cauterization.
Tremor enim quiescit cum cauterio oliuari, et festinat sanitas aegritudinis frigidae.	For tremor rests with a cautery of olive oil, and the health of coldness hastens.
¶ De modo cauterizandi Albathir.	On the manner of cauterizing Albathir.
Caput LVII.	Chapter LVII.
Quandoque expelluntur in corpore Albathir foedae, id est, pustulae, quae fiunt a materiis grossis corruptis.	Sometimes foul matter, that is, pustules, are expelled from the body of Albashir, which are made from corrupted thick materials.
Oportet ergo in primis cum apparent, ut cauterizentur super omne caput pustulae cauterio subtili cum ligno myrti, cuius extremitas accensa est cum igne.	Therefore, first of all, when they appear, let them be cauterized over the whole head of the pustule with a fine cauterizing iron made of myrtle wood, whose end has been set alight with fire.
Aut cum radice aristolochiae longae.	Or with the root of long asarone.
Aut cum cauterio lenticulari.	Or with a lens-shaped cautery.
Et quandoque cauterizantur ademenul, in principio expulsionis suae secundum hunc modum: et non augentur: et disrumpitur superfluitas faciens eos, et sanatur ex eis.	And sometimes the bowels are cauterized at the beginning of their expulsion in this way: and they do not increase; and the excess is broken, making them whole, and they are healed from them.
Verumtamen oportet ut fiat illud post euacuationem cum phlebotomia.	Nonetheless, it ought to be done after evacuation with bloodletting.
¶ De modo cauterizandi in fluxu sanguins ex arteria in uulnere.	On the manner of cauterization in the flow of blood from an artery in a wound.
Caput LVIII.	Chapter LVIII.
Multotiens accidit fluxus sanguinis ex arteria, quae incisa est apud uulnus, quod accidit extrinsecus, aut apud incisionem apostematis, aut cauterium membri, et similia eis: et fit difficile abscindere eum.	Often blood flow occurs from an artery that has been cut at a wound, which happens externally or at the incision of a boil, or cauterization of a limb, and similar to these: and it becomes difficult to stop it.
