Plaerumque enim addit in apostemate: et non oportet ut facias illud nisi apud declinationem apostematis eius calidi.	Usually he adds this to a boil, and you should not do it unless the decline of the boil is hot.
Si autem non est praesens tibi hoc instrumentum, tunc accipe cannam, et compone in extremitate eius corticem oui: ut non comburatur os infirmi: quoniam cortex oui prohibet uaporem comburere os: et haec est ex bona curatione cum salute.	If this instrument is not present to you, then take a tube and place cork at its end so that the bone of the infirm does not burn; because cork prevents steam from burning the bone; and this is from good care with health.
¶ De extractione spinarum, et ossium de gula.	On the extraction of thorns, and bones from the throat.
Caput XXXVIII.	Chapter XXXVIII.
Multotiens adhaeret in gutture os, aut spina piscis, aut aliud.	Many times a fish bone or other thing adheres in the throat.
Oportet ergo ut extrahas quod ex eis est apparens super quod cadit uisus, postquam premis linguam cum instrumento apud solem, et declaratur tibi quod est in gutture.	Therefore it is necessary that you remove what appears from them which falls upon the sight, after you have pressed the tongue with an instrument at the sun, and it has been made clear to you what is in the throat.
Et quod non apparet tibi et occultatur in gutture, oportet ut facias uomere infirmum antequam digeratur cibus in stomacho.	And if it does not appear to you and is hidden in the throat, it is necessary for you to make a vomiting before food is digested in the stomach.
Fortasse enim egredietur res annexa per uomitum.	Perhaps, indeed, the thing attached will come out through vomiting.
Aut deglutiat infirmus frustum napi, aut radicem lactucae, aut deglutiat buccellam panis sicci: aut accipiat frustum spongiae marinae siccae lenis: et liga ipsum in filo, deinde deglutiat ipsum.	Or let the sick person swallow a piece of barley, or lettuce root, or a mouthful of dry bread; or take a piece of dried sea sponge, gentle, and bind it with thread, then swallow it.
Cum ergo peruenit ad locum ubi sunt spinae, aut os, et extrahitur, tunc egreditur.	When therefore it comes to the place where the spines, or bones are, and is extracted, then it exits.
Si ergo non egreditur cum eo quod diximus: tunc utere instrumento ex plumbo secundum hanc formam.	If therefore it does not exit with what we have said, then use an instrument of lead according to this form.
Sit grossius quam Radius parumper, et in extremitate eius sit curuitas, quam intromittat in guttur suum cum facilitate: et ipse habeat caput suum eleuatum sursum.	Let it be thicker than the radius a little, and at its end let there be a curvature, so that it may enter its throat with ease; and let it itself have its head elevated upwards.
Et caueat a tactu suae epiglotis, ut non accidat ei tussis, et impellat cum eo os, aut spinam, aut intromittat ipsum medicus manu sua.	And let him beware of touching his epiglottis, lest he have a cough, and drive it in with his mouth or spine, or insert it himself with his hand.
Verum quod infirmus intromittat, hoc est melius: propter scientiam suam de loco rei annexae: et impellat inferius, aut trahat manum suam cum instrumento sursum, totum illud secundum quantitatem quae praeparatur ei, donec egrediatur.	It is indeed better if the infirm person inserts it; because of his knowledge of the place of the annexed thing: and he pushes down below, or pulls his hand with the instrument upwards, the whole of it according to the quantity that is prepared for him, until it emerges.
¶ De extractione Sanguisugae.	On the removal of leeches.
Caput XXXIX.	Chapter XXXIX.
Quando medicatur sanguisuga cum eo quod dixi in diuisione ex curatione cum medicinis, et non confert, tunc considera in gutture infirmi coram sole, siue apud solem postquam premis linguam eius cum instrumento quod narraui tibi.	When a leech is applied with what I said in the division on healing with medicines, and it does not help, then consider in the throat of the sick person in front of the sun, or in the sun after you have pressed their tongue with the instrument that I told you about.
Si ergo cadit uisus tuus super sanguisugam, extrahe eam cum uncino paruo, aut cum gesti subtilibus decenter.	If therefore your sight falls upon a leech, extract it with a small hook, or with fine tweezers.
Quod si non est possibile cum eis: tunc accipe cannulam concauam, et intromitte eam in guttur infirmi usque prope guttur: deinde intromitte in concauitatem cannulae ferrum ignitum cum igne.	If it is not possible with these things: then take a concave tube and insert it into the throat of the sick person up to near the throat; then insert into the concavity of the tube iron heated with fire.
Fac illud multotiens: et abstineat infirmus ab aqua tota die.	Do this many times: and let the sick person abstain from water all day.
Deinde accipiat uitreatam plenam aqua frigida, et aperiat os eius in ea: et colluat os suum cum ea, et non deglutiat ex ea aliquid: et moueat aquam una hora post aliam cum manu sua.	Then let him take a full mouthful of cold water and open his mouth in it; and let him fill his mouth with it, and not swallow any of it; and move the water every hour with his hand.
Sanguisuga enim ilico cum sentit aquam cadit.	For the leech, when it feels water, immediately falls down.
Si autem non egreditur cum eo quod narrauimus, tunc suffumiga infirmum cum cimicibus, aut cum asa cum instrumento quod narraui in suffumigatione uuulae.	If it does not come out as we have narrated, then smoke the sick person with lice, or with asa and the instrument I have narrated in the fumigation of the vulva.
Fac illud multotiens, quoniam ipsa cadet.	Do this many times, for it will fall of itself.
Et modus operationis in suffumigatione est, ut accipias ollam, in qua sint prunae uiuae cum igne: et olla sit cooperta cum coopertorio, in cuius medio sit foramen: et componatur in illo foramine extremitas instrumenti.	And the method of operation in fumigation is that you take a pot in which are live plums with fire: and let the pot be covered with a cover, in the middle of which there is a hole: and let the end of the instrument be placed in that hole.
Deinde proiice suffumigationem, et ponat infirmus os suum in extremitate cannulae, et claudat os suum, ut non egrediatur suffumigatio, donec scias quod suffumigatio iam peruenit ad sanguisugam.	Then throw the fumigation, and let the sick person put their mouth at the end of the tube, and close their mouth so that the fumigation does not escape until you know that the fumigation has already reached the bloodletting area.
Nam sanguisuga statim cadet.	For the leech will immediately fall off.
Quod si non cadit, tunc itera suffumigationem multotiens.	If it does not fall, then repeat fumigation many times.
Et toleret infirmus sitim, et comedat salsa, et allia, et non bibat aquam.	And let the weak one bear thirst, and eat salted foods, and others, and not drink water.
Necesse est ergo ut egrediatur cum hoc regimine.	Therefore it is necessary that he depart with this regimen.
Et haec est forma instrumenti cum quo extrahitur sanguisuga ex gutture, quando cadit super ipsam uisus.	And this is the form of the instrument with which bloodsucker is extracted from the throat when it falls upon itself by sight.
Est simile forcipibus, sicut uides: nisi quia est ei haee curuitas quae intromittitur ad guttur.	It is similar to forceps, as you see: except that it has this curvature which goes into the throat.
Et extremitas eius similis ori auis quae nominatur ciconia, in quo est asperitas limae: quando comprehendit aliquid, non dimittit ipsum omnino.	And its extremity is like the beak of a stork, which has the roughness of a file: when it grasps something, it does not let go of it at all.
¶ De apertione Apostematum, et eorum sectione, et cura in genere.	On the incision of abscesses and their cutting, and care in general.
Caput XL.	Chapter XL.
Apostematum species sunt multae, multorum modorum, secundum quod uenit rememoratio eorum, scilicet unius, et unius in hoc libro: et sunt diuersae in perforatione eorum, et sectione ipsorum ex duobus modis.	There are many kinds of boils, and many ways, according to how they are remembered, namely one, and one in this book: and they are different in their piercing, and cutting them in two ways.
Quorum unus est ex specie apostematis in seipso, et eo quod comprehendit ex humiditatibus.	One of these is a kind of abscess within itself, and that which it contains from humidities.
Et modus secundus est propter loca, in quibus accidit ex corpore.	And the second method is because of the places where it happens from the body.
Quoniam apostema accidens in capite, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in ano: et apostema accidens in loco carnoso, est aliud ab apostemate accidente in iuncturis: et unicuique eorum est iudicium suum ex operatione.	Because a boil occurring in the head is different from a boil occurring in the anus: and a boil occurring in a fleshy place is different from a boil occurring in the joints: and to each of these their own judgment by operation.
Et ex apostematibus sunt quae non oportet ut perforentur, nisi post maturationem saniei in eis, et complementum eius: et ex eis sunt, quae oportet ut perforentur, dum sunt cruda, et non maturantur secundum complementum.	And from boils there are some which ought not to be pierced unless after the ripening of the healing in them, and its completion: and from these there are some which ought to be pierced while they are raw, and do not ripen according to the completion.
Sicut apostemata quae sunt propinqua iuncturis.	As abscesses that are near the joints.
Quoniam apostema quando accidit prope iuncturam, et prolongatur esse eius, donec putrefit quod est in circumitu eius fortasse corrumpuntur ligamenta, aut nerui illius iuncturae: quare est caussa propior contractionis illius membri.	Because an abscess when it happens near a joint and it is prolonged until it rots what is around it, perhaps the ligaments or nerves of that joint will be corrupted: therefore it is the proximate cause of contraction of that limb.
Aut est apostema apud membrum principale: quoniam si tu tardas perforationem eius, donec maturetur, nocebit uel illi, uel per illud membro principali.	Or it is an abscess at a main limb: for if you delay its piercing until it ripens, it will harm either him or through that main limb.
Aut est prope anum, perfora ergo ipsum immaturum: et non oportet, ut perfores, apostema crudum, non completae digestionis, nisi quod est prope anum, ut non putrefiat profundum, et longetur ad interiora ani, et fiat fistula, aut fiat in termino eius quod non sanatur.	If it is near the anus, pierce it when immature: and it should not be pierced if it is a raw abscess, not yet fully digested, except if it is near the anus so that it does not rot deeply and extend to the interior of the anus, and become a fistula, or form at its end that which does not heal.
Oportet ut scias horam perforationis apostematis, quod maturatum est secundum complementum: et est apud sedationem doloris, recessionem febris, et diminutionem rubedinis, et pulsationis, et acuitatem capitis apostematis: et reliqua signa.	You ought to know the hour of perforation of a boil that has matured according to its completion: and it is in the sedation of pain, recession of fever, and diminution of redness, and pulse, and sharpness of the head of the boil: and the rest of the signs.
Et oportet, ut facias eandem perforationem in inferiori loco apostematis, et uehementioris eminentiae: et sit perforatio uadens in longitudine corporis, si apostemata sunt in partibus manuum et pedum, et locis lacertorum, et chordarum, et neruorum, et arteriarum, et ad ultimum in omnibus locis aequalibus, quibus non est reflexio.	And it is necessary that you make the same perforation in the lower place of the abscess and the more prominent eminence: and let the perforation be sharp in the length of the body, if the abscesses are in the parts of the hands and feet, and places of the lacerations, and cords, and nerves, and arteries, and ultimately in all equal places, where there is no reflection.
In illis autem quae reflectuntur, uade cum perforatione secundum illud membrum.	In those which are reflected, go with a piercing according to that limb.
Quando uero apostema est in locis carnosis: tunc melius est ut dimittas perforationem eius, donec confirmetur eius digestio, sicut diximus secundum complementum.	When a boil is in fleshy places: then it is better to let the opening of it discharge, until its digestion has been confirmed, as we have said according to the completion.
Quoniam si tu perforas ipsum ante illud, prolongatur cursus uirus ex eo, et est multae sordis et sordiciei, et fortasse indurantur labia eius, et profunditas eius.	For if you pierce it before that point, the course of the virus is prolonged from it, and there is much dirt and filth, and perhaps the lips of it will endure, and its depth.
Et quaedam apostemata perforantur secundum latitudinem corporis apud necessitatem: aut secundum illud quo indiget membrum.	And certain abscesses are pierced according to the width of the body, as necessity demands; or according to what limb needs it.
Et oportet, ut administres in apostematibus paruis perforationem paruam, et in apostematibus magnis perforationem amplam: aut sectiones multas per similitudinem magnitudinis apostematis.	And it is necessary that you administer in small abscesses a small perforation, and in large abscesses a wide perforation; or many incisions according to the likeness of the magnitude of the abscess.
Et sunt ex apostematibus, in quibus oportet ut concauetur cutis: et incidatur quando iam facta est sicut pannus, et facta est in termino, quod iam mortua est: sicut illud quod accidit in multis, ut dubelet, et bubonibus.	And there are abscesses, in which it is necessary that the skin be scooped out; and it should be cut when it has become like a cloth, and has come to an end, that is, when it has died: such as happens in many cases, so that it may burst, and buboes.
Et ex eis sunt quae secantur sectione habente tres angulos.	And among these are those which are cut with a three-angled incision.
Et ex eis est, ex quo inciditur sicut figura folii myrti.	And of these is one which occurs like the figure of a myrtle leaf.
Sicut apostema inguinum.	Like an abscess in the groin.
Et ex eis sunt in quibus administratur sectio rotunda, et sectio lunaris: et similes eis ex sectionibus.	And of these there are those in which a round incision and a lunar incision are administered, and similar incisions to these.
Illud uero cui non est caput, sicut sunt apostemata lenia superficialia, oportet ut perfores ipsum perforatione superficiali, uel plana tantum.	As for those who lack a head, as in superficial, soft boils, it is necessary to pierce them with a superficial or only flat perforation.
Et oportet, quando apostema est grossum, et iam collegit saniem multam, et perforas ipsum, ut non properes et extrahas pus totum in illa hora: imo extrahe ex ipso partem eius.	And it is necessary when the abscess is large and has already gathered much pus, that you pierce it, so that you do not hurry and extract all the pus in that hour; rather, extract part of it.
Deinde opila apostema usque ad diem alium.	Then let it be treated with poultices and an abscess until another day.
Deinde extrahe quiddam ex pus iterum.	Then remove something from the pus again.
Fac illud multotiens secundum gradationem, donec egrediatur: praecipue si infirmus est debilis uirtutis, aut mulier praegnans, aut puer paruus, aur senex decrepitus: spiritus enim animalis ab animali multotiens resoluitur cum egressione saniei: et fortasse moritur infirmus, et tu non percipis.	Do this many times according to gradation, until it comes out: especially if the patient is weak in virtue, or a pregnant woman, or a small boy, or an old decrepit man: for the animal spirit is much resolved from the animal with the expulsion of phlegm: and perhaps the patient dies, and you do not perceive.
Caue ergo hoc capitulum cautela magna.	Therefore, take great care with this chapter.
Et post perforationem tuam, qua ista perforas apostemata, oportet ut abstergas uulnus: et considera.	And after you have perforated it, through which you pierce the abscesses, it is necessary that you cleanse the wound; and consider.
Si ergo est uulnus apostematis paruum, aut est sectio plana, tunc administra licinia ex lino, aut coto antiquo.	If therefore is a wound of small abscess, or is a flat section, then administer lint from linen, or old cotment.
Et si est apostema magnum, et fissurae perforationis multae sunt, oportet tunc ut intromittas in omnem fissuram licinium, donec perueniant adinuicem.	And if it is a large abscess, and there are many fissures of the opening, then you must introduce into every fissure a liniment until they reach each other.
Et si in apostemate abscidisti partem cutis, aut in circumitu concauasti eam: tunc oportet ut impleas eam coto ueteri, aut sicut quando texitur pannus, aut raditur lanugine lini absque humiditate: et stringe ipsum usque ad tertium diem.	And if in an abscess you have cut away a part of the skin, or hollowed it out on its edge: then it is necessary that you fill it with old dung, or as when a cloth is used to cover it, or wool is applied without moisture; and bind it up until the third day.
Deinde proiice ipsum, et cura illud cum eo quod oportet ex unguento, donec sanetur.	Then throw it away, and take care of it with what is necessary ointment, until it heals.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis in hora tuae operationis, tunc administra aquam frigidam, et acetum, postquam imbibitur in eis pannus: et ponis ipsum super locum fluxus sanguinis multotiens.	If it happens that there is bleeding during your operation, then administer cold water and vinegar after a cloth has been soaked in them: and place it over the place of bleeding many times.
Si autem perseuerat fluxus sanguinis, tunc oportet ut administres regimen, et curationem, et pulueres, quae narraui in locis multis huius nostri libri, et ex diuisione.	If, however, bleeding persisted, then it is necessary that you administer a regimen and treatment and powders, which I have recounted in many places in this book of ours, and from the division.
Si autem est in tempore hyemis, et locus apostematis est multorum neruorum: tunc oportet ut infundas puluillos cum uino, et oleo calidis: et ponas eos super loca.	If it is in wintertime, and the place of the abscess is of many nerves, then it is necessary that you pour poultices with wine and hot oil, and place them over the places.
Et si fuerit in aestate, et loca sunt carnosa: tunc oportet ut ponas puluillos imbibitos in aqua, et oleo, aut eum uino et oleo, et totum illud frigidum.	And if it is in summer and the places are fleshy: then you ought to put little sponges soaked in water, and oil, or him with wine and oil, and the whole thing cold.
Donec quando erit dies tertius, sicut diximus, tunc oportet ut soluas apostema, et abstergas ipsum, et administres in curatione eius quod ei conuenit, donec sanetur.	Until the third day, as we have said, then it is necessary that you should loosen the abscess and cleanse it, and administer to its cure what is fitting for it, until it is healed.
Hoc est ergo quod necessarium est ex cognitione curationis apostematum uniuersaliter.	This therefore is what is necessary from the knowledge of healing boils universally.
Secundum semitam uero distinctionis, iam dixi de omni apostemate, qualiter est uia ad curationem eius capitulatim singulariter.	According to the method of distinction, I have already said about every kind of abscess, how the way to its cure is taken individually chapter by chapter.
¶ De sectione apostematum quae accidunt in cute capitis.	On the incision of boils that occur in the skin of the head.
Caput XLI.	Chapter XLIX.
Accidunt in cute capitis apostemata parua, et sunt ex speciebus Nodorum, quos continent tunicae, quae sunt eis sacci: quasi ipsa sint hausolati gallinae.	Small boils occur in the scalp skin and are of the kind of nodules, which contain sacks, like small bags of chicken's blood.
Et ipsorum species sunt multae.	And their kinds are many.
Ex eis sunt pingues: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditatem similem limo: et ex eis quae continent humiditatem similem frisatis et pultibus: et eis similibus, et ex eis sunt, quae sunt lapidea dura.	Of these there are fatty ones; and there are those which contain moisture like slime; and those which contain moisture like gruel and porridge; and the like; and there are also those which are hard and stony.
Et in sectione omnium, et ipsorum extractione non est timor, dum apud ipsorum sectionem non facit contrarietatem arteria.	And in the sectioning of all and their extraction there is no fear, as long as it does not oppose the artery during the sectioning of them.
Et operatio in sectione eorum est, ut experiaris ea cum instrumento, cuius forma uenit post haec, quod nominatur Intromissum, donec scias quid contineat.	And the operation on their section is that you should experience it with an instrument, whose form comes after this, which is called Intromissum, until you know what it contains.
Nam si est illud quod continet humiditas, tunc seca ipsum sectione secundum longitudinem sectione superficiali: secundum hanc formam.	If it is that which contains moisture, then dry it with a cut along its length by a superficial cut: according to this form.
Et incipe cum sectione ex linea b. ad lineam, g. Cum ergo euacuatur humiditas, tunc excoria kistin quae continet illam humiditatem, et non dimittas ex ea aliquid penitus.	And begin with a cut from line b to line g. When therefore the humidity is evacuated, then scrape the cyst which contains that humidity, and do not allow anything to be taken out of it completely.
Multotiens enim redit, si remanet ex ea aliquid.	Often indeed it returns, if anything remains of it.
Deinde submerge cotum in unguento aegyptio, si est praesens: et si non, in aqua et sale: et imple cum eo uulnus, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Then immerse a wad in Egyptian ointment, if it is present: and if not, in water and salt: and fill the wound with it, and leave it until the next day.
Ipsum enim corrodet quod remansit ex kisti.	For it will corrode that which remains from the cyst.
Deinde itera super ipsum cotum cum aegyptio secundo, et tertio, et si indiges illo, donec confidas quia non remanserit ex kisti aliquid, tunc enim cura uulnus cum unguento, donec sanetur.	Then repeat the operation on the same tumor with an Egyptian second and third time, and if you do not digest it with this, until you are confident that nothing remains of the cyst, then treat the wound with ointment until it heals.
Quod si apostema continet nodum pinguem: tunc seca ipsum secundum hanc formam, sectione habente formam crucis: et proiice uncinos inter duolabia sectionis, et excoria ipsum ab omni parte: et conare uirtutem tuam in extractione tunicae quae continet ipsum.	If it contains a fatty node, then cut it according to this form, with the incision having the shape of a cross: and throw hooks between the two lips of the incision, and scrape it from every part: and try your strength in extracting the tunic that contains it.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi arteria, tunc fac illud quod narrabo tibi post.	If however the artery acts against you, then do that which I shall tell you after.
Et similiter fac in apostemate, si est lapideum, ex sectione, et curatione eadem, secundum quod diximus.	And similarly do in an abscess, if it is stony, from incision, and cure the same, according to what we have said.
Et sectio super apostema lapideum est facilior: quoniam est pauci sanguinis et humiditatis.	And the incision over a stone abscess is easier because there is little blood and moisture.
Et quandoque sunt quaedam horum apostematum quae sunt in capite in quibusdam hominibus, cum quibus penitus non est humiditas.	And sometimes there are certain of these abscesses which are in the head in some men, with which there is no moisture at all.
Quod est: quia ego secui super apostema in capite mulieris uetulae, et inueni apostema sicut lapis solidus et durus, asper, albus, qui non poterat frangi: et si percuteretur cum eo aliquis proiiciendo, uulnerat ipsum.	That is, because I cut into an abscess on the head of an old woman, and found the abscess like a solid, hard stone, rough, white, which could not be broken; and if it were struck with something by throwing it, it would wound it.
In aliis uero apostematibus accidentibus in capite, praeter haec scilicet apostemata quae accidunt in capitibus puerorum, et apud radices aurium, sectio eorum omnium sit sectio superficialis.	In other boils and accidents on the head, besides these namely those which happen on the heads of children, and at the roots of the ears, the section of all of them should be a superficial section.
Vel pone perforationem eorum semper ab inferiori parte eorum, ut alleuietur cursus saniei ad inferiora.	Or place the perforation of them always from the lower part of them, that the course of healing may be relieved downwards.
Deinde cura ea cum eo quod conuenit eis ex curatione.	Then care for him as is convenient in his cure.
¶ De sectione Strophularum in collo.	On the cutting of strangulated veins in the neck.
Caput XLII.	Chapter XLII.
Multotiens acccidunt ista apostemata in collo, et sub assellis, et inguinibus: et quandoque accidunt in reliquo corpore.	These abscesses often occur in the neck, and under the armpits, and in the groin: and sometimes they occur in the rest of the body.
Et super illa quae ex eis accidunt in collo, sunt unum, et multa: et generantur ab inuicem: et omnis Strophula ex eis est intra tunicam propriam ei, sicut est in nodis et apostematibus capitis, sicut narrauimus.	And over those which happen from them in the neck, there are one and many: and they are generated from each other: and every strophula from these is inside its own tunic, as it is in nodes and boils of the head, as we have narrated.
Et species harum Strophularum sunt multae.	And there are many kinds of these Strophulaes.
Et ex eis enim sunt lapideae: et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates: et ex eis sunt malignae, quae non obediunt curationi.	And from these there are stones; and from these there are those which contain moistures; and from these there are malignant ones, which do not obey treatment.
In illa ergo quam ex eis uides bonae dispositionis in tactu, cuius manifestum est propinquum colori cutis, et mouetur ad omnem partem, et non est annexa cum neruis colli, neque cum guidegi, neque cum arteria, neque est profunda: oportet ut seces eam sectione superficiali a superiori parte ad inferiorem partem corporis ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. et excoria eam ab omni parte: et extende duo labia cutis cum uncino, aut cum uncinis multis, si indiges illo, sicut diximus in apostematibus capitis, et extrahe eam paulatim.	In that one therefore which you see of good disposition in touch, whose manifest color is near to the skin, and it moves to every part, and is not attached with nerves of the neck, nor with the guidegi, nor with the artery, nor is it deep: it is necessary to cut it by a superficial section from the upper part to the lower part of the body along the line, b. to the line, g., and to scrape it from every part: and extend the two lips of the skin with a hook, or with many hooks if you need it, as we said in abscesses of the head, and extract it gradually.
Et est super cautelam, ut non incidatur uena, aut neruus.	And it is a matter of great care that one not wound a vein, or nerve.
Et sit spatumile non acutum ualde: ut non addat tibi manum tuam cum incisione, aut inquietet infirmum, et incidas quod non est necesse.	And let the spatula be not too sharp: so that it does not add your hand with the incision, or trouble the sick person, and you cut what is not necessary.
Si autem incidis uenam, aut arteriam, aut prohibet te ab operatione, tunc pone in uulnus zegi tritum, aut quosdam pulueres qui abscindunt sanguinem, et stringe uulnus, et dimitte ipsum, donec quiescat acuitas apostematis, et mollificetur uulnus: uel incipit et uult putrefieri.	If, however, you cut a vein, or artery, or something prevents you from operating, then place in the wound ground zegi, or some powders that stop blood, and bind the wound, and leave it until the sharpness of the abscess has subsided, and the wound has softened: or it begins and wants to rot.
Nam sanguis abscinditur tuncia Redi ergo ad operationem tuam, donec compleas.	For blood is cut off, tunic. So go back to your operation until you have finished it.
Deinde inquire digito tuo indice, si remansit aliquid ex Strophulis aliis paruis: ergo incide eas, et munda eas.	Then probe with your index finger if anything of the other small strophuli remains; therefore cut them and cleanse them.
Quod si est in radice Strophulae uena magna: tunc oportet ut non incidas illam Strophulam ex radice sua: imo oportet ut liges eam cum filo duplato forti, et dimittas eam donec cadat per se absque nocumento.	If a large vein is in the root of the strophula: then it is necessary that you do not cut that strophula from its root: rather it is necessary that you tie it with a doubled strong thread, and let it go until it falls by itself without harm.
Deinde imple uulnus coto ueteri, quod iam submersisti in unguento aegyptio.	Then fill the wound of the belly, which you have already submerged in Egyptian ointment.
Deinde cura ipsum.	Then care for it itself.
Si inciditur Strophula tota, tunc oportet ut aggreges labia duo uulneris: et suas ipsum statim, postquam uides quia prorsus non remansit superfluitas.	If the strophulus is cut entirely, then it is necessary to bring together the two lips of the wound: and its own, immediately after you see that there remains not at all superfluous matter.
Si autem uides quod remansit superfluitas propter magnitudinem Strophulae, tunc oportet ut intendas ad incidendam radicem eius, et extrahendam eam: et administra suturam quam diximus.	If you see that there is excess remaining because of the size of the Stropha, then it is necessary to extend it to cut its root and remove it, and administer the suture which we have said.
Et quae ex Strophulis continet humiditates, perfora illam perforatione superficiali: ut appareat tibi locus maturitatis eius: et pone perforationem ab eo quod sequitur inferius corporis, sicut diximus.	And that which contains moisture from the strophulus, pierce it with a superficial perforation, so that the place of its maturity may appear to you; and place the perforation below that which follows in the lower part of the body, as we have said.
Deinde administra post perforationem licinia cum unguento, et similia eis, ut corrodat quod remansit ex corruptione, donec quando uides uulnus iam mundatum esse: tunc cura ipsum cum unguento generatiuo carnis, donec sanetur.	Then after perforation administer a plaster with ointment, and similar things, so that it corrodes what remains from corruption until when you see the wound already clean: then care for it with an ointment of flesh generation, until it heals.
¶ De sectione Epiglotis ab apostemate intra guttur accidente.	On the incision of the epiglottis from an abscess in the throat.
Caput XLIII.	Chapter XLIII.
Dixerunt antiqui hanc sectionem in Epigloti, et non uidi aliquem in terra nostra, qui eam fecerit: et haec est scriptura sermonis eorum.	The ancients said this incision is in the epiglottis, and I did not see anyone in our land who has done it: and this is the writing of their words.
In habentibus autem synanchiam, oportet ut deuitetur sectio Epiglotis: cum non fiat iuuamentum per illud: propterea, quod omnes uenae et pulmo sunt infirmi.	In those having a synanchia, it is necessary that the section of the Epiglottis be made; when this is not helpful, because all veins and lung are weak.
In illis uero qui habent apostema calidum in ore, aut gutture, aut duabus amigdalis, quando non est aegritudo in cannali, oportet uti sectione Epiglotis, ad fugiendum ex perditione quae fit ex praefocatione.	In those who have a hot abscess in the mouth, or throat, or both tonsils, when there is no pain in the canal, it is necessary to use the section of the Epiglottis, to avoid destruction that occurs from pre-inflammation.
Oportet ergo quando uolumus illud, ut secemus Epiglotim sub tribus circulis Epiglotis, aut quatuor, sectione parua per latitudinem, in eo quod est inter duos circulos per quantitatem, quod sit sectio in sifac, non in cartilagine: et iste quidem locus est conueniens sectioni, quoniam est priuatus carne, et uasa sanguinis ab eo sunt longinqua.	Therefore, when we wish to cut the epiglottis, it should be done under three or four circles of the epiglottis with a small incision across its width, in that which is between two circles, so that the section be in the soft tissue and not in the cartilage; and this place is convenient for cutting because it is devoid of flesh, and the blood vessels are distant from it.
Quod si medicator est timidus, tunc oportet ut extendat cutem gutturis cum uncino.	If a surgeon is fearful, then it is necessary that he extend the skin of the throat with a hook.
Deinde findat cutem, donec quando peruenit ad cannalem: deuitet uas sanguinis, si uidet ex eis aliquid.	Then he must lay open the skin until he reaches the vessel; if he sees anything coming from them, let him remove it.
Deinde secet sifac quod narrauimus: et significatur super sectionem cannalis ex phlegmate quod egreditur ex ea, cum eo quod disrumpitur, et abscisione uocis.	Then he cuts the incision as we have narrated; and it signifies on the cutting of the canal from the pus that comes out of it, with what is broken apart, and the severance of the voice.
Et dimitte uulnus apertum tempore aliquo.	And leave an open wound for some time.
Cum ergo remouetur hora in qua timetur praefocatio, aggrega duo labia uulneris cutis, et sue ipsam solam absque cartilagine.	When therefore it is removed at the hour when fear of inflammation, bring together the two lips of the wound of skin, and suture itself alone without cartilage.
Deinde administra medicinas quae faciunt nasci carnem, usquequo sanetur.	Then administer medicines that make flesh grow, until it is healed.
Inquit Albucasis.	Says Albucasis.
Summa huius sermonis quem narrauimus, expositio non est, nisi quando uident, quod aliquod horum apostematum iam opilauit guttur infirmi: et sublimatus est infirmus super mortem, et uult intersecari anhelitus eius: uadunt ad secandum Epiglotim, ut respiret infirmus super locum uulneris quadam respiratione, et saluetur a morte: et propter hoc praeceperunt dimittere uulnus apertum, donec consumatur malicia aegritudinis, et est malicia eius tribus diebus, et quasi ipsa: tunc ergo praecaeperunt suere uulnus, et curare ipsum, donec sanetur.	The summary of what we have narrated, is not an exposition, unless when they see that some of these abscesses have already opened the throat of the sick person; and the sick person has been raised above death, and wants to be cut open so that he breathes, and is saved from death; therefore they go to cut the Epiglottis, so that the sick person may breathe over the place of the wound with some respiration, and be saved from death; and for this reason they ordered to leave the wound open until the evil of the illness has been consumed, and it is three days in nature, then they ordered to sew up the wound, and take care of it until it heals.
Et illud quod uidi per me ipsum est, quod una ancilla accaepit cultellum, et misit cum in guttur suum, et incidit cum eo partem cannalis pulmonis.	And that which I saw with my own eyes was that one maidservant took a knife and sent it into her throat, and it struck the part of the windpipe.
Et uocatus sum ad curationem eius, et inueni eam mugire, sicut est mugitus mortui.	And I was called to care for him, and I found him mooing, as is the mooing of the dead.
Detexi ergo a uulnere, et inueni sanguinem qui egressus fuerat ex uulnere paruum.	I discovered therefore from the wound, and I found blood which had gone out of the wound small.
Confisus ergo sum, quod ipsa non absciderat uenam, neque guidegi: et uentus egrediebatur ex uulnere.	Therefore, I am confused that she did not cut off the vein or artery, and wind was coming out of the wound.
Properaui ergo, et sui uulnus, et curaui ipsum, donec sanum est: et non accidit ancillae aliquid, nisi raucedo in uoce: et rediit post dies ad meliorem dispositionum suarum.	I therefore attended to his wound and cared for it until it was healed; and nothing happened to the handmaid except a hoarseness of voice; and after days she returned to better disposition of her affairs.
Hinc ergo dico: quod in sectione Epiglotis non est timor.	Therefore, I say: that in the cutting of the epiglottis there is no fear.
¶ De sectione Herniae gutturis.	On the incision of an inguinal hernia.
Caput XLIIII.	Chapter XLIV.
Hoc Apostema nominatum Hernia gutturis, est apostema magnum, secundum colorem corporis: et est in mulieribus multum.	This abscess called Hernia gutturis is a large abscess, according to the color of the body: and it is much in women.
Et est secundum duos modos: aut enim est naturale: aut est accidentale.	And it is according to two modes: either it is natural; or it is accidental.
In naturali certe non est ingenium.	Certainly it is not natural talent.
Accidentale uero est secundum duos modos: quorum unus est similis nodis pinguibus.	An accident is according to two modes: one of which is similar to fatty knots.
Et modus alter, est similis apostemati quod fit ex nodatione arteriae.	And another way is similar to an abscess that arises from the tying of an artery.
Et in ipso est timor, et non oportet ut praesumptio fiat ad ipsum cum ferro, nisi in eo quod est paruum: et tu proba ipsum, et inuestiga ipsum cum Intromisso.	And in itself there is fear, and it ought not to be presumed against it with a sword unless in that which is small; and you try it, and investigate it with an introduction.
Si ergo inuenis ipsum simile nodo pingui, et non est suspensum cum aliqua uenarum: tunc seca ipsum, sicut secantur nodi: et extrahe ipsum cum eo quod continet ex kisti, si est in kisti: et si non, tunc perscrutare totum eius.	If therefore you find a similar lump to the one described, and it is not suspended with any veins: then cut it, just as knots are cut; and extract it along with what it contains from the cyst, if it is in a cyst: and if not, then examine the whole of it.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod oportet ex curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for the place as is necessary until it heals.
¶ De sectione super species Nodorum.	On cutting above the species of Nodes.
Caput XLV.	Chapter XLV.
Nodorum multae sunt species, et ego iam dixi omnes species eorum in diuisione: et oportet ut narrem hic differentiam inter Nodum, et Exituram: cum sit dubitationem faciens.	There are many kinds of nodes, and I have already said all their kinds in the division: and it is necessary that I tell here the difference between a Node, and an Fistula: when there is doubt-making.
Dico ergo, quod cum Exitura est caliditas, et febris, et dolores uehementes, donec sedatur ebullitio superfluitatis, et completur putrefactio: tunc enim quiescunt febris et calor.	Therefore I say, that when the heat, fever, and violent pains have subsided until the boiling of superfluity is calmed and putrefaction is complete: then indeed the fever and heat will cease.
Cum Nodo uero non est caliditas, neque febris, neque dolores, et continet eos kistis sifachin, qui est eis saccus proprius, et est secundum colorem corporis: et est incaeptio eorum sicut cicer, et fit sicut batecha, et maior et minor.	When a node is not hot, nor feverish, nor painful, and it contains them with its own bag called sifachin, which is according to the color of the body: and its beginning is like a chickpea, and it becomes like a lentil, and larger and smaller.
Et sunt secundum duas species: aut pingues: aut continent humiditatem.	And they are according to two kinds: either fatty or containing moisture.
Et colores humiditatis sunt multi, secundum quod dixi in diuisione.	And the colors of humidity are many, according to what I said in the division.
Oportet ergo, quando peruenis ad curationem Nodi, ut experiaris eum, et inquiras ipsum in primis cum instrumento quod nominatur Intromissum, secundum quod ueniet forma eius in capitulo quod est post hoc.	Therefore, when you come to the treatment of a Node, it is necessary that you examine it and inquire about it first with an instrument called Intromissum, according to what its form will be in the chapter which follows after this.
Et modus inquisitionis apostematum, et Nodorum omnium est, ut accipias hoc instrumentum, et intromittas ipsum in humidiorem locum, quem inuenis in apostemate: et tu reuolue digitos tuos cum eo paulatim, donec scias quod instrumentum iam penetrauit cutem.	And the way to inquire about abscesses and all nodes is, that you take this instrument and insert it into the more humid place which you find in the abscess: and you revolve your fingers with it gradually until you know that the instrument has already pierced the skin.
Deinde ultima manum tuam secundum mensuram magnitudinis apostematis.	Then your last hand according to the measure of the size of the abscess.
Deinde extrahe Intromissum, et considera illud quod egrediur in uestigio eius.	Then draw out what was inserted, and consider that which comes out in its track.
Si ergo egreditur humiditas currens, quicunque color sit: tunc seca ipsum sectione superficiali, secundum quod dixi in reliquis apostematibus.	If therefore a running wetness emerges, whatever color it may be: then dry it with a superficial incision, according to what I said in the rest of abscesses.
Et si non egreditur humiditas in uestigio Intromissi, tunc scias quia est pinguis: seca ergo super ipsum sectione habente formam crucis, secundum formam hanc, sicut docui te: et suspende ipsum cum uncinis, et excoria cutem ab omni parte cum facilitate: et custodi kistin si potes super illud, ut extrahas ipsam sanam cum Nodo.	And if the moisture does not exit in the path of introduction, then know that it is fat: therefore make a dry incision over it having the form of a cross, according to this form, as I have taught you; and suspend it with hooks, and scrape the skin from every part with ease; and guard the cyst if you can over it, so that you may extract it sound with the node.
Si autem disrumpitur kistis apud operationem, et non est possibile extrahere ipsam sanam, multotiens enim accidit illud, tunc extrahe ipsam frustatim, donec non remaneat ex ea aliquid.	If however the bladder bursts during the operation, and it is not possible to remove it whole, since this often happens, then remove it in pieces until nothing remains of it.
Nam si remanet ex ea aliquid parum, aut multum, redit Nodus secundum plurimum.	For if anything is left from it, a little or much, a Knot will return according to the greatest amount.
Quod si uincit te, et remanet ex eo parum: tunc imple uulnus apud completionem tuam, quibusdam pulueribus corrosiuis acutis: et stringe uulnus, et pone supra ipsum quod sedet apostema calidum, et cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	If it overcomes you and there remains a little of it, then fill the wound at your completion with some corrosive powders, and tighten the wound, and place above it that which sits hot abscess, and care for it with the rest of the cure, until it heals.
Si ergo est Nodus magnus, tunc sue duo labia eius, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat.	If therefore a knot is large, then suture its two lips, and care for it with that which is conjoined.
Si autem est tibi contraria uena pulsatilis, aut non pulsatilis: tunc propera, et imple locum zegi trito, et dimitte ipsum strictum duobus diebus, aut tribus, donec putrefiat uulnus, et quiescat ebullitio sanguinis: deinde redi ad incidendum illud quod remansit ex Nodo.	If however the pulsating vein or non-pulsating vein is against you: then hasten, and fill the place with triturated zege and let it be loose for two or three days until the wound putrefies and the boiling of blood subsides: then return to cutting what remains from the Node.
¶ De foris instrumentorum pro sectione et perforatione.	Concerning instruments for cutting and piercing the mouth.
Caput XLVI.	Chapter XLVI.
EX Eis sunt formae Intromissorum, et sunt trium specierum.	There are forms of instruments introduced, and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et ex eis est medium, et ex eis est paruum.	From these there is a great one, and from these there is a medium one, and from these there is a small one.
Fiant ex ferro alfulud quadratarum extremitatum decenter, ut festinent introitum in apostemate.	Let there be made from iron lancets of the squares' extremities centered, that they may hasten the entrance into the abscess.
Et istae sunt formae Experientium, et no, id est, perforantia: et unum eorum nominatur beris, idest, peforans: et sunt trium specierum.	And these are the forms of Experiences, and no, that is to say, piercing: and one of them is named beris, that is, piercing: and they are of three kinds.
Ex eis enim est magnum, et medium, et paruum.	Of these there is a great, and a middle, and a small one.
Conueniunt, ut inuestigentur per ea apostemata, et exiturae, et fistulae, et bubones ab eo quod inter ea est ex ossibus.	It is necessary that these abscesses, and discharges, and fistula, and swellings be investigated from what exists between them from the bones.
Et aliis fiunt rotunda, tersa, lenia, sicut acus magnae quibus subsellia suuntur, ex citrino scilicet, aut ex aere, aut ferro, aut argento.	And others are made round, smooth, and soft, like large needles which they insert under the skin, out of yellow metal, or copper, or iron, or silver.
Et meliora eorum sunt quae fiunt ex citrino.	And better ones are made from citron.
Et fiunt Experientia etiam de plumbo nigro, quae conueniunt ut per ea experiantur fistulae, quarum concauitate sunt reflexiones, ut reflectantur cum lenitate sua cum illis reflexionibus.	Experience is also made with black lead, which is useful to try out fistula tubes, whose concavity reflects back so that they are reflected gently with those reflections.
Et sunt iterum trium specierum.	And they are again of three kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt longa, ex eis media, et ex eis breuia, secundum quantitatem amplitudinis fistulae et stricturae eius.	Because some are long, some medium, and some short, according to the quantity of width of the fistula and its constriction.
Forma Vncinorum, et sunt multarum specierum.	The form of hooks, and there are many kinds.
Quoniam ex eis sunt simplices, scilicet quibus est curuitas una: et sunt trium specierum sicut uides, Magni, Medii, et Parui.	Because they are simple ones, that is, those with one care: and they are of three kinds as you see, Great, Medium, and Small.
Et ex eis sunt Vncini caeci: et sunt trium specierum.	And of these there are blind pouches: and they are of three kinds.
Et ex eis sunt uncini habentes duas curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et ex eis sunt uncini habentes tres curuaturas, et sunt trium specierum: et omnes isti sunt necessarii in loco suo.	And of these there are hooks having two curves, and they are of three kinds: and of these there are hooks having three curves, and they are of three kinds: and all these are necessary in their place.
Et istae sunt formae Scalpellorum, quibus secantur et excoriantur Nodi, et apostemata: et sunt trium specierum: quoniam ex eis est magnum, medium, et paruum.	And these are the forms of scalpels with which knots and abscesses are cut and scraped: and there are three kinds: because among them is a large one, a medium one, and a small one.
Eorum extremitates quibus fit sectio sunt acutae, extremitates aliae sunt non acutae: et non ponuntur taliter, nisi ut cum eis fiat iuuamentum in excoriatione Nodorum apud timorem incisionis uenae, aut nerui: et ut sanetur per ea infirmus, et inueniat tranquillitatem parumper ex adustione quam inuenit apud excoriationem apostematis.	The extremities that are cut are sharp, the other extremities are not sharp; and they are not placed in this way unless that help is given to them with a scraping of nodules out of fear of incision of the vein, or nerve; and that the weak one may be healed through them, and find a little peace from burning as he finds in the scraping of an abscess.
Istae sunt Magda, et sunt specierum trium.	These are Magda, and there are three kinds of them.
Fiunt ex aere, et sunt similia Radio, cum quo fit alcohol: et in extremitate lata est puncta Spatumilis occultata: et in ea currit ad interiora, et ad exteriora quando uis, sicut uides.	They are made of metal, and are similar to a Still used for making alcohol: and at the wide end there is a small point hidden called Spatula; and through this it flows inwards and outwards when you wish, as you see.
Forma Spatumilium quae absconduntur inter digitos apud perforationem apostematum: et non percipiunt ea infirmi: et sunt trium specierum, magnum, medium, et paruum.	The shape of pus pockets that are hidden between the fingers at the site of a wound abscess: and the sick do not feel these, and they come in three types, large, medium, and small.
Fomae Ventosarum cum quibus abscinditur fluxus sanguinis: et sunt trium specierum, magnae, mediae, et paruae.	Wounds of the winds with which the flow of blood is cut off; and they are three kinds, great, medium, and small.
Fiant ex aere, aut citrino, rotundae, ad longitudinem parumper, sicut uides: et sint ad subtilitatem.	Let them be made of copper or citrine, round, a little lengthways, as you see: and let them be fine.
Et oportet ut sint istae species Ventosarum apud te magnae, et paruae: ut abscindas per eas sanguinem cum uelocitate apud necessitatem, et tunc quando non est tibi praesens medicina.	And it is necessary that these kinds of  wind instruments be with you both great and small: so that you may cut off blood with them quickly when it is necessary, and then when medicine is not present to you.
Verumtamen non utaris eis in abscisione sanguinis in omni loco corporis, et non utaris nisi in locis carnosis: sicut lacertis cruris, et coxae, et lacertis brachiorum, et mammillarum, et uentris, et inguinum, et similibus eis, ex lacertis carnosis, humidis.	However, you do not use them for cutting blood in every place of the body, but only in fleshy places: such as the armpits of the legs, and hips, and armpits of the arms, and nipples, and belly, and groin, and the like, from fleshy, moist wounds.
Et quandoque fiunt ex eis instrumenta parua alia similia corticibus fisticorum, secundum suam formam: quibus abscinditur sanguis quando fluit ex loco phlebotomiae, aut apud incisionem uenae, aut arteriae: et quandoque fiunt ex eis rotundae secundum hanc formam.	And sometimes they are made from them small instruments similar to the bark of a fist, according to their form: with which blood is cut when it flows from the place of phlebotomy, or near the incision of a vein, or artery: and sometimes they are made from them round, according to this form.
¶ De cura Mammillarum hominum quae mammillis mulierum assimilantur.	On the treatment of the nipples of men which resemble the nipples of women.
Caput XLVII.	Chapter XLVII.
Quandoque inflantur Mammillae quorundam hominum apud complementum somni (id est, cum incipiunt pollui in somno) donec similantur mammillis mulierum: et remanent apostemosae foede.	Sometimes the breasts of some men swell at the time of sleep (that is, when they begin to dream) until they resemble the breasts of women, and they remain festering with pus.
Qui ergo abhorret illud, oportet ut secet super mammillas sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Deinde excoria pinguedinem totam.	Whoever avoids this, it is necessary that he cut above the nipples with a lunar section, according to this form from the line, b, to the line, g. Then scrape off all the fat.
Postea imple uulnus ex medicamine incarnatiuo.	Then fill the wound with a medicine of incorporated [ingredients].
Deinde aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then gather together the two lips of the wound with a suture, and take care of it until it heals.
Si autem declinat mammilla ad inferiora, et mollificatur propter magnitudinem suam, sicut accidit mulieribus: tunc oportet ut findatur in duobus lateribus suis superioribus duabus sectionibus similibus figurae lunari, quarum unaquaeque continetur cum altera apud fines utriusque, donec sit linea maior continens minorem, secundum hanc formam ex linea, b. ad lineam, g. Postea excoria cutem quae est inter duo labia, et aufer pinguedinem, et administra quod diximus de sutura et pulueribus, quod est necessarium ex curatione, donec sanetur.	If, however, the nipple is inclined downwards and softens because of its size, as happens to women: then it must be cut in two sections on its upper sides, similar in shape to the moon, each containing the other at the edges of both, until a larger line contains a smaller one, according to this form from line b to line g. Afterwards scrape the skin which is between the two lips and remove the fat, and administer what we have said about sutures and powders, which are necessary for healing, until it heals.
Si autem non comples incisionem eius quod oportet te incidere, propter inquietudinem infirmi, aut propter fluxum sanguinis: tunc oportet ut impleas uulnus coto submerso unguento corrosiuo, et dimitte ipsum, donec corrodat illud quod remansit ex pinguedine.	If however you are not able to make the incision as is required of you because of the restlessness of the sick person, or because of the flow of blood: then it is necessary that you fill the wound with a thick ointment submerged with corrosive substance, and leave it so, until it corrodes that which remains from fat.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of him until he is healed.
¶ De perforatione apostematis, quod accidit sub Titillico.	On the incision of a boil that happens under the nipple.
Caput XLVIII.	Chapter XLVIII.
Ista apostemata quae accidunt sub Titillico, sunt ex speciebus Strophularum dura, quae continet kistis, et ex eis sunt quae continent humiditates.	These abscesses which occur under the nipple are of kinds of hard  Strophula, which contain cysts, and from these are those which contain humors.
Quae ergo sunt ex eis quae continent humiditates, oportet ut secentur sectione lunari, secundum hanc formam, ex linea b. ad lineam, g. cum ergo euacuatur totum quod est in apostemate ex sanie, tunc imple ipsum coto ueteri, et dimitte ipsum usque ad diem alium.	Therefore, those which contain moisture should be cut with a lunar section, according to this form, from line b to line g. And when everything that is in the abscess from pus has been evacuated, then fill it with old stool, and leave it until the next day.
Deinde auferatur cotum, et curetur cum unguento conueniente ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then the clot is removed, and it is treated with ointment suitable for it until it heals.
Quod si apostema fuerit ex specie nodorum Strophularum, tunc scinde super ipsum, sicut diximus in sectione super Strophulas aequaliter.	If an abscess be of the kind of Strophula knots, then cut above it, as we said in the section about cutting into Strophulae equally.
Si autem extenditur uulnus in hoc ut emittat pus, tunc administra in eo cauterium, secundum quod diximus in eo quod praemissum est.	If, however, a wound is extended so that it emits pus, then administer to it cautery, according to what we have said before.
¶ De sectione apostematis quod accidit propter Arteriam et Venam.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs because of an artery and vein.
Caput XLIX.	Chapter XLVII.
Quando disrumpitur Arteria, et consolidatur cutis quae est supra eam, tuno multotiens accidit inde apostema: et similiter accidit Venae etiam, ut accidat in ea apostema et inflatio.	When an artery is ruptured and the skin above it is healed, often a boil occurs from there, and similarly with veins, that a boil and swelling occur in them.
Et signa quibus cognoscitur, quod apostema et inflatio sint propter Arteriam et Venam, sunt: quoniam, quando apostema est propter arteriam, est longum, aggregatum in profundo corporis: et quando impellis apostema digits tuis, sentis quasi sit ei stridor.	And the signs by which it is known that an abscess and inflammation are due to an artery and a vein are: because when an abscess is due to an artery, it is long, gathered deep in the body: and when you press the abscess with your fingers, you feel as if there were a crackling sound.
Et illud quod est propter Venam, est rotundum in manifesto corporis.	And that which is because of the Vein, is round on the manifest body.
Et sectio super hoc apostema est error, et praecipue quod est sub ascellis, et inguinibus, et collo, et in locis multis corporis: et est magnum ualde.	And a section above this abscess is an error, and especially that which is under the armpits, and groins, and neck, and in many places of the body: and it is very great.
Oportet ergo ut deuitetur eius cura cum ferro, et quod ex eis etiam est in extremitatibus, aut in capite, oportet ut deuitetur.	Therefore it is necessary that his care be performed with iron, and what from them is also in the extremities, or in the head, it is necessary that it be performed.
Super illud ergo quod ex eis est ex inflatione orificii Arteriae, finde in cute sectione in longitudine.	Therefore, about that which is from them by inflation of the artery's opening, make a cut in the skin lengthwise.
Deinde aperi sectionem cum uncinis, postea Arteriam: et libera eam ex tunicis, donec detegatur.	Then open the section with hooks, afterward the Artery: and free it from its coverings until it is revealed.
Deinde intromitte sub ea acum, et fac eam penetrare usque ad latus aliud, et stringe Arteriam cum filo duplo in duobus locis, secundum quod docui te in extractione duarum Arteriarum quae sunt in timporibus.	Then introduce the point under it, and make it penetrate to the other side, and bind the Artery with a double thread in two places, according to what I have taught you in the extraction of the two Arteries that are in the temples.
Deinde punge locum, qui est inter duo ligamenta cum spatumili, donec egrediatur sanguis qui est in eo totus, et soluatur apostema.	Then prick the place that is between two ligaments with a lancet until all the blood that is in it comes out and the abscess breaks up.
Deinde administra curationem quae generat pus, donec cadant ligamenta: postea cura illud cum unguentis conuenientibus ad illud, donec sanetur.	Then administer a cure that generates pus until the ligaments fall away; afterwards care for it with ointments suitable to it, until it heals.
Quod si fuerit apostema propter sectionem Venae, tunc oportet ut teneas manu tua quod tibi possibile est ex apostemate cum cute.	If it is an abscess due to the cutting of a vein, then you ought to hold with your hand as much as you can from the abscess with skin.
Deinde intromitte acum sub loco quem tenuisti manu tua, et fac eam penetrare: et sit in ea filum duplum, donec extrahas ipsum ex latere altero.	Then introduce a needle under the place you held with your hand, and make it penetrate; and let there be a double thread in it until you extract it from the other side.
Deinde liga cum ipso apostema ligamento bono: secundum quod dixi tibi in ligamento uuae, a duabus partibus cum duabus extremitatibus fili.	Then tie the band with the abscess with a good ligature: according to what I told you about the ligament of the vein, from two parts with two extremities of thread.
Si autem times quod extrahatur filum, tunc intromitte acum aliam cum filo alio sub apostemate toto apud incisionem acus: preme, et stringe fila tua in quatuor locis.	If you fear that the thread will be pulled out, then introduce another needle with a different thread under the entire abscess at the incision; press and tighten your threads in four places.
Deinde seca apostema in medio sui, donec quando egreditur quod in eo est: tunc incide superfluitatem cutis, et dimitte quod ligatum est ex ea.	Then dry the abscess in the middle of itself until it brings forth what is in it; then cut away the excess skin, and release what is tied from it.
Deinde pone super ipsum puluillum quem submersisti in uino, et oleo.	Then place upon it the little bit that you submerged in wine and oil.
Deinde administra curationem, quae fit cum liciniis et unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then administer treatment which is done with liniments and ointment until it heals.
¶ De apostemate quod accidit ex torsione Neruorum.	On an abscess that occurs from a twisting of the nerves.
Caput L.	Chapter L.
Sicut accidit apostema in Arteria et Vena, similiter accidit apostema in Neruis: quod accidit in eis percussio, aut accidit a labore superfluo, et similibus: et fit plurimum illis in locis adiutoriorum, aut calcanei, et in omni loco in quo mouentur iuncturae: et est apostema graue.	As an abscess occurs in an artery and vein, so also does it occur in a nerve; which occurs in them by percussion, or by excessive labor, and the like: and it is most frequent in those places of the helpers, or heel, and in every place where joints are moved: and it is a serious abscess.
Similatur color eius reliquo corpori, et est in pluribus dispositionibus absque dolore: et quando stringitur cum uehementia, sentit in eo infirmus simile stupori.	Its color resembles that of the rest of the body, and it is in many dispositions without pain: and when it is squeezed with force, it feels in it weak like a kind of stupor.
Et non est apostema aggregatum in profundo corporis, imo est sub cute, et ipsum mouetur ad omnem partem, et non uadit ad anteriora, uel ante, neque retro ad posteriora.	And it is not an abscess collected deep in the body, but rather under the skin, and it moves to every part, and does not go to the front parts, or forward, nor backward to the back parts.
Quod ergo ex eis est in iuncturis, non oportet ut inuadatur cum ferro.	Therefore, what is among those things in the joints, it ought not to be entered with iron.
Fortasse enim accidet contractio.	Perhaps contraction may occur.
In illo autem quod ex eis est in capite, aut in fronte, finde cutem cum spatumili.	In that which is from them in the head, or on the forehead, cut the skin with a scalpel.
Si ergo est apostema paruum, tunc tene ipsum cum forficibus, et abscinde ipsum a radice.	If therefore it is a small abscess, then hold it with forceps and cut it from its root.
Et si est magnum, tunc suspende ipsum eum uncino, et excoria ipsum: deinde aufer ipsum, et aggrega uulnus cum sutura: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	And if it is large, then suspend it with a hook, and scrape it; then remove it, and close the wound with suture; and care for it until it heals.
¶ De sectione apostematis, quod accidit in uentre.	On the incision of an abscess that occurs in the abdomen.
Caput LI.	Chapter LXI.
Accidunt quibusdam hominibus multotiens in uentribus eorum, et in reliquis corporibus ipsorum, thelil, quae nominantur Fungalia, per similitudinem ipsorum cum fungis.	There happen to some men many times in their bellies, and in the rest of their bodies, growths which are called Fungalia, by similarity of them with mushrooms.
Quorum radix est subtilis, et ipsorum caput est grossum, et conuersa sunt labia eorum.	The root of which is fine, and their head is thick, and their lips are reversed.
Et est ex eis paruum: et est ex eis quod magnificatur ualde.	And it is small of these: and it is much magnified of these.
Et ego quidem iam uidi uirum, et in uentre eius erant duo thelil, quae erant magis quam rebus aliis similia fungis: non erat differentia inter ea, alba, minutae radicis, et inuersabantur labia eorum, et findebantur, et humiditas currebat ex eis semper.	And I myself have seen a man, and in his belly were two swellings which were more like fungi than anything else: there was no difference between them, white, small roots, and their lips were turned inward and they ended, and moisture always flowed from them.
Incidi ergo ea, et inueni in pondere unius quasi X et VIII uncia et in altero quasi VI uncia Et operatio in incisione eorum est, ut consideres tunc, si infirmus est humidus, et color thelil est albus, humidum, subtilis radicis: tunc incide ipsum cum spatumili lato, et sint in praesentia tua cauteria in igne.	Therefore, cut them and I found in one a weight of almost X and VIII ounces and in the other almost VI ounces. And the operation in their incision is, that you consider then, if the infirm is moist, and the color thelil is white, moist, subtle root: then cut it with a wide spatula, and let cauteries be present in your fire.
Multotiens enim expellitur apud sectionem eius sanguis multus: propera ergo si te uincit sanguis, tunc cauteriza ipsum.	For often much blood is expelled during its cutting; therefore if you are overcome by blood, then cauterize it.
Quod si uides infirmum pauidum et timidum ab incisione cum ferro, tunc accipe filum ex plumbo decenter factum, et stringe cum eo athelul: cuius modus est quem diximus, et dimitte ipsum duobus diebus.	If you see a weak and fearful patient from the cutting with iron, then take a lead thread made properly, and bind it with it athleul: whose way is which we have said, and release him in two days.
Deinde adde in strictura plumbi.	Then add lead to the constriction.
Non ergo cesses stringere plumbum, quotiens imprimit in thelil, donec abscindatur, et cadat per se absque labore.	Therefore do not cease pulling on the lead until it is imprinted into the tile, until it breaks off and falls by itself without labor.
Si autem thelil grossae fuerit radicis, tunc in incisione eius est quiddam timoris et pauoris: praecipue quod est in uentre.	If however the root is of great size, then in its incision there is some fear and anxiety, especially because it is in the belly.
Verumtamen possibile est, ut incidas medietatem eius.	Nevertheless it is possible that you cut its half.
Deinde cauteriza ipsum, ut non redeat.	Then cauterize it so that it does not return.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur uulnus.	Then care for the wound until it heals.
Et caue ne praesumas incidere thelil quod est fusci coloris, pauci sensus, foedi aspectus: ipsum enim est apostema cancerosum: et ego ueniam cum rememoratione Cancri post hoc.	And beware that you do not presume to cut into the thing that is dusky in color, with few senses, and foul appearance: for this is a cancerous abscess; and I will come back with a remembrance of Cancer after this.
¶ De cura eminentiae Vmbilici.	On the treatment of the eminence of the umbilicus.
Caput LII.	Chapter LI.
Fit eminentia Vmbilici ex caussis multis.	A protrusion of the umbilicus arises from many causes.
Aut ex fissuris sifac, quod super uentrem est: et exit ex eo althub, aut intestinum, secundum quod accidit in reliquis rupturis.	Or from fissures which are above the belly and it exits from there either the large intestine or the small intestine, according to what happens in other ruptures.
Aut ex sanguine qui fluit ex Vena, aut ex Arteria, secundum quod praemissum est.	Either from the blood that flows from a Vein, or from an Artery, according to what has been said before.
Aut ex uentositate coartata in eo.	Or contracted by a wind therein.
Si autem est propter fissuram sifac, et exitum thirbi: tunc est color apostematis similis colori corporis: et est lene, absque dolore: et apparet diuersi situs.	If it is due to a fissure of the skin and the discharge of pus: then the color of the abscess is similar to the color of the body: and it is soft, without pain: and it appears in various locations.
Et si est propter egressionem intestini, tunc est situs eius, cum eo quod narrauimus, uehementioris diuersitatis.	And if it is because of the protrusion of the intestines, then its location is, with that which we have narrated, of greater variety.
Cum ergo tu premis ipsum digitis tuis, occultatur: deinde redit, et fortasse est cum eo sonitus: et magnificatur multum apud introitum balnei, et laborem uehaementum.	When therefore you press it with your fingers, it disappears; then it returns, and perhaps there is a sound with it; and it becomes much larger at the entrance of the bath, and labor is felt.
Si uero est propter humiditatem, est lene, tunc non occultatur quando premis ipsum manu tua, neque constringium, neque additur.	If it is because of moisture, it is soft, then it is not hidden when you press it with your hand, nor is a constriction added.
Quod si est propter sanguinem, tunc cum istis signis apparet apostema ad nigredinem de cliue.	If it is because of blood, then with these signs the pus appears black from the ulcer.
Si autem est propter carnem natam: tunc est apostema graue, grossum, durum, et figitur secundum quantitatem unam.	If it is due to flesh being born: then it is a serious, large, hard abscess, and it forms according to the amount of one.
Si uero est propter uentositatem, tunc tactus eius est lenis.	If it is because of windiness, then its touch is gentle.
Et operatio in illo est, ut consideres tunc, si eminentia umbilici est propter sanguinem Arteriae, aut Venae, aut uentositatem: tunc oportet ut prohibearis a curatione eius.	And the operation on this is that you should consider then if the prominence of the navel is because of blood from the Artery, or Vein, or windiness; then it is necessary that you prevent its cure.
Nam in illo est timor et pauor, sicut docui te in capitulo, in quo dixi apostemata propter arteriam et uenam.	For there is fear and dread, as I taught you in the chapter, in which I said abscesses because of the artery and vein.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est propter intestinum, aut zirbum: tunc oportet ut praecipias infirmo, quatenus teneat anhelitum suum, et stet stans extensus.	If the prominence of the navel is due to intestine or a tumor: then it is necessary that you instruct the sick person so that he holds his breath and stands standing extended.
Deinde signa cum encaustro in circumitu umbilici totius.	Then signs with a cautery around the whole navel.
Postea praecipe ei, ut resupinetur inter manus tuas super dorsum suum.	Then command him to lie down between your hands upon his back.
Deinde circunda cum spatumili lato in circumitu umbilici super locum quem signasti cum encaustro.	Then surround with a spatula wide around the navel above the place which you have marked with encrustation.
Postea extende medium apostematis ad superiora, cum uncino magno.	Afterwards, extend the middle of the abscess upwards with a large hook.
Deinde liga eum in circumitu forti cum filo, aut cum chorda de serico ligamento firmo: et sit nodus ligamenti alenxotati.	Then bind him around with a strong thread, or with a silk cord of firm ligament: and let the knot of the ligament be untied.
Deinde aperi medium apostematis extensum supra ligamentum.	Then open the center of the abscess extended above the ligament.
Si ergo inueneris ipsum iam captum a ligamento: tunc extrahe alenxotati, et intromitte in ipsum digitum indicem, et impelle intestinum ad interiora uentris: et si inueneris zirbum, tunc accipe ipsum cum uncino, et incide superfluitatem eius.	If therefore you find it already caught by the ligament: then extract it with an instrument, and introduce into it your index finger, and drive the intestine into the interior of the belly: and if you find a hernia, then take it with a hook, and cut away its superfluity.
Si autem contraria est tibi arteria, aut uena: tunc circunda ipsum multum.	If, however, the artery or vein is opposite you, then wind around it much.
Deinde redi ad operationem tuam.	Then return to your operation.
Et accipe duas acus, et intromitte in eis duo fila fortia: et intromitte duas acus in circumitu quem fecisti circa apostema in modum crucis, quas facis penetrare.	Take two needles and insert into them two strong threads: and insert two needles around the circumference which you have made around the abscess in the form of a cross, which you make penetrate.
Deinde stringe apostema in quatuor locis super acus: et si uis, aufer acus, et dimitte locum, donec putrefiat caro extensa: et cadat per se: aut incide ipsam quando subtiliatur et putrefit.	Then bind the abscess in four places above the needle: and if you wish, remove the needle, and leave the place, until the extended flesh rots: and falls by itself: or cut it yourself when it becomes subtle and rots.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod oportet ex unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for him with what is necessary from ointment until he heals.
Quod si eminentia umbilici est ex carne nara in eo, aut ex humiditate: tunc oportet ut concaues apostema, sicut diximus.	If the prominence of the umbilicus is from flesh or a hernia, or from moisture, then it is necessary to concave the abscess as we have said.
Et extrahas sanguinem, aut humiditatem, quam inuenis in eo.	And you shall draw out blood, or moisture, which you find in it.
Deinde cura ipsum cum eo quod solidat locum.	Then care for it with that which solidifies the place.
¶ De cura CANCRI.	On the treatment of cancer.
Caput LIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam diximus in diuisione species Cancri, et qualiter est uia ad curationem eius cum medicinis: et cauendum ab eo cum curatione eius cum ferro, ut non ulceretur: et diximus Cancrum generatum in matrice, et cautelam a curatione eius.	We have spoken in the division of the kinds of Cancer, and how is the way to its cure with medicines: and beware of it with its cure with iron, that it may not ulcerate: and we have spoken of Cancer generated in the womb, and caution from its cure.
Et dixerunt antiqui, quod quandoque Cancer est in loco, ubi possibilis est eius eradicatio: sicut Cancer qui est in mammillis, aut in coxa, et eis similibus, ex membris locatis ad extrahendum totum eius: praecipue quando est incipiens paruus.	And the ancients said that sometimes cancer is in a place where it is possible to eradicate it: such as cancer that is in the nipple, or in the hip, and similar parts, from members located to remove the whole thing: especially when it is beginning small.
Quando uero antiquatur, et est magnus, non oportet ut appropinques ei.	When, however, it becomes old and large, it is not proper that you should approach it.
Ego enim non potui sanare ex eo aliquem: neque uidi alium ante me qui peruenerit ad illud.	For I could not heal anyone from it; nor did I see anyone before me who has ever cured it.
Et operatio in eo, quando est locatus sicut diximus, est, ut praecedas, et soluas infirmum ex cholera nigra aliquotiens.	And the operation in this case, when it is situated as we have said, is, as before, to open the patient from black bile several times.
Deinde phlebotoma ipsum si inuenis cum repletione manifesta.	Then if you find the lancet filled with blood that is clearly visible.
Deinde praepara infirmum praeparatione, in qua locetur cum operatione.	Then prepare the sick person for the preparation, in which he will be operated on.
Deinde proiice in Cancrum uncinos qui conueniunt ei.	Then throw into the ulcer hooks that fit it.
Postea concaua ipsum ab omni parte cum cute, secundum perscrutationem, donec non remaneat aliquid ex radicibus eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere, et non abscindas ipsum uelociter, imo exprime loca, et absterge sanguinem grossum totum manu tua, aut cum quo possibile est ibi ex instrumentis.	Afterward, hollow out the entire thing with skin, according to examination, until nothing remains of its roots: and let blood flow, and do not cut it quickly, rather squeeze the places, and wipe away all the gross blood with your hand, or with whatever instrument is possible there.
Si autem contrarietatem facit tibi fluxus sanguinis grossi ex incisione arteriae, aut uenae: tunc cauteriza uenam, donec abscindatur sanguis.	If a flow of thick blood from an incision in an artery or vein causes you trouble, then cauterize the vein until the blood is cut off.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with the rest of the treatment, until it heals.
¶ De cura Hydropisis.	On the Treatment of Dropsy.
Caput LIIII.	Chapter LIII.
Iam narrauimus in diuisione species Hydropisis, et qualiter fit aggregatio aquae: et signa omnis speciei, et curationem eius cum medicinis.	Now we speak in the division of the kinds of dropsy, and how the gathering of water is made: and the signs of every kind, and its cure with medicines.
Et illa quae curatur cum ferro, non est nisi species asclitis sola: et non approximatur cum ferro speciei timpanitis: neque speciei hyposarcae penitus: nam illud mortale est.	And that which is cured with iron is only a species of abscess alone; and it is not approached with iron in the case of otitis, nor in the case of hydrops entirely; for this is mortal.
Quando tu iam medicatus es hanc speciem Hydropisis timpanitis cum medicinis, et non contulit medicatio tua: tunc considera.	When you have already treated this type of Watery Swelling of the Ear with medicines, and your treatment has not helped, then consider.
Nam si infirmo iam consecuta est debilitas, aut est cum eo infirmitas alia praeter Hydropisim: sicut si sit cum eo tussis, aut uentris solutio, et similia illis: tunc caue ne mediceris ei cum ferro: quoniam est timor illud.	For if weakness has already overtaken the sick person, or there is another infirmity besides dropsy, such as coughing, or diarrhea of the belly, and things similar to these: then beware that you do not treat him with iron; because there is fear of this.
Si autem uides infirmum exuberantis uirtutis, neque est cum eo aegritudo praeter Hydropisim solam: et non est puer, neque senex: tunc modus operationis in eo est, ut tu eleues infirmum stantem inter manus tuas, et minister post ipsum exprimat uentrem eius manu sua impellendo aquam ad inferiorem partem pectinis.	If you see a patient with abundant strength and the only ailment is hydrops, and he is neither a child nor an old man, then the mode of operation on him is that you raise the patient standing between your hands, and a minister behind him presses his abdomen with his hand, driving water to the lower part of the chest.
Deinde accipe spatumile spinosum, secundum hanc formam.	Then take a pointed spatula, according to this form.
Sit duarum partium acutarum, longum, acutae extremitatis sicut Spatumile.	Let there be two acute parts, long and with a sharp end like a spatula.
Verumtamen in eo sit quiddam breuitatis paulatim, ut non pertranseas cum eo apud operationem usque ad intestinum, et laedas ipsum.	Nevertheless, there should be something of brevity little by little so that you do not pass through it with him at the operation up to the intestines and wound him.
Deinde considera.	Then consider.
Nam si est generatio Hydropisis ex parte intestinorum, tunc oportet ut elongeris cum sectione ab umbilico quantitate trium digitorum, ad inferiora in directo eius supra pectinem.	If a Hydrops is generated from the part of the intestines, then it is necessary to extend with a section from the navel three finger widths down directly above the breastbone.
Si uero generatio Hydropisis est propter aegritudinem epatis: tunc sit sectio tua sinistra ab umbilico tribus digitis.	If now the generation of Hydropsis is because of the sickness of the liver, then your section should be on the left from the navel three fingers' width.
