Then bind it over the flesh which is under the bone: and extend its extremity so that you draw the flesh to the lower part: and you will uncover the flesh over the place which you wish to suture, so that it does not harm the saw by cutting the flesh.
Pone lignum, aut tabulam sub osse inferius decenter: quoniam quando facis illud, non prohibetur quin secet carnem corruptam.	Place a stick, or a board under the bone below in the center; because when you do this, it does not prevent cutting rotten flesh.
Et oportet ut sit Serratura super locum corruptum parumper, ut non sit in concauitate ossis corruptio: et non appareat in apparitione sua sensui, et cogat ad Serraturam sui uice alia.	And it is necessary that a clamp be placed upon the place corrupted for a short time, so that there may not be corruption in the concavity of the bone: and it may not appear in its appearance to the sense, and compel to the clamp of its vice another thing.
Quod si os est corruptum, et non est eminens, imo continuatur pars eius cum parte: et corruptio est in medio eius, aut in parte ipsius: tunc detege carnem ab omnibus partibus totam.	If the bone is broken and not protruding, but its part continues with that part; and the corruption is in the middle of it, or in a part of it, then uncover the flesh from all parts altogether.
Deinde pone lignum inferius.	Then place the lower wood.
Postea serra illud ex parte prima, ubi est corruptio, donec continuetur Serratura ex parte altera: et sit Serratura secundum longitudinem a corruptione parumper, secundum quod diximus.	Afterwards, saw it on the first part, where is the corruption, until the sawing continues on the other part: and let the sawing be according to the length from the corruption a little, as we have said.
Quod si corruptio est in iunctura, incide ipsam iuncturam corruptam, et serra os ubi continuatur ex parte altera.	If corruption is in a joint, cut the corrupted joint itself, and saw the bone where it continues from the other part.
Si uero corruptio est in continuatione duarum iuncturarum, tunc non est in ea ingenium nisi abrasio.	If however corruption is in the junction of two articulations, then there is no skill in it except abrasion.
Quod si corruptio est in pectine manus, aut in pectine pedis: tunc res in eo est difficilis ualde.	If corruption is in the breast of the hand, or in the breast of the foot: then the matter is very difficult there.
Verum oportet, ut inquiras corruptionem qualiter appareat tibi.	But it is necessary that you inquire how the corruption appears to you.
Et abradas eam, et mundes ipsam secundum quamcunque dispositionem tibi possibile est, et cum quocunque ingenio rectificatur tibi: quando non facit tibi contrarietatem Vena, aut Neruus.	And having scraped it, and cleansed it according to whatever arrangement is possible for you, and with whatever ingenuity it may be rectified for you: when it does not make opposition to you of Vein, or Nerve.
Et scias quod incisoria, et Serrae ad incidendum ista ossa sunt multa, secundum situm ossium, et praparationem eorum, et ipsorum grossitudinem, et subtilitatem eorum, et magnitudinem, et paruitatem ipsorum, et duriciem ipsorum, et eorum raritatem.	And know that the cutting tools, and saws for cutting these bones are many, according to the location of the bones, and their preparation, and their thickness, and fineness, and size, and smallness, and hardness, and their rarity.
Quapropter oportet, ut praepares omni speciei operationis instrumentum conueniens ad illam operationem.	Therefore it is necessary that instruments suitable for each kind of operation be prepared.
Et scias, quod operationes istae significant tibi super speciem instrumenti quo indiges, quando tecum est studium longum.	And know that these operations signify to you about the kind of instrument which you will need when it is a long study with you.
Et cognitio modorum huius artis, testimonium modorum aegritudinum: tunc enim iam inuenies per teipsum illud quod conuenit ei ex instrumentis ad omnem infirmitatem.	And knowledge of the modes of this art is a testimony to the modes of illnesses: for then indeed you will find through yourself that which is suitable for it from instruments to every infirmity.
Et ego sum firmans tibi in ultimo huius capituli numerum instrumentorum, quae pones exempla super quae incides, et probationem qua experiaris super alia.	And I am affirming to you at the end of this chapter the number of instruments which you will put examples upon which you will cut and proof which you will try on others.
Forma Serrae.	The Form of the Saw.
Forma alterius Serrae.	Form of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The shape of another saw.
Forma Serrae alterius.	The form of another saw.
Haec forma Serrae depicta, sit decenter facta.	This form of the saw, as depicted, is well made.
Fiat arcus eius superior, acuitas eius ex ferro: et manubrium eius ex buxo, et sit pyramidale decenter factum.	Let its arc be above, its sharpness from iron: and its handle from boxwood, and let it be pyramidal in shape, made off-center.
Forma Rasorii iuncturarum.	The form of a knife for joints.
Sit caput huius Rasorii, secundum formam capitis claui stellati: et puncta eius sint secundum formam punctorum elischetfegi.	Let the head of this razor be, according to the shape of the head of a star-shaped key: and its points be according to the shape of the points of the  elischetfegi.
Et non conuenit, nisi ut fricentur cum eo capita iuncturarum, quando corrumpuntur, aut os amplum, et magnum est.	And it is not fitting, unless they are rubbed with it, heads of the joints, when they are corrupted, or a wide and large bone.
Forma maioris Rasorii.	Shape of the Greater Scalpel.
Forma medii Rasorii.	The form of a scalpel's middle.
Forma Rasorii lati.	Shape of a broad scalpel.
Forma Rasorii in quo est concauitas.	Shape of a scalpel which has a concavity.
Forma Rasorii alterius subtilis.	Form of another fine razor.
Forma Rasorii alterius curuatae extremitatis.	Form of a lancet for another curved limb.
Forma Rasorii parui, subtilis tentae.	The form of the scalpel is small and fine blade.
Forma Rasorii cum quo inciduntur ossa.	The form of a chisel used for cutting bones.
Forma etiam Rasorii magni.	The shape of the large scalpel also.
Hoc similatur Radio, et extremitas est sicut Serra: exhibetur in locis multis ex rasione ossium.	This is similar to a chisel, and its extremity is like a saw: it is shown in many places from the sawing of bones.
Forma Rasorii quod conuenit ad rasionem eius quod perforatum est ex ossibus.	The shape of a scalpel which is suitable for the cutting of something that has been pierced through from the bones.
Extremitas eius triangula, acutarum est extremitatum.	The extremity of it is triangular, and its points are acute.
Fit ex Indi.	It is made from India.
Et similiter oportet, ut fiant omnia quae diximus ex Rasoriis, et Incisoriis, et Serris.	And similarly, it is necessary that all things which we have said be done from razors, and incisions, and saws.
¶ De incisione extremitatum, et Serratura ossium.	On the incision of extremities, and the setting of bones.
Caput LXXXIX.	Chapter LXXXIX.
Putrefiunt extremitates, aut ex caussa extrinseca, aut intrinseca.	The extremities putrify, either from an external cause, or from an internal cause.
Cum ergo medicatus fueris illam corruptionem curatione medicinarum, et non confert curatio: et uides corruptionem incidere in membrum, quam non repercutit aliquid: tunc oportet ut incidas illud membrum usque ubi consequitu corruptio, ut euadat infirmus per illud a morte, aut a malicia quae est maior defectu membri.	When therefore you have medicated that corruption with medicine, and the treatment does not help; and you see the corruption to affect the limb, which is not struck by anything: then it is necessary that you should cut into that limb until where the corruption follows, so that the sick man may be delivered through it from death, or from the evil which is greater than the defect of the member.
Et signum cui accidit illud est, quod denigratur membrum, donec putetur: quod ignis combussit ipsum, aut putrefit post nigredinem: donec inciditur illa putredo usque ad illud quod sequitur illud membrum, et serpit in totum corpus.	And the sign of this is that the limb is darkened until it is thought to be burned by fire or rotting after blackening: until the rot comes down to that which follows the limb and creeps into the whole body.
Propera ergo cum incisione eius, et similiter si caussa corruptionis est a percussione quorundam uenenosorum: sicut scorpionis marini, et uiperae, et rutellae, et similium.	Therefore, it is proper to make an incision with it, and similarly if the cause of corruption is from the sting of certain venomous things, such as a sea scorpion, and viper, and rattle snake, and similar ones.
Si ergo corruptio, aut percussio est in extremitate digiti, tunc incide digitum, et non des spacium corruptioni, ut incedat usque ad reliquam manum.	If therefore decay or percussion is in the extremity of the finger, then cut the finger, and do not leave space for the decay, so that it may go as far as the rest of the hand.
Et similiter si accidit in manu, tunc incide eam ex radice focilis, et non des spacium corruptioni, donec capiat in focili brachii.	And similarly if it happens in the hand, then cut it from the root of the finger and do not close the space for corruption until it reaches the elbow.
Et si inuadit in eo, tunc incide brachium apud cubitum in iunctura sua.	And if it invades in it, then cut the arm at the elbow at its joint.
Si autem pertransit corruptio, et uides eum circiter cubitum: tunc in illo est mors infirmi.	If however corruption passes through, and you see him about the arm: then there is death of the sick person.
Et administrare praeter illud ex curatione, est quantitas uirtus.	And in addition to this from healing, is the quantity of virtue.
Et similiter fac de pede, quando inuadit corruptio in digito, tunc incide ipsum apud unum nodorum: et si capit in pectine pedis, tunc incide pedem totum.	And similarly do for the foot, when corruption has invaded the finger, then cut it at one of the joints; and if it seizes on the arch of the foot, then cut the whole foot.
Si autem ascendit ad genu, tunc incide crus apud iuncturam genu.	If it ascends to the knee, then cut the leg at the knee joint.
Quod si corruptio iam peruenit supra genu, tunc non est in ea ingenium, nisi dimissio, et relinquere infirmum morti.	If corruption has already reached above the knee, then there is no remedy for it except to release and leave the weak to death.
Et modus incidendi membrum, aut serrandi ipsum est, ut stringas ligamentum in inferiori, quem uis incidere: et stringe ligamentum aliud supra locum.	And the manner of cutting a limb, or sewing it up is, as you would cut the ligament below, which you wish to cut; and tie another ligament above the place.
Et extendat minister ligamentum unum ad inferiora: et extendat minister aliud ligamentum superius ad sursum.	And let one minister extend a ligament downward: and let another minister extend a ligament upward.
Et tu separa carnem quae est inter duo ligamenta, cum Spatumili lato, donec detegatur caro tota.	And you separate the flesh which is between the two ligaments, with a broad spatula, until the whole flesh is uncovered.
Deinde incidatur, aut serretur.	Then it is cut, or sewn up.
Et oportet, ut ponas ab omnibus partibus pannum lini, et non tangat Serra locum sanum: et accidat infirmo laesio addita, et apostema calidum.	And it is necessary that you put linen from all parts, and let the saw not touch the healthy place: and let the infirmity added with an abscess happen.
Si autem accidat fluxus sanguinis interius dum operaris, tunc cauteriza locum uelociter: aut pone super ipsum quosdam pulueres abscindentes sanguinem.	If it happens that there is an internal bleeding while you are operating, then cauterize the place quickly: or put some powders on top of it that stop the blood.
Deinde redi ad medicationem tuam, donec compleatur.	Then return to your treatment until it is complete.
Deinde liga membrum uulneratum cum ligamento conueniente ei, et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then bind the wounded limb with a suitable ligament, and care for it until it heals.
Et ego narro tibi quod accidit uiro in pede suo, hoc idem accidens quod narro tibi.	And I tell you what happened to a man in his foot, this same thing that I tell you.
Quod est, quia accidit in pede suo nigredo, cum adustione quae assimilatur combustioni ignis: et corruptio illa in primis accidit in digito suo, donec coepit pedem totum.	That is because it happened in his foot, blackness, when a burning which is assimilated to the fire's burning; and that corruption first happened in his finger, until it began the whole foot.
Properauit ergo uir ex seipso, postquam uidit corruptionem incidere in membro cum uehementia eius, quod inuenit ex dolore, et adustione eius: et incidit ipsum apud iuncturam, et sanatus est.	Therefore a man made use of himself after he had seen the corruption to fall upon his limb with violence of it, which he found from the pain and burning of it: and he cut it at the joint, and was healed.
Et postquam praeteriit ei tempus longum, accidit ei illa eadem corruptio in digito manus suae indice.	And after a long time had passed for him, the same corruption happened to his index finger of his hand.
Venit ergo ad me, et conatus sum recuperare illam superfluitatem cum eo quod posui super manum ex medicinis post mundificationem corporis eius: et non repercussa est superfluitas, et coepit incedere in digitum alium: donec coepit coruptio in manum.	He therefore came to me, and I tried to recover that superfluity with what I had placed on his hand from medicines after the cleansing of his body: and the superfluity was not recovered, and it began to move into another finger; until corruption began in his hand.
Vocauit ergo me, ad incidendum manum eius: et nolui illud, sperans ex me super repercussionem illius superfluitatis: et timui etiam super ipsum apud incisionem manus eius mortem.	Therefore he called me to cut his hand: and I refused it, hoping for an outcome from me beyond the repercussions of that superfluity; and I also feared for him death upon the cutting of his hand.
Quoniam uirtus uiri erat super casum.	For his skill was superior to that of others.
Postquam ergo desperauit de me, reuersus est ad terram suam: et peruenit ad me de eo, quia properauit, et incidit manum suam totam: et sanatus est.	After he had despaired of me, he returned to his land: and it came to pass concerning him that he hurried, and fell with his whole hand: and he was healed.
Et non attuli hanc narrationem, nisi ut sit adiutorium super illud quod cadit de genere huius aegritudinis: et ut sit significatio qua significetur, et secundum quam agatur.	And I have not brought forward this account, except that it may be an aid concerning that which falls under the kind of this ailment: and that it may be a sign by which it is signified, and according to which it is treated.
¶ De cura Sinuum, et qualitate clisterizationis cum medicinis.	On the care of sinuses, and the nature of clysters with medicines.
Caput XC.	Chapter XC.
Quando accidit apostema in quibusdam membris carnosis, et prolongatur spacium apostematis, donec collectionem facit saniei: deinde rumpitur, aut perforatur, et egreditur quod in eo est ex sanie, et remanet locus uacuus quasi sit uas: et cutis quae est super ipsum sicut pannus qui iam subtiliatus est: et non peruenit ad ultimum in corruptione sua, neque imprimit in os, neque in neruum, neque in ligamentum: meretur ut nominetur Sinus: et non nominatur Fistula: uerumtamen si prolongatur spacium eius, donec imprimat corruptio in aliquid horum membrorum, tunc nominatur Fistula, aut zuken.	When a boil occurs in some fleshy limbs and the space of the boil is prolonged until it forms a collection of pus: then it bursts or is perforated, and what is in it comes out of the pus, and a hollow place remains like a vessel: and the skin which is over it is like a cloth which has already been finely woven: and does not reach to the last stage of corruption, nor does it imprint on the bone, nor on the nerve, nor on the ligament: it deserves to be called a Sinus: and it is not called a Fistula: but if the space of it is prolonged until the corruption imprints itself on any of these limbs, then it is called a Fistula, or zuken.
Et cura eius est, ut incidas illam cutem totam sicut reuoluitur: et praecipue quando subtiliata est, et facta sicut pannus: et confidis quia non aaehaeret cum loco, propter corruptionem suam.	And the care of it is, that you cut that skin entirely as it turns over: and especially when it has been softened and made like cloth: and trust that it does not adhere to the place, because of its corruption.
Si autem speras quod adhaereat cutis, et non consequitur ex eo corruptio illa ultima consecutione: et si in cute est spissitudo ex carne, tunc cura ipsum cum Clisteri: et est, ut consideres ad Sinum.	If you hope that it will adhere to the skin and not lead to that final corruption, and if there is thickness from flesh in the skin, then care for it with a clyster, and it is, as you consider, to the Sinus.
Tunc si est magnus, et pus quod emittitur ex eo est foetidi odoris: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum medicamine aegyptio, quod est aceti, et olei, et ziniar, partes recipiens aequales, aggregentur in uase: et decoquantur super ignem, donec rubeat medicamen: et ueniat in spissitudinem mellis.	Then if it is large, and the pus which comes forth from it is of foul smell: then clysterize it with an Egyptian remedy, which is vinegar, and oil, and ziniar, parts receiving equal, are gathered into a vessel: and they are boiled over fire until the remedy boils: and comes to the thickness of honey.
Deinde accipe ex eo quod tibi necesse est: et dissolue ipsum cum aqua et melle, et clisteriza cum eo Sinum: et stringe orificium eius, et dimitte medicinam in eo ad quantitatem duarum horarum.	Then take from it what you need: and dissolve it with water and honey, and enema the sinus with it. And close its opening, and let the medicine remain in it for the amount of two hours.
Deinde extrahe ipsum cum expressione: fac illud diebus tot, donec mundificetur Sinus, et remoueatur foetor.	Then extract it with expression: do this for so many days until the sinus is purified and the stench is removed.
Et quandoque clisterizatur cum aqua cineris, quando non est tibi praesens hoc medicamen: et est, ut accipias cinerem lignorum uitis, aut cinerem ex lignis ilicis: et proiicias super eam aquam.	And sometimes it is administered with water and ashes when this medicine is not present to you; and it is that you receive the ash of grape wood, or ash from holly wood; and you pour it over the water.
Deinde cola eam, et clisteriza cum ea, donec confidas quod Sinus iam ablutus est.	Then treat it with a compress and use an enema until you are confident that the sinus has been cleared.
Quod si infirmo non est tolerantia super medicamen aegyptium, neque aquam cineris, tunc clisteriza ipsum cum aqua et melle, cui iam permixtum est aliquid ex ziniar contrito.	If the patient cannot tolerate the Egyptian medicine or water of ash, then give him an enema with water and honey, to which has already been mixed something of ground zinjar.
Aut clisteriza ipsum cum melle et uino permixtis, quoniam de proprietate mellis est, ut mundificet, et abluat: et uinum facit adhaerere Sinum, praecipue quando in uino est superfluitas stipticitatis et siccitatis.	Or cleanse him with an enema of honey and wine mixed together, because it is the property of honey to cleanse and wash, and wine makes the sinus adhere, especially when there is an abundance of astringency and dryness in the wine.
Cum facis illud aliquotiens, et confidis quod Sinus corruptio iam remota est: tunc clisteriza ipsum cum eo quod facit nasci carnem in eo.	When you have done this several times and trust that the corruption of the sinus has already been removed: then irrigate it with that which causes flesh to grow there.
Et est, ut accipias ex emplastro dyafinicon: et dissoluas ipsum cum oleo rosato, et uino stiptico: aut clisteriza ipsum cum quibusdam medicinis, et unguentis aliis, quorum proprietates scripsi in tractatu unguentorum.	And it is, that you may receive from the diafinicon plaster: and dissolve it with rose oil, and stiptic wine: or clysterize it with certain medicines, and other ointments, whose properties I have written in the treatise on ointments.
Quod si orificium Sinus est strictum, in quo non capit cannula clisteris: tunc amplifica ipsum cum ferro parumper: aut pone in ipso licinium inuolutum in unguento aegyptio, aut in unguento basilicon, donec amplificetur.	If the opening of the sinus is narrow, in which a clyster cannula does not fit; then enlarge it with a small knife: or place within it a linen cloth smeared with Egyptian ointment, or with basilica ointment, until it is enlarged.
Et similiter si est orificium etiam amplum, tunc aggrega labia eius cum sutura: et dimitte ex eo quantitatem in quam ingrediatur clistere sine additione.	And similarly if the opening is also wide, then gather its lips together with a suture: and release from it the quantity into which the clyster will enter without addition.
Et similiter si orificium eius ex quo currit pus, est eleuatum ad superiora: tunc seca ipsum in depressiori loco qui est in ipso, ut currat ex eo pus usque inferius: quoniam pus quando coartatur in profunditate Sinus, prohibet carnem generari in eo.	And similarly if the opening from which the pus runs is elevated upwards: then dry it out in a lower place that is in it, so that it may run from there downwards; because when pus is constricted in the depth of the sinus, it prevents flesh from being generated in it.
Quod si non est tibi possibile secare Sinum circiter inferius eius secundum quod uis: tunc conare, ut praepares membrum praeparatione qua currat ex eo pus cum facilitate secundum quod praeparatur tibi.	If it is not possible for you to cut the Sinus approximately below it as you wish: then try to prepare the limb with preparation which will allow it to drain pus easily as it is being prepared for you.
Conare, ut non retineatur in eo aliquid ex pus omnino: et accipe medicinas consolidatiuas quae ponuntur super signum, conuenientes ad illud quod uis.	Try so that nothing of the pus is retained in it at all; and take medicinal poultices which are placed over the wound, suitable to what you wish.
Et extende eas super pannum lini.	And spread them over linen cloth.
Et sit pannus tantae quantitatis, qua fiat communicatio totius Sinus.	Let a cloth be of such size that communication of the whole sinus is made.
Deinde incide cum forficibus in directo orificii Sinus foramen, amplius orificio Sinus parumper.	Then cut with forceps at the direct opening of the sinus foramen, a little wider than the opening of the sinus.
Deinde extende ex unguentis lenibus super pannum alium, secundum quantitatem foraminis: et pone eum super ipsum positione longinqua ab orificio Sinus, ut alleuietur exitus pus ex eo: et non auferas pannum magnum, nisi post dies aliquos uice una.	Then extend from the ointments gentle on another cloth, according to the amount of the hole: and place it above it in a position far from the opening of the sinus, so that the exit of pus from it may be eased: and do not remove the large cloth, except after some days once.
Ille autem qui est super orificium Sinus, est ille quem remoues in omni hora, ut egrediatur quod aggregatur in eo ex pus: et ut scias, an illud quod currit ex eo uirus, est multum, aut parum: aut digestum, aut indigestum.	He who is over the opening of the Sinus, is he whom you remove at every hour, that what accumulates there from pus may go out; and so that you may know, whether that which runs out from it is much or little; or digested or indigested.
Et cum hoc iterum considera locum Sinus ipsius, an in ipso sentiat dominus eius dolorem, aut non sit in eo dolor, et an sit in eo apostema, aut non sit in eo apostema.	And again with this consider the place of the sinus itself, whether the lord feels pain in it, or whether there is no pain in it, and whether there is an abscess in it, or whether there is not an abscess in it.
Cum ergo protenditur medicatio tua taliter, et uides materiam quae egreditur super orificium Sinus, tunc scias, quod Sinus iam adhaeret, aut approximat adhaerentiae: tunc ergo solue ipsum in mane, aut in tertio die: et quando soluis uulnus, tunc permuta pannum alium, et renoua unguentum.	When therefore your treatment is thus extended, and you see the material which comes out above the opening of the Sinus, then know that the Sinus has already adhered, or approaches adhesion: then therefore dissolve it in the morning, or on the third day: and when you have dissolved the wound, then change the other cloth, and renew the ointment.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post spacium longum uirus subtile, tunc non desperes de adhaerentia eius, nam sanatio eius appropinquat, quoniam ex hominibus sunt qui tardant generationem carnis in uulneribus suis, et ex eis sunt qui agunt econtrario illius.	If a subtle virus emerges from the sinus after a long time, do not despair of its adhesion, for its healing is approaching, because some people delay the generation of flesh in their wounds, and there are those who act contrary to this.
Si autem egreditur ex Sinu post dies multos pus indigestum, tunc scias quod sinus non adhaeret.	If after many days undigested pus comes out of the sinus, then know that the sinus does not adhere.
Si ergo tardatur adhaerentia Sinus, et prolongatur res eius: tunc adde in exiccatione medicinarum, uerum faciant medici, ut sint medicinae in substantia sua humidae, et in uirtute sua siccae: sicut unguentum dyafinicon, quando additur in eo superfluitas additionis ex zegi.	If therefore the adhesion of the Sinus is delayed, and its process is prolonged: then add to the drying of the medicines, truly make the physicians so that they are medicines in their substance humid, and in their virtue dry: such as unguentum dyafinicon, when superfluity of addition from zegi is added to it.
Et ex magis ultimo quo curatur, est, ut accipias unguentum dyafinicon, et soluatur cum oleo rosato, et roretur super ipsum uinum antiquum aequale in substantia sua.	And of the most final cure, it is, that you take ointment diyafinicum and dissolve it with rose oil, and return it upon itself old wine equal in substance.
Deinde confice ipsum cum eo, et utere ipso.	Then make it with him and use it yourself.
Et iam facit simile huic actioni, quando non est tibi praesens unguentum dyafinicon, mel, quando decoquis ipsum, donec ingrossetur, et uteris eo.	And now he does something similar to this action, when you do not have dyafinicon ointment at hand, honey, when you have boiled it until it thickens, and use it.
Aut accipe myrrham, et aloen, et olibanum: tere totum, et pulueriza illud super mel dum est super ignem.	Or take myrrh and aloes and frankincense: pound the whole thing together, and pulverize it over honey while it is on the fire.
Deinde line super ipsum pannum, et stringe ipsum super Sinum: et line cum melle quod decoquisti, donec ingrossatum est: et pulueriza super ipsum species, et pone super ipsum pannum, et stringe eum.	Then a line over the very cloth, and tighten it over the sinus: and a line with honey which you have cooked, until it has thickened; and pulverize on top of it spices, and put them on top of the cloth, and tighten it.
Et quandoque administratur in illo aristolochia longa, et radices lilii coelestis, et est lilium: et farina herbi, et centaurea.	And sometimes it is administered there, the long birthwort, and roots of celestial lily, and it is lily, and herb flour, and centaurea.
Utere eis simplicibus, aut aggregatis, tere ea, et cribella ipsa: et pulueriza super mel quod narraui, et utere eo.	Use these simple ones, or those that are combined, rub them and the strainers themselves; and pulverize above honey as I have narrated, and use it.
Quod si prolongatur res Sinus, et non sanatur hac curatione: tunc scias, quod in profundo eius est corruptio: aut iam facit impressionem in ossibus, aut in reliquis membris duris, aut ligamentis: tunc cura ipsum curatione Fistularum, secundum quod praemissum est.	If the sinus condition persists and does not heal with this treatment: then know that there is corruption in its depths; or it has already made an impression on the bones, or the other hard members, or the ligaments; then treat it with the treatment of fistulas, according to what was previously stated.
¶ De cura Panaritii et unguis attritae, et incisione digiti additi, et sectione.	On the treatment of a paronychia and an abraded nail, and on the addition of a finger digit, and on the cutting (open).
Caput XCI.	Chapter XCIX.
Panaritium est apostema quod nascitur sub ungue pollicis manus, aut pedis: et fortasse nascitur in reliquis digitis.	A pimple is an abscess that is born under the nail of the thumb of the hand, or of the foot: and perhaps it is born in the other fingers.
Cum ergo prolongatur res eius, et negligitur curato eius, et apostematur apostemate calido: aut corrumpitur, et emittit pus, donec corrodit radicem unguis: et fortasse corrumpit eam totam, et fortasse peruenit corruptio ad os, donec est ei odor foetidus: et fit extremitas digiti lata, et fit color eius fuscus.	When therefore the matter is prolonged and its treatment is neglected, and it becomes a hot abscess: or it rots, and discharges pus until it corrodes the root of the nail; and perhaps it corrupts it entirely, and perhaps the corruption reaches the bone, until it has a foul odor: and the extremity of the finger becomes wide, and its color becomes dark.
Quando ergo tu curas ipsum, cum eo quod diximus in diuisione, et non confert curatio tua: tunc oportet ut incidas cum ferro totam superfluitatem quae remansit ex ungue.	When therefore you care for a wound and what we said in the division is not useful, and your care does not help; then it is necessary that you cut with a knife the whole superfluity which remains from the nail.
Deinde cauteriza uulnus post illud.	Then cauterize the wound after this.
Cauterium enim iuuatiuum est ualde.	A cautery is indeed very useful.
Si uero os est sanum, et est unguis etiam sana, et additiones uacuae unguis iam comprimunt carnem ad interiora, et incipiunt pungere ipsam, et laedunt eam: tunc oportet ut ponas Radium subtilem sub angulo unguis quae pungit carnem, et impelle eam sursum: et incide eam carnem cum facilitate, et pone super illud quod remanet de carne ex medicinis comburentibus, corrosiuis, donec remoueatur totum eius.	If the bone is healthy and the nail is also healthy, and the additions of the nail already press flesh to the inside, and begin to prick it, and harm it: then it is necessary that you put a thin radium under the angle of the nail which pricks the flesh, and drive it upward: and cut that flesh with ease, and place on top of that which remains of the flesh from burning medicines, corrosive ones, until the whole of it is removed.
Deinde cura illud cum unguentis, donec sanetur.	Then care for it with ointments until it heals.
Si autem corruptio iam imprimit in os, tunc oportet ut incidas illud os, et extrahas ipsum: non enim sanatur unquam dum permanet in eo os corruptum.	If corruption has already set in on the bone, then it is necessary to cut into that bone and remove it; for it is never healed while the corrupted bone remains there.
Quod si uides corrosionem et corruptionem incedere in digitum, tunc incide eum in uno nodorum, secundum quod praemissa est eius rememoratio.	If you see decay and corruption progressing in the finger, then cut it at one of the joints, according to what has been said before about its recollection.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then care for it until it heals.
Si autem accidat ungui attritio, aut percussio: et contingit in ea dolor uehemens, tunc oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	If, however, it happens that a nail be rubbed or struck and a severe pain comes upon it, then it is necessary for the surgeon first to blood-lett the affected person.
Deinde seca unguem cum Spatumili acuto sectione transuersa de sursum ad uisum.	Then dry the nail with a sharp spatula, making a transverse section from top to bottom as desired.
Et custodi, ne sectio perueniat ad carnem quae est sub ungue, nam tu facies accidere per illud super infirmum dolorem uehementem, et erit caussa ad natiuitatem carnis additae in loco.	And guard yourself so that the incision does not reach the flesh which is under the nail, for you will cause a very violent pain to happen through it to the sick man, and it will be the cause for added flesh growth in its place.
Deinde cura locum cum eo quod sedat dolores.	Then care for the place with that which soothes the pains.
Digitus uero additus qui nascitur in quibusdam manibus hominum, fortasse est carnosus totus: et fortasse sunt in quibusdam eorum ossa, et fortasse est in eo unguis: et quidam eorum nascitur in radice iuncturae, aut est natiuitas eius in quibusdam nodis digiti.	The finger which is born in some hands of men, perhaps is fleshy throughout; and perhaps there are bones in some of them, and perhaps there is a nail in it; and some of them are born at the root of the joint, or its birth is in some knots of the finger.
Ille ergo qui nascitur in quibusdam nodis digiti, non mouetur: et ille qui nascitur apud iuncturam digiti, fortasse mouetur.	Therefore he who is born in certain knots of the finger, does not move: and he who is born at the joint of the finger, perhaps moves.
Eius ergo qui ex eis est carnosus, sectio eius facilis est.	Therefore, it is easy to make an incision in that which of these is fleshy.
Quod est, ut incidas ipsum apud radicem suam cum Spatumili lato.	That is, that you cut it at its root with a broad spatula.
Eius autem cuius natiuitas est in radice iuncturae curatio, est difficilis.	The healing of one whose nativity is at the root of the joint is difficult.
Abstine ergo ab incisione eius.	Therefore abstain from cutting it.
In illo uero qui nascitur in digito apud ultimum nodorum, tunc oportet ut incidas in primis carnem eius incisione rotunda usque ad os.	In that one who is born with a fingernail at the last node, it is necessary to cut first the flesh of it with a round incision until the bone.
Deinde serra os cum una illarum Serrarum conuenientium ad illud.	Then saw with one of those saws fitting for it.
Deinde cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	Then take care of it until it heals.
Consolidatio autem quae accidit digitis adinuicem, multotiens accidit aut ex natiuitate hominis, id est, nascitur cum eo, aut a consolidatione uulneris, aut combustione ignis, et similibus.	The consolidation that occurs in the fingers of adjacency, often happens either from birth, that is, it is born with it, or from the consolidation of a wound, or burning fire, and similar things.
Oportet ergo ut seces illam consolidationem, donec redeant digiti secundum formam suam naturalem.	Therefore it is necessary that you cut away that consolidation until the fingers return to their natural form.
Deinde pone inter eos licinia, aut pannos infusos in oleo rosato: ut non consolidentur uelociter, et separa inter eos: aut pone inter eos laminam plumbi subtilem, donec consolidetur locus secundum quod oportet.	Then place between them linen cloths, or rags soaked in rose oil: so that they do not solidify too quickly, and separate between them; or place between them a thin sheet of lead until the place has solidified as is necessary.
Et similiter si accidat consolidatio quibusdam digitis cum palma, tunc seca illam consolidationem, secundum quod praeparatur et conuenit figurae membri.	And similarly if it happens that a digit is fused with the palm, then cut that fusion, according to how it is prepared and convenient for the shape of the limb.
¶ De incisione Vitium.	On the Incision of a Defect.
Caput XCII.	Chapter XCII.
Uites sunt Venae inuolutae, grossae, plenae superfluitatibus melancholicis quae accidunt in pluribus membris corporis: et plurimum euentus earum est in cruribus, praecipue in cruribus iter agentium et laborantium, et portantium.	Veins are found wrapped and large, full of superfluous melancholic substances that occur in many parts of the body; and most frequently they occur in the legs, especially in the legs of those who walk and labor, and carry things.
Oportet ergo ut administres excussionem corporis ex cholera nigra aliquotiens excussione forti.	Therefore it is necessary that you administer an incision of the body from black bile several times with a strong incision.
Deinde phlebotoma patientis eas basilicam.	Then the phlebotomist should take the patient's blood vessel.
Curatio uero earum cum ferro, est secundum duos modos.	The cure of them with iron, is according to two ways.
Vnus eorum est, ut secentur, et extrahatur sanguis niger.	One of them is that they are cut and black blood is drawn out.
Et modus alter est, ut eleuetur Vena, et extrahatur tota.	And another method is, that the vein be lifted and drawn out entirely.
Sectio uero eius est secundum hunc modum.	The section of it is according to this way.
Embroca crus in primis cum aqua calida multum, donec resoluatur sanguis grossus faeculentus.	Swell the leg first with hot water until the thick, foul blood is dissolved.
Deinde stringe crus infirmi a superiori parte coxae eius, usque ad inferiorem partem genu cum uitta.	Then bind the leg of the infirm from the upper part of the hip, to the lower part of the knee with a bandage.
Deinde seca uenam in loco uno, aut duobus, aut tribus sectione ampla.	Then dry the vein in one place, or two, or three with a wide incision.
Deinde eleua, id est, extrahe sanguinem in manu tua ab inferiori parte cruris, usque ad sursum, et a superiori oportet ut phlebotomes infirmum in primis.	Then raise, that is, draw blood from the lower part of the leg upward with your hand, and from above it is necessary for the lancet to cut the weak first.
Deinde seca unguem cum usque inferius: donec egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uides sufficere, et quam tolerat uirtus infirmi.	Then dry the nail until it comes out from the blood as much as you see sufficient, and as much as the strength of the weak can bear.
Postea liga eam: et praecipe ei, ut abstineat a cibis generantibus choleram nigram: et itera euacuationem et phlebotomiam, quando implentur Venae, et nocet illud infirmo.	Afterwards bind it, and instruct him to abstain from foods that produce black bile. And repeat evacuation and bloodletting when the veins are full, and this harms the sick person.
Eleuatio autem eius est secundum hunc modum.	Its elevation is according to this manner.
Rade crus infirmi, si in ea sunt pili multi.	If the leg is weak, and has many hairs on it.
Deinde intromitte ipsum in balneum: aut embroca ipsum in crure eius cum aqua calida, donec rubeat, et exuberentur Venae: aut exercitetur exercitio forti, si non est ei praesens balneum, donec calefiat membrum.	Then introduce it into the bath: or embrocate it on his leg with warm water until it reddens, and the veins swell: or exercise him vigorously, if there is no bath present, until the limb heats up.
Deinde seca cutem in directo uenae sectione per longitudinem: aut in ultimo eius apud genu, aut in inferiori parte eius apud calcaneum.	Then dry the skin in a direct vein incision lengthwise: or at its end near the knee, or in the lower part near the heel.
Deinde aperi cutem cum uncinis, et excoria uenam ab omni parte, donec appareat sensui: et est apud apparitionem eius, quod uides eam rubeam ad nigredinem decliuem.	Then open the skin with hooks, and excise the vein from every part until it appears to the sense: and at its appearance, you see it red to blackness sloping.
Cum ergo uadit ex cute, uides eam albam quasi sit chorda.	When it comes out of the skin, you see it white like a cord.
Deinde intromitte sub ea Radium, donec quando eleuatur et egreditur de cute: suspende eam cum uncino caeco, leni.	Then introduce under it a radium until when it is raised and comes out of the skin: suspend it with a hook, gently.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam prope illam sectionem tribus digitis.	Then make a dry incision near that incision with three fingers' width.
Deinde excoria cutem a superiori parte uenae, donec appareat.	Then scrape the skin from the upper part of the vein until it appears.
Deinde eleua eam cum Radiis sicut fecisti, et suspende eam cum uncino alio, sicut fecisti in primis.	Then raise it with Rays as you did before, and suspend it with another hook, as you did at first.
Deinde seca sectionem aliam, aut sectiones plures, si indiges illo.	Then make another dry incision, or several incisions, if you need them.
Deinde eleua, et incide ipsam ultima sectione apud calcaneum.	Then elevate and make an incision at its last section near the heel bone.
Deinde extrahe eam ad sectionem quae est supra eam.	Then draw it out to the section which is above it.
Et fac illud, donec extrahas eam ex sectione quae est superior, uel altior sectionibus omnibus, donec quando egreditur tota: tunc incide eam.	And do this until you have removed it from the incision which is higher, or all higher incisions, until when it emerges wholly; then cut into it.
Si autem non obedit tibi ad extrahendum, et eleuandum: tunc intromitte acum cum filo forti duplo, et liga eam, et extrahe ipsam: aut intromitte sub ea Radium: et reuolue manum tuam ad omnem partem, donec egrediatur.	If it does not obey you to extract and elevate it, then introduce a needle with a strong double thread, and tie it, and extract it; or introduce a probe under it, and revolve your hand to every part until it emerges.
Et caue, ne incidatur.	And beware, lest it be struck.
Nam si incidatur, fit difficile tibi eleuare eam ualde, et ingreditur super infirmum ex ea nocumentum.	For if it is cut, it will be difficult for you to remove it well, and it will enter into the weak place from it damage.
Cum ergo extraxeris eam totam: tunc pone super locum uulnerum lanam submersam in uino et oleo rosato, aut oleo: et cura ipsum, donec sanetur.	When therefore you have extracted it whole: then place upon the place of the wound wool dipped in wine and rose oil, or oil: and take care of it until it heals.
Quod si Vitis est contracta, habens tortuositatem cui sit inuolutio ad partes, et non est sicut diximus secundum rectitudinem: tunc oportet ut findas super eam ad omnem partem tortuositatis eius, et loca inuolutionis ipsius.	If the vein is contracted, having a winding shape whose convolution goes to parts, and is not as we said according to straightness; then it is necessary that you feel upon it on every part of its winding shape, and the places of its convolution.
Deinde suspende eam cum uncinis, donec eleues eam totam: et caue apud sectionem tuam super eam ne incidas uenam, aut uulneres: nam difficile fiet super te eleuare, uel extrahere eam.	Then suspend it with hooks until you have lifted the whole thing; and be careful at your incision upon it that you do not cut a vein or wound it, for it will be difficult to lift or extract it above you.
Conserua ergo prudentiam tuam.	Therefore, keep your prudence.
Forma Incidentis quo sanatur Vitis.	The Method of Cutting for the Healing of a Grapevine
Forma Vncini caeci.	The shape of a blind pouch.
Non est ei curuitas sicut reliquis Vncinis, neque est acutae extremitatis, ut non uulneret uenam: et est grossae flectuositatis, lenis: quoniam si esset subtilis, incideret uenam subtilitate sua: imo sit ei superflua grossitudo, sicut diximus.	There is no need for it to be as fine as the other needles, nor does it have a sharp point so that it does not wound a vein; and it is of thick flexibility, gentle: because if it were fine, it would wound a vein with its fineness; indeed let its thickness be superfluous, as we said.
De extractione Venae cruris.	On the Extraction of the Vein of the Thigh.
Caput XCIII.	Chapter XCI.
Haec Vena generatur in cruribus in terris calidis, sicut Alizegi, et terra Arabum, et in terris aridis, calidis, paucae teneritatis, id est, in quibus non nascitur herba, neque arbor.	This vein is generated in the legs in hot lands, such as those of Alizegi and Arabia, and in dry, hot lands with little tenderness, that is, in which neither grass nor tree grows.
Et fortasse generatur in locis aliis corporis praeter crura.	And perhaps it is generated in other places of the body besides the legs.
Et generatio quidem eius est a putrefactione quae accidit sub cute, sicut accidunt intra corpora serpentes et uermes ascarides, et uermes generati inter cutem et carnem.	And its generation is indeed from putrefaction that happens under the skin, just as it happens within bodies of snakes and worms ascarides, and worms generated between the skin and flesh.
Et signum incaeptionis euentus huius Venae est, quod accidit in crure inflammatio uehemens.	And the sign of the beginning of this Vein's incision is that a fierce inflammation happens in the leg.
Deinde uesicatur locus.	Then it is cauterized.
Deinde incipit Vena exire ex loco illius uesicationis, quasi sit radix plantae, aut animal.	Then begins the vein to exit from the place of that urination, as if it were the root of a plant, or an animal.
Cum ergo apparet ex ea extremitas eius, tunc oportet ut inuoluas super ipsam frustum plumbi, cuius pondus sit ex drachma keil, usque ad drachmas II et noda ipsam: et dimitte plumbum suspensum ex crure.	When therefore the extremity of it appears, then it is necessary that you wrap upon itself a lead piece, whose weight be from one drachma to two drachmas and tie it; and let go the suspended lead from the leg.
Quotiens ergo egreditur ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, inuolue illud in plumbo, et noda illud.	Whenever therefore anything comes out of it to the outside, wrap it in lead and tie it.
Quod si prolongatur multum, tunc incide partem eius, et inuolue residuum.	If it is prolonged for a long time, then cut part of it, and wrap up the rest.
Et non incidas eam radicitus antequam egrediatur tota.	And do not cut it root and branch before it has come out entirely.
Quoniam si incidis, contrahitur, et ingreditur in carnem: et facit accidere apostema, et putredinem in loco, et ulcus malum.	For if it cuts, it contracts and enters into flesh; and it causes an abscess to happen, and rot in the place, and a bad ulcer.
Quapropter oportet, ut suauiter tractetur, et extrahatur paulatim, donec egrediatur ex ultimo sui, et non remaneat ex ea aliquid in corpore: et ex hac quidem Vena egreditur in quibusdam hominibus quod est in longitudine sua quinque palmorum et decem.	Therefore it is necessary that it be treated gently and extracted gradually until it emerges from its last part, and nothing of it remains in the body: and from this vein some men emerge which is in length five palms and ten.
Et iam peruenit ad me, quia exiuit uiro ex XX palmis.	And now it has come to me, because a man has emerged from twenty palms.
Si autem inciditur tibi in hora medicationis tuae: tunc intromitte radium in foramine eius, et perfora eam foramine longo, cum corpore, donec euacuetur totum quod est in ea ex materia: et administra putrefactionem loci cum medicinis diebus aliquot.	If you encounter this during your medical treatment: then insert a reed into its hole and pierce it with a long hole together with the body until all that is within it of matter is evacuated, and administer corruption to the place with medicines for several days.
Deinde cura ipsum curatione apostematum.	Then care for the treatment of abscesses.
Et haec quidem Vena quandoque habet ramos multos, praecipue quando apparet in iunctura pedis, aut in pede ipso: et accidunt ei orificia multa, et egreditur ex omni orificio ramus.	And this vein sometimes has many branches, especially when it appears at the joint of the foot, or in the foot itself; and it happens to have many openings, and a branch emerges from every opening.
Cura ergo ipsam, sicut diximus in diuisione, et cum eo quod praemissum est.	Therefore, care for it, as we said in the division, and with what was previously stated.
¶ De sectione super Vermes generatos sub cute, et dicitur Aegritudo bouina.	On the incision over worms generated under the skin, and it is called the illness of a bull.
Caput XCIIII.	Chapter XCI.
Haec Aegritudo nominatur in quadam terra apud nos Aegritudo bouina: propterea, quia multotiens accidit bouibus, et est uermis paruus unus, qui nascitur inter cutem et carnem.	This illness is called among us in a certain land "bull's sickness," because it happens very often to oxen, and there is a small worm that is born between the skin and the flesh.
Et uadit in corpore toto, ascendendo et descendendo: et ostenditur sensui apud ambulationem eius de membro ad membrum, donec disrumpit ubicumque disrumpit in cute locum, et egreditur.	And it goes through the whole body, ascending and descending; and it is shown to the sense in its movement from limb to limb, until it ruptures wherever it ruptures in the skin, and exits.
Et generatio eius est ex putredine quorundam humorum.	And its generation is from the rot of some humors.
Sicut accidunt uermes et serpentes, id est, lumbrici, et ascarides in uentre.	As worms and serpents, that is, roundworms and pinworms, happen in the belly.
Et timetur ex malicia eius.	And it is feared from its malice.
Quia quando ipse uadit in corpore, et eleuatur ad caput, et peruenit ad locum: tunc fortasse aperit in eo, et egreditur, et destruit oculum: et accidit illud multotiens.	Because when he enters the body and is raised to the head and comes to the place: then perhaps he opens it and emerges and destroys the eye: and this happens often.
Cum ergo uis curare eum, et extrahere ipsum, tunc non fit illud nisi apud ambulationem eius, et apparitionem ipsius sensui.	Therefore, when you wish to cure him and extract it, then this is done only when he walks about and appears to his senses.
Oportet ergo, ut stringas quod est supra eum, et quod est sub eo cum ligamento constrictione forti.	Therefore, you must bind that which is above it and that which is below it with a strong constricting band.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry over it, and take it out.
Quod si profundatur in carne, et non inuenis ipsum: tunc pone super locum cauterium cum igne, donec moriatur.	If it goes deep into the flesh and you do not find it, then place a cautery with fire over the spot until it dies.
Et maius quod timetur, est corruptio eius, qua corrumpit oculum, sicut diximus.	And the greater thing to be feared is its corruption, which corrupts the eye, as we have said.
Si autem uides eum iam peruenisse in capite prope oculum, tunc stringe sub eo supercilium strictura bona.	If you see him having arrived near the eye on the head, then tighten under it a good constriction of the eyebrow.
Deinde seca super ipsum, et extrahe eum.	Then dry him over and remove him.
Et oportet ut utatur infirmus mundificatione sui corporis, cum medicinis soluentibus humores putridos malos.	And it is necessary that the sick person use the purification of his body, with medicines dissolving the bad, putrid humors.
Et caueat sibi a cibis generantibus putrefactionem.	And let him beware of foods that generate putrefaction.
¶ De sectione super aegritudinem Nakir.	On incision for disease according to Nakir.
Caput XCV.	Chapter XC.
Haec aegritudo nominatur in terra nostra Nakir: et est dolor qui accidit in quibusdam membris: deinde permutatur de membro ad membrum.	This ailment is called Nakir in our land: and it is pain which occurs in certain limbs: then it changes from limb to limb.
Et ego quidem iam uidi ipsum, secundum quod narro tibi.	And I indeed have already seen him, as I tell you.
Vocatus sum ad mulierem infirmam in quibusdam uillis.	I was summoned to a weak woman with some wounds.
Et detexit brachium suum, et uidi inflationem paruam in uena funis brachii.	And he exposed his arm, and I saw a small swelling in the vein of the arm's cord.
Et postquam remansi hora una, uidi unam inflationem incedere cum focili, sicut incedit uermis, ascendendo ad humerum eius uelocius quam esse potest: ut sit sicut argentum uiuum, quando currit de loco ad locum.	And after I waited one hour, I saw one inflation moving with a finger, like a worm, ascending to his shoulder faster than it could: like live silver, when it runs from place to place.
Recessit ergo dolor ex illo loco, et fixus est in humero.	Therefore pain went from that place and settled in the shoulder.
Deinde sedi hora una, et cucurrit in reliquum corpus, donec perueniret in brachium aliud.	Then he sat for an hour, and it ran throughout the rest of his body until it reached the other arm.
Deinde narrauit mihi, quia reuoluebatur in toto corpore suo, secundum quod uidi.	Then he told me that he was turning over his whole body, as I saw.
Miratus sum ergo de uelocitate permutationis eius de membro ad membrum.	I was amazed at the speed of its transfer from one member to another.
Et ego quidem ante illud non uideram hanc aegritudinem oculis meis taliter secundum hunc modum.	And I indeed before this had not seen this sickness with my eyes in this way according to this manner.
Verumtamen uidi multos, qui inueniunt dolorem permutari de membro ad membrum: et non uidi ipsum oculis, sicut uidi eum in muliere.	However, I have seen many who find pain to change from one limb to another; and I did not see it with my eyes, as I saw it in a woman.
Et ego non cogito illud esse, nisi quod est propterea, quod mulier fuit ex illis qui sunt ex uillis sicci corporis detectarum uenarum: hinc ergo apparet sensui illa uentositas permutata.	And I do not think that this is otherwise, because the woman was from those who have veins of dry body tissue exposed; hence, it appears to the sense that lightness has been changed.
Et est necesse, ut non appareant secundum hanc rationem in illis qui sunt deliciosi, et corporibus humidis, occultarum uenarum.	And it is necessary that they not appear according to this reason in those who are delicate and with moist bodies, of hidden veins.
Cum ergo uis curationem eius, et sentit patiens illud dolorem: tunc si est apparens tibi oculo, sicut diximus, tunc stringe supra ipsum, et sub ipso uelociter: et seca supra ipsum, donec egrediatur illa uentositas coartata: et cauteriza locum.	When therefore you wish to cure it, and the patient feels this pain; then if it appears to your eye, as we have said, then tightly bind above it, and below it quickly: and dry above it until that windiness is expelled constrainedly: and cauterize the place.
Si autem non uides ipsum oculis tuis: tunc cura ipsum cum excussione corporis, et cum eo quod expellit uentositates, et carminat eas cum pillulis foetidis, et pillulis de serapino, et similibus.	If you do not see it with your own eyes, then treat it with a scraping of the body and with that which expels winds, and carminates them with foul pills, and pills from serpentaria, and similar ones.
¶ De extractione Sagittarum.	On the extraction of arrows.
Caput XCVI.	Chapter XCVI.
Sagittae diuersificantur secundum species suas, et secundum loca in quibus cadunt ex corpore.	Arrows are diversified according to their kinds and according to the places in which they fall from the body.
Earum uero diuersitas est: quoniam ex eis sunt quae habent cuspides magnos, et paruos: et concauae, et surdae.	Their diversity is: because among them are those that have large points, and small: and concave, and deaf.
Et ex eis sunt quae habent tres angulos.	And there are those which have three angles.
Et ex eis quibus sunt linguae.	And from those who have tongues.
Et ex eis quibus sunt astellae.	And from those which have stars.
Illae uero quae sunt secundum membra in quibus cadunt, est secundum duos modos.	Those which are according to the limbs in which they fall, are according to two ways.
Aut enim membra sunt ex membris principalibus concauis, sicut cerebrum, et cor, et epar, et pulmo, et renes, et intestina, et uesica, et eis similia.	Or else the limbs are from the principal members concave, such as the brain, and the heart, and liver, and lung, and kidneys, and intestines, and bladder, and the like.
Quando ergo cadit in aliquo horum membrorum, et apparent tibi signa mortis, quae ego narro tibi post, tunc oportet ut deuites extractionem illius sagittae ex eis, nam mors consequitur illum in quo est, in pluribus dispositionibus.	When therefore it falls into any of these members, and the signs of death appear to you which I tell you after, then it is necessary that you avoid the extraction of that arrow from them, for death follows him in whom it is, in many dispositions.
Et quando non apparent tibi ista signa mala, et sagitta non est absconsa in profunditate membri, tunc extrahe ipsam, et cura uulnus.	And when these signs of evil do not appear to you, and the arrow is not hidden in the depth of the limb, then draw it out, and take care of the wound.
Ex signis enim cerebri quando cadit in eo sagitta, et penetrat os, et egreditur siphac quod est super cerebrum, est: quoniam accidunt ex illo soda uehemens, et scotomia, et uertigo, et rubedo in oculis, et inflatio, et rubedo linguae, et spasmus, et permixtio intellectus, et uomitus cholerae.	When an arrow falls into the brain and penetrates the skull and emerges from the part above the brain, the signs are: because there occurs from it violent frothing, and scotoma, and vertigo, and redness in the eyes, and inflation, and redness of the tongue, and spasm, and confusion of the intellect, and vomiting of bile.
Et fortasse egreditur sanguis ex naribus, aut auribus.	And perhaps blood may issue from the nose, or ears.
Et fortasse abscinditur sermo, et destruitur uox.	And perhaps speech is cut off, and the voice is destroyed.
Et egreditur ex loco uulneris humiditas alba similis pulti.	And there comes forth from the place of the wound a white moisture like gruel.
Et exit ex eo simile aquositati carnis.	And it comes out from there like a watery fleshiness.
Si ergo apparent tibi ista signa, tunc abstine a curatione, et extrahe sagittam si non egreditur.	If therefore these signs appear to you, then abstain from treatment, and remove the arrow if it does not exit.
Signa autem sagittae quando cadit in corde, sunt: quod ipsa est prope mammillam sinistram: et sentit cum ea quasi ipsa sit fixa in re dura, non in re uacua.	The signs of an arrow when it falls into the heart are: that it is near the left nipple: and he feels as if it were fixed in a hard thing, not in an empty thing.
Et fortasse sagittae est motus similis motui pulsus: et currit ex uulnere sanguis niger.	And perhaps the movement of an arrow is similar to the movement of a pulse; and blood runs from the wound black.
Et sequitur illud frigus extremitatum, et sudor frigidus, et syncopis.	And following this comes coldness of the extremities and cold sweat and fainting spells.
Scias ergo, quod mors descendit procul dubio.	Know therefore that death certainly comes.
Et signum sagittae quando uulnerat pulmonem, est exitus sanguinis spumosi ex uulnere: et uasa quae sequuntur collum, apostematur, et mutatur color infirmi.	And the sign of an arrow wound to the lung is the exit of frothy blood from the wound; and the vessels that follow the neck suppurate, and the color of the sick man changes.
Et expirat spiritum magnum, altum: et quaerit attractionem aeris frigidi.	And he exhales great, high spirit: and seeks the attraction of cold air.
Quod si cadat sagitta in uelamen, quod est in pectore: tunc est prope costas paruas: et fit anhelitus magnus cum dolore uehementi, cum suspirio: et mouentur omnia membra humerorum.	If an arrow falls into the membrane that is in the chest: then it is near the ribs: and a great gasp with intense pain, with a sigh: and all the members of the shoulders move.
Et si cadat sagitta in stomachum, tunc fortasse egreditur ex uulnere ex cibo aliquid indigestum.	And if an arrow falls into the stomach, then perhaps something indigested will exit from the wound along with food.
Et si cadit sagitta in Ventrem, et figitur in eo: egreditur aliquid stercoris ex uulnere, aut zirbum, aut intestinum quod iam disruptum est.	And if an arrow falls into the belly and lodges in it, something of feces comes out from the wound, or a piece of intestine which is already torn.
Non est ergo spes in curatione eius, neque in extractione sagittae.	Therefore there is no hope of healing it, nor of extracting the arrow.
Quod si sagitta cadat in Vesicam, et egrediatur urina: et procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora, et fortior sit dolor super infirmum: tunc scias, quia est mortale.	If an arrow falls into the bladder and urine flows out, and something proceeds from it to the outside, and the pain is stronger over the patient: then you shall know that it is mortal.
Reliqua autem membra, sicut facies, et collum, et guttur, et spatula, et adiutorium, et spondiles dorsi, et furcula, et coxa, et crus, et eis similia ex membris saluantur secundum plures dispositiones: quando non inuenit sagitta arteriam, aut neruum: et non est sagitta uenenosa.	The remaining members, such as the face, and neck, and throat, and spatula, and auxiliary tool, and dorsal vertebrae, and collarbone, and hip, and leg, and things similar to these members are healed according to various arrangements: when it does not find the artery, or nerve: and is not a poisonous arrow.
Et ego narro tibi quod uidi de esse harum sagittarum, ut significes per illud super curationem tuam.	And I tell you what I have seen of these arrows, so that you may understand through this about your treatment.
Quod est, quia cuidam uiro cecidit sagitta in lachrymali oculi eius, in radice nasi.	That is because to a certain man an arrow fell into the lacrimal gland of his eye, at the root of his nose.
Extraxi ergo eam ipsi ex parte altera, sub adipe auris eius: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei in oculo eius nocumentum.	Therefore I extracted it from the other side, under the fat of his ear: and he was healed, and no harm came to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam Iudaeo, quae cecidit ei in adipe oculi sui sub palpebra inferiori: et sagitta iam occultata erat, et non consecutus sum ex ea nisi extremitatem paruam eius, cum qua adhaeret in ligno suo: et erat sagitta magna ex sagittis arcuum Turcorum, cum ferro leni, in qua non sunt aures.	And I extracted another arrow from a Jew, which had fallen into the fat of his eye under his lower eyelid: and the arrow was already hidden, and I did not extract it except for its small extremity, with which it adheres to its shaft: and the arrow was large of the arrows of the Turkish bows, with gentle iron, in which there are no ears.
Sanatus est ergo Iudaeus, et non accidit in oculo eius accidens malum.	The Jew was therefore healed, and no evil accident happened to his eye.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam ex gutture Christiani.	And I extracted another arrow from the throat of a Christian.
Et erat sagitta arabica, et est illa cui sunt aures.	And there was an Arabian arrow, and it is that which has ears.
Secui ergo super ipsam inter duas guidegi: et iam submersa erat in gutture eius.	I therefore followed it between two guides; and now it was submerged in his throat.
Subtiliatus sum ergo cum ea, donec extraxi eam: et sanatus est Christianus.	Therefore I worked skillfully with it until I extracted it: and Christian was healed.
Et extraxi sagittam aliam uiro quae ceciderat in uentre eius: et cogitauimus, quia moreretur ex ea.	And I removed another arrow from a man who had fallen into his belly: and we thought that he would die from it.
Postquam ergo praeterierunt ei triginta dies, et non mutatum est super eum aliquid ex dispositionibus eius, secui super sagittam: et ingeniaui super eam, et extraxi eam: et sanatus est, et non accidit ei accidens malum.	After thirty days had passed and nothing had changed in his condition, I cut along the shaft of the arrow: and I fashioned it, and extracted it: and he was healed, and no evil happened to him.
Et uidi uirum cui cecidit sagitta in dorso eius, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam.	And I saw a man to whom an arrow fell on his back, and the wound had become solid over it.
Postquam ergo fuit post septem annos, exiuit sagitta in radice coxae eius.	After seven years, a shaft emerged from the root of his hip.
Et uidi mulierem cui cecidit in uentre suo sagitta, et consolidatum est uulnus super eam, et remansit sagitta intra ipsam: et non mutata est ex dispositionibus eius aliqua, et mulier non inuenit ei nocumentum in aliqua ex operationibus suis naturalibus.	And I saw a woman to whom an arrow fell into her belly, and the wound was consolidated over her, and the arrow remained inside her: and nothing was changed from her dispositions, and the woman did not find harm to her in any of her natural operations.
Et uidi uirum alium, cui cecidit sagitta in facie sua: et consolidatum est uulnus, et remansit, non inueniens ei multum dolorem: et similia istis multa.	And I saw another man, to whom an arrow fell upon his face: and the wound was consolidated, and remained, not finding much pain in him: and similar things like these many.
Et extraxi sagittam uiro ex principibus Regis, quae ceciderat ei in medio nasi sui, et iam declinauerat ad partem dextram parumper: et occultata erat sagitta tota.	And I extracted an arrow from a man of the King's princes, which had fallen into the middle of his nose, and had already declined to the right side a little: and the arrow was completely hidden.
Vocatus sum ergo ad curationem eius post casum sagittae usque ad tres dies.	Therefore I was called to his cure after the arrow wound for three days.
Inueni ergo uulnus sagittae strictum ualde.	I therefore found a wound from an arrow quite constricted.
Inquisiui ergo eam cum tenta subtili, et non sensi eam: et ipse quidem inueniebat punctionem et dolorem sub aure sua ex parte dextra.	Therefore I examined it with a fine probe and did not feel it; and he himself was finding a prickling and pain under his ear on the right side.
Speraui ergo, quod erat illa punctio ex extremitate sagittae.	Therefore I supposed that the prick was from the point of the arrow.
Emplastraui ergo locum cum emplastro in quo erat uirtus attractiua, et digestiua, confidens apud me, quod apostemaretur locus, et appareret mihi signum sagittae, ut secarem super eam: et non accidit in loco accidens significans quod sagitta consecuta sit locum.	Therefore I placed a plaster on the spot with a plaster which had the power of attraction and digestion, trusting that the place would fester and that a sign like an arrow would appear to me so that I could cut above it: but nothing happened in the spot that indicated that the arrow had followed the place.
Assiduaui ergo cum emplastro super eum diebus multis: et non accidit accidens, et consolidatum est uulnus interim: et remansit infirmus de extractione eius spacio dierum, donec sensit sagittam die quodam intra nasum suum.	Therefore I diligently applied a poultice to it for many days; and no accident occurred, and the wound was consolidated in the meantime; and he remained weak from its extraction for a space of days until he felt the arrow one day inside his nose.
Et narrauit mihi illud.	And he told me this.
Posui ergo super illud uulnus medicinam acutam, corrosiuam diebus multis, donec apertum est: et cum tenta tentaui ipsum, et sensi extremitatem sagittae subtilem quae adhaeret in ligno.	Therefore I placed on the wound medicine acute and corrosive for many days until it opened; and when I probed it and felt the subtle point of the arrow adhering to the wood.
Deinde addidi in apertione uulneris per illam medicinam acutam, donec apparuit nobis uisibiliter extremitas sagittae: et praeteriit mihi cum eo spacium temporis circiter quatuor menses.	Then I added to the opening of the wound with that acute medicine until the tip of the arrow appeared visibly to us; and about four months elapsed with him in that time.
Deinde postquam amplificatum est uulnus, et possible fuit mihi intromittere forcipes in ipsam, et mouere ipsam, et non obediuit ad exitum: tunc non cessaui subtiliare, et ingeniare super eam cum modis ingeniorum, donec coepi super eam die quodam cum forcipibus decenter factis, secundum quod ueniet forma eorum in fine capituli, donec extraxi eam.	Then after the wound was enlarged, and it was possible for me to insert forceps into it, and move it, and it did not obey to exit: then I did not cease to be subtle, and to devise over it with modes of ingenuity, until I began upon a certain day with forceps made properly, according to what will come in the form of them at the end of the chapter, until I extracted it.
Deinde restauraui uulnus.	Then I restored the wound.
Et medici quidem iudicant, quod cartilago nasi non restauratur.	And indeed doctors judge that cartilage of the nose is not restored.
Restauraui ergo ipsam, et consolidatum est uulnus, et sanatus est infirmas sanitate integra: nec nocuit ei aliquid omnino.	Therefore, I restored it, and the wound was consolidated, and the infirm person was healed in perfect health: and nothing harmed him at all.
Et ego narro tibi qualitatem extractionis quarundam sagittarum: ut ponas illud regulam et significationem super illud quod non dixi.	And I tell you the quality of the extraction of certain arrows: so that you may place that rule and meaning over what I did not say.
Quoniam partes huius artis et distinctiones earum non comprehenduntur cum narratione: neque comprehendit illud liber, et artifex prudens comparat cum pauco super multum: et cum eo quod est paesens, super illud quod est absens: et inuenit operationem nouam, et instrumentum nouum apud descensus rerum extranearum huius artis quando accidunt.	Since the parts of this art and their distinctions are not grasped with the narration; nor does it encompass that book, and a wise craftsman compares little to much; and what is present to what is absent; and finds a new operation, and a new instrument among the descents of foreign things of this art when they occur.
Dico ergo, quod sagittae non egrediuntur ex membris quibus sunt fixae, nisi secundum duos modos.	Therefore I say that arrows do not come out of limbs in which they are fixed, except according to two modes.
Aut per attractionem ex loco ex quo intrauit.	Either by drawing it out from where it entered.
Aut contrario partis alterius.	Or on the contrary, the other part.
Et illa quae egreditur unde intrauit, aut est sagitta procedens in loco carnoso: et attrahitur, et egreditur.	And that which comes out from where it entered, or is an arrow proceeding in fleshy place: and it is drawn out, and it comes out.
Quod si non obedit ad exitum ex hora in qua cadit: tunc oportet ut dimittas ipsam aliquot diebus, donec putrefiat caro quae est in circumitu eius: et alleuietur attractio eius, et eius egressio.	If it does not yield to removal by the hour in which it falls: then it is necessary that you dismiss it for several days, until the flesh that is around it rots: and the attraction of it is relieved, and its exit.
Et similiter si figitur in osse, et non obedit tibi ad exitum, tunc dimitte ipsam etiam aliquot diebus: et itera eam cum attractione et motione omni die, donec egreditur.	And similarly if it becomes lodged in the bone, and does not obey you to come out, then leave it also for several days: and repeat it with traction and movement every day until it comes out.
Quod si non obedit tibi ad exitum post dies, tunc oportet ut perfores in circumitu sagittae in ipso osse ab omni parte cum terebro subtili, donec amplificentur sagittae.	If it does not obey you to the end after days, then you ought to pierce it around the arrow shaft in the bone itself from every part with a fine awl until the arrows are enlarged.
Deinde attrahe eam, et extrahe ipsam.	Then draw it out and remove it.
Si autem sagitta est fixa in capitis osse, et iam processit in uno uentrium cerebri, et apparent ex infirmo quaedam illorum accidentium quae dixi: tunc abstine ab attractione sagittae, et dimitte eam, donec aequetur esse eius post dies.	If however the arrow is fixed in the bone of the head, and has already progressed into one part of the brain's ventricle, and some of those accidents which I have said appear from the sick man, then abstain from drawing out the arrow, and let it go, until it may be equal to be removed after days.
Nam si sagitta peruenit ad sifach, tunc mors non prolongatur ei.	For if an arrow reaches the lung, then death does not delay for him.
Et si sagitta non est fixa, nisi in corpore ossis tantum, et non penetrat usque ad sifach: et remanet infirmus aliquot diebus, et non accidit ei ex illis accidentibus aliquid: tunc ingenia in attractione sagittae et extractione eius.	And if the arrow is not fixed, only in the bone, and does not penetrate to the fascia, and remains weak for several days, and nothing happens to him from those accidents; then the ingenuity is in drawing out the arrow and extracting it.
Si autem est fixa ualde, et non obedit tibi ad attractionem: tunc administra terebella in circumitu sagittae, sicut narraui tibl: deinde cura locum, donec sanetur.	If, however, it is firmly fixed and does not obey you when you try to pull it out: then administer a trepanation around the arrowhead, as I have told you before. Then take care of the place until it heals.
Si autem Sagitta iam absconsa est in loco corporis, et occultatur et absconditur a sensu: tunc inquire eam cum tenta.	If now the arrow is hidden in the place of the body and is concealed and hidden from sense, then seek it out with your touch.
Si autem sentis eam, tunc attrahe eam cum quibusdam instrumentis quae conueniunt attractioni eius.	If you feel it, then draw it out with certain instruments which are suitable for its removal.
Si autem non potes super eam, propter constrictionem uulneris, et propter longitudinem sagittae in profundo: et non est illic os, neque neruus, neque uena: tunc finde super eam, donec amplificetur uulnus, et sit possibile extrahere sagittam.	If you cannot, however, because of the constriction of the wound and because of the length of the arrow deep within: and there is no bone, nor nerve, nor vein there: then find upon it, until the wound becomes enlarged, and it is possible to extract the arrow.
Quod si sunt ei aures quibus teneatur, tunc libera carnem fixam in eis ab omni parte, omni ingenio quo potes illud, et ingenia, si non potest super euasionem carnis in fractura aurium, et contorsione earum, donec euadat.	If he has ears that are held fast, then free the flesh fixed in them from every part, with all your skill as you can, and the skills, if it is not possible above the evasion of flesh in a fracture of the ears, and their twisting, until it comes out.
Et tu quando administras extractionem Sagittae, in quocumque loco est, tunc utere contorsione manus tuae, cum forficibus ad partes omnes, donec facias eam euadere: et subtilia ultima subtilitate, ut non frangatur Sagita, et fiat difficilis tibi attractio eius, et ipsius extractio.	And when you administer the extraction of a arrow, wherever it is, then use the twisting of your hand, with forceps to all parts, until you cause it to emerge: and with the utmost subtlety, so that the arrow does not break, and it be difficult for you its attraction, and its extraction.
Quod si non potes super eam ex hora una, tunc dimitte eam diebus aliquot, donec putrefiant quae sunt in circumitu eius.	If you cannot remove it within one hour, then leave it for several days until what is around it has decayed.
Deinde itera eam: alleuietur enim tuncia Si uero contrarietatem tibi facit fluxus sanguinis, tunc administra quod diximus ex curatione in capitulo suo: et custodi uirtutem tuam ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, aut chordae.	Then repeat the process: for if blood flow is loosened, and if it opposes you, then administer what we said from the cure in its chapter: and keep your strength from cutting a vein, or nerve, or tendon.
Et administra ingenium omni modo quo tibi possibile est euasionis Sagittae: et sit illud cum facilitate, et tranquillitate, uel tarditate, et firmitate, sicut narraui tibi.	And administer the skill in every way you can of the evacuation of the arrow, and let it be with ease, and tranquility, or slowness, and firmness, just as I have told you.
Et oportet, ut facias cum trahis Sagittam, ut infirmus sit secundum figuram, secundum quam fuit apud casum Sagittae in ipso.	And it is necessary that you do when drawing an arrow, that it be weak according to the figure, according to how it was with the case of the arrow itself.
Quoniam est magis iuuatiuum.	Because it is more helpful.
Si autem non est tibi possibile illud, tunc administra quod tibi est possibile ex figuris.	If that is not possible for you, then administer what is possible for you from the figures.
Sagitta autem quae egreditur ex contrario partis alterius, aut iam procedit ex ea aliquid ad exteriora: aut facit gibbositatem extremitas Sagittae per sensum ex superiore parte cutis propinquae, et uides eam eminentem: seca ergo super eam, et sit sectio secundum quantitatem quod capiant in ea forcipes.	The arrow which comes out from the opposite part of another, or has already come out from it to the exterior; or makes a swelling at the extremity of the arrow by feeling from the upper part of the skin close by, and you see it protruding: therefore dry it carefully on it, and let the section be according to the quantity which they grasp in it with forceps.
Deinde attrahe eam: ipsa namque fit facilis ad exitum.	Then draw it out; for indeed it becomes easy to be drawn out.
Si uero retinetur in osse, tunc torque manum tuam secundum rotunditatem, donec imprimat Sagitta in osse, et amplificet sibiipsi: deinde trahe ipsam.	If it is held in the bone, then twist your hand according to the roundness, until the arrow imprints itself in the bone and amplifies itself; then draw it out.
Et si non: dimitte eam diebus aliquot: deinde itera eam, donec egrediatur.	And if not: let her be left for a few days; then repeat it until she comes out.
Quod si lignum Sagittae est in ea, tunc impelle ipsam cum eo.	If a piece of wood from an arrow is in it, then drive that out with it.
Si autem cecidit lignum, et uis administrare impulsionem: tunc intromitte ad eam instrumentum concauum, ut ingrediatur concauitas eius in caudam Sagittae: deinde impelle eam cum ipso.	If a stick has fallen and you wish to administer an impulse: then introduce an instrument with a concave shape into it so that the cavity of the instrument enters the tail of the arrow, then drive it in with the same force.
Si autem Sagita est concaua, tunc impelle eam cum instrumento intrante in ipsam.	If, however, the arrow is concave, then drive it in with an instrument going into it.
Sagitta enim alleuiatur per illud.	For the arrow is lifted up by that.
Quod si Sagitta est toxicata, tunc oportet, ut concaues carnem totam, in qua est uenenum: si est tibi possibile illud.	If the arrow is poisoned, then it is necessary to cut out all the flesh in which the poison is: if it is possible for you to do that.
Deinde cura eam cum eo quod conuenit ad illud.	Then care for it as is fitting for that.
Quod si Sagitta est cadens in pectore, aut in uentre, aut in uesica, aut in latere: et est propinqua ex eo quod tangis cum tenta, et possibile est tibi secare super eam: tunc seca, et caue ab incisione uenae, aut nerui, et extrahe eam.	If the arrow is falling into the chest, or belly, or bladder, or side: and it is near because you touch it with your finger, and it is possible for you to cut above it: then cut, and beware of incision of vein, or nerve, and draw it out.
