Deinde sue uulnus, si uides, et cura illud, donec sanetur.	Then treat the wound if you see it, and care for it until it heals.
Et haec est forma Forcipum, quibus extrahuntur Sagittae.	And this is the form of forceps, with which arrows are extracted.
Sint extremitates similes rostro auis, quae factae sunt sicut ferra: quando capiunt super Sagittam, non dimittunt eam.	Let the extremities be like the beak of a bird, which have been made like iron: when they grasp a shaft, they do not let it go.
Et fiunt ex eis species multae, magnae, et paruae, et mediae, secundum quantitatem magnitudinis Sagittae, et paruitatis eius, et amplitudinis uulneris, et constrictionis eius.	And many kinds are made from these, large and small and medium, according to the quantity of the magnitude of the arrow, and its smallness, and the wideness of the wound, and its constriction.
Forma Impellentis concaui.	Shape of the Concave Impelling Tool.
Et forma Impellentis surdi.	And the form of the Impeller for the deaf.
Hoc est surdae extremitatis sicut Radius, ut alleuietur introitus eius in sagittam concauam, et impellatur cum eo.	This is for the deaf extremity like the radius, so that its entrance may be relieved into a concave arrow and it may be driven with it.
Huius extremitas impellentis concauae est concaua sicut penna auis: ut alleuietur introitus sagittae in ipsam et impulsio eius.	The extremity of this instrument is concave like a bird's feather so that the entrance of the arrow into it and its impulse may be eased.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum.	On the incision of veins.
Caput XCVII.	Chapter XC VII.
Uenae phlebotomandae, quarum cucurrit consuetudo in corpore, sunt triginta.	There are thirty veins that are commonly bled from in the body.
Ex quibus in capite sunt sexdecim: duae Venae pulsatiles, quae sunt post aures, dictae duae Herbae: et duae Arteriae, quae sunt in duobus timporibus apparentes: et duae Venae quae sunt in duobus lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, quae dicuntur Aspicientes: et Vena praeparata in medio frontis: et uena quae est in extremitate nasi.	Of these, there are sixteen in the head: two pulsating veins, which are behind the ears, called Herbae; and two arteries, which are apparent in both temples; and two veins which are in the two lacrimals of the two eyes, which are called Aspicientes; and a prepared vein in the middle of the forehead; and a vein which is at the extremity of the nose.
Et duae Guidegi, quae sunt in collo.	And two guidegis, which are in the neck.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio superiore oris.	And two veins that are in the upper lip of the mouth.
Et duae uenae quae sunt in labio inferiore.	And two veins that are in the lower lip.
Et istae sunt uenae quae dicuntur Algecherich.	And these are the veins which are called Algecherich.
Et duae uenae quae sunt sub lingua.	And the two veins that are under the tongue.
Venae autem quae phlebotomantur in brachiis, sunt quinque uenae in omni brachio.	The veins which are opened in the arms are five veins in each arm.
Vna earum est Cephalica, et est ex latere syluestri: et nominat eam uulgus uenam capitis.	One of these is the Cephalic vein, and it is from the side of the neck; and the common people call it the vein of the head.
Et Fusca.	And Black.
Et est Media uena, et est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae: et nominat eam uulgus uenam corporis.	And it is the Middle vein, and it is composed of the Basilica branch and the Cephalic branch; and the common people call it the vein of the body.
Et Basilica, et est posita in latere domestico: et nominatur etiam Titillicaris.	And Basilica, and it is placed in the domestic side: and it is also called Titillicaris.
Et nominat eam uulgus uenam uentris.	And the common people call it a vein of the abdomen.
Et Funis brachii, et est posita super focile: et est illa in qua phlebotomatur, et est illa quae apparet supra pollicem appatitione manifesta.	And the string of the arm is placed upon a board: and that is the one in which bloodletting is performed, and that which appears above the thumb by incision obvious.
Et Saluatella: et est uena quae est inter annularem et minimum: et sunt ei duo rami.	And Saluatella: and there is a vein which is between the annular and the smallest: and it has two branches.
Et in crure et in pede sunt tres uenae.	And in the leg and in the foot there are three veins.
Vna earum est quae est sub pollicis curuatura ex latere syluestri.	One of them is that which is under the curvature of the thumb from the inside side.
Et secunda est Saphena: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere domestico.	And the second is Saphena: and its place is at the heel from the inner side.
Et uena Nesse: et locus eius est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	And vein of Nesse: and its place is by the heel bone from the side of the inside.
Et in crure alio sunt tres uenae similes illis.	And in the other leg there are three veins similar to those.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum uenarum post Aures.	On bloodletting of two veins after the ears.
Phlebotomiae uero duarum uenarum quae sunt post Aures, iuuamentum est ad catarros antiquos, et hemigraneam, et sahafati, et ulcera capitis mala antiqua.	The cutting of two veins which are behind the ears is a help for old catarrhs, and headaches, and wounds in the head, and ulcers of the head, ancient evils.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eam est secundum quod narro.	And the quality of the phlebotomy is as I have told you.
Et est, ut radatur caput infirmi: et fricetur occipitium eius in loco duarum uenarum cum panno aspero fricatione bona.	And it is, as the head of the sick person be shaved: and the occiput of him be rubbed in the place of two veins with a rough cloth with good friction.
Deinde stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareant duae uenae.	Then the sick person should tighten their neck with a cloth until two veins appear.
Et loca earum sunt post Aures in duobus locis depressis capitis.	And their locations are behind the ears in two depressed places of the head.
Quaere ergo eas digito tuo, et ubi sentis pulsum earum sub digito tuo, illic signa cum encaustro.	Therefore, seek them out with your finger, and where you feel their pulse under your finger, mark there with sealing wax.
Deinde accipe phlebotomum cultellarem, et est ille qui dicitur Incidens.	Then take a surgical knife, and it is called Incisor.
Deinde intromitte ipsum sub uena in cute, donec perueniat phlebotomus ad os.	Then introduce it under the vein into the flesh, until the phlebotomist reaches the bone.
Deinde eleua manum tuam cum uena et cute ad superiora, et incide uenam cum cute incisione incidente.	Then lift your hand with the vein and skin upwards, and cut the vein with the skin by a cutting incision.
Et sit longitudo incisionis quantitas duorum digitorum iunctorum, aut circiter illud: et fac exire ex sanguine quantum uis.	And let the length of the incision be the quantity of two joined fingers, or about that: and make blood exit as much as you wish.
Deinde stringe eam cum puluillis, et dimitte eam, donec sanetur.	Then bind it with splints and let it go until it heals.
Et iam praecessit in principio libri incisio earum, et ipsarum cauterizatio.	And now he proceeds at the beginning of the book incision of them, and their cauterization.
¶ De phlebotomia duarum Arteriarum in timporibus.	On bloodletting of two arteries at times.
Duarum uero Arteriarum quae sunt in duobus timporibus phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad hemigraneam antiquam: et sodam prauam, et obtalmiam assiduam: et cursum superfluitatum effusarum acutarum ad oculos.	Of the two arteries which are in the two times of phlebotomy, the help is for ancient migraine: and bad sore, and continuous ophthalmia: and course of superfluous acute discharges to the eyes.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of blood letting is as I tell you.
Stringat infirmus collum suum multum, donec appareant duae uenae sensui apparitione manifesta: et demonstretur pulsus earum sub digito tuo.	The weak person tightens his neck a great deal until two veins appear to the sense in manifest appearance: and they are shown to be pulsating under your finger.
Tunc enim signa cum encaustro.	Then with encrusting plaster.
Deinde eleua cutem desuper uenam ad superiora cum digito tuo indice, et intromitte phlebotomum incidentem desubtus, et eleua uenam ad superiora.	Then elevate the skin from above with your index finger and introduce the cutting knife below, and elevate the vein upward.
Et incide eam, sicut fecisti in duabus uenis aliis: et fac currere ex sanguine secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	And cut into it as you did in the two other veins: and make it bleed according to the quantity of your need.
Deinde solue coartationem infirmi, et pone digitum tuum super uenam hora una.	Then loose the constriction of the sick person, and place your finger upon the vein for an hour.
Postea pone super ipsam cotum et puluillos, et stringe ipsum desuper constrictione forti: et dimitte ipsam, donec sanetur.	Afterward place upon the same poultice and compresses, and bind it above with a strong constriction: and let it go until it heals.
Et iam praecessit rememoratio earum, et ipsarum incisio, et earum extractio in principio libri.	And now comes a recollection of them, and their incision, and their extraction at the beginning of the book.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae frontis post phlebotomiam Cephalicae.	On vein incision of the forehead after cephalic vein incision.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae uenae frontis est post phlebotomiam Cephalicae, ad aegritudines faciei antiquas: et ad hemigraneam, et rubedinem: et ulcera foeda.	A wound from a vein-cutting in the forehead is after cephalic bloodletting for old pains of the face, and for migraine, and redness, and foul ulcers.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, secundum quod narro tibi.	And the quality of bloodletting is, as I tell you.
Coartet infirmus collum suum cum uitta, donec appareat uena.	The sick man bends his neck with a bandage until the vein appears.
Deinde accipe instrumentum quod nominatur Fossorium.	Then take the instrument that is called a Fossorium.
Cuius haec est forma.	This is its form.
Pone acumen eminens quod est in capite Fossorii super ipsam uenam, et percute super ipsum cum pectine, aut cum re alia in modo eius: et dimitte sanguinem currere secundum quantitatem quam uis.	Place the sharp point that is at the head of the Fossorium over the vein itself, and strike upon it with a comb, or with something else in a similar way: and let the blood flow according to the quantity which you wish.
Deinde solue perforationem infirmi, et stringe eam, donec sanetur.	Then loosen the wound of the sick person, and tighten it until it heals.
Et quandoque aperitur cum phlebotomo lato.	And sometimes it is opened with a broad lancet.
Verumtamen non oportet, ut sit phlebotomus acutae extremitatis, sicut reliqui phlebotomi, imo sit latae extremitatis.	However, a lancet should not be sharp at the extremity, like other lancets, but rather blunt at the extremity.
Et phlebotoma eam secundum transuersionem: quoniam os est propinquum: et fortasse in eo frangetur phlebotomus quando est subtilis.	And let the lancet be passed across it because the bone is near, and perhaps the lancet will break when it is fine.
¶ De phlebotomia Venarum in duobus Lachrymalibus.	On bloodletting of the veins in the two tear ducts.
Iuuamentum autem duarum Venarum quae sunt in duobus Lachrymalibus duorum oculorum, est ad oculum ex scabie et rubedine: et sebel in oculo, et aegritudinibus faciei.	An injury to two veins that are in the two tear ducts of both eyes is to the eye from scab and redness: and it hurts in the eye, and pain in the face.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum cum uitta.	And the quality of bleeding them is that the sick man should tighten his neck with a bandage.
Deinde phlebotoma eas: et tu sis stans super caput eius.	Then cut with the phlebotome and you be standing over his head.
Et fiat phlebotomia secundum transuersum ad longitudinem parum, cum phlebotomo paruo, lato parumper, nam in loco non est caro.	And let a phlebotomy be made transversely along the length, with a small lancet, somewhat broad, for there is no flesh in the place.
Si enim phlebotomus est subtilis extremitatis, fortasse frangitur.	If indeed the incision is in a delicate extremity, perhaps it will break.
Deinde fac currere ex sanguine quantum est tibi necesse.	Then make it flow out from the blood as much as is necessary for you.
Et pone super eas cotum, et stringe eas nocte una, et solue eas.	And place upon them a cloth, and bind them together one night, and untie them.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Nasi.	On bloodletting of the veins of the nose.
Venae autem Nasi phlebotomia, est conferens ad febrem acutam, et sodam uehementem, et aegritudines faciei, sicut hemigraneam, et rubedinem quae accidit in facie: praecipue quando est antiqua.	Phlebotomy of the veins of the nose is helpful for acute fever and violent abscesses and facial pains, such as migraine and redness that occurs on the face, especially when it is old.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringat infirmus collum suum.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that it tightens the weak neck of
Deinde tene nasum eius manu tua sinistra, et accipe phlebotomum subtilem, longum: et fige eum in medio leporis ipsius, inter illud quod distinguit nasum secundum rectitudinem.	Then hold his nose with your left hand, and take a subtle, long lancet, and place it in the middle of his harelip, between that which distinguishes the nose according to straightness.
Quoniam uena non apparet sensui illic, et quia sanguis incipit fluere statim.	Because the vein does not appear to the sense there, and because the blood begins to flow immediately.
Et oportet, ut ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo parumper: et facias currere ex sanguine secundum necessitatem tuam.	And it is necessary that you let your hand with the lancet run slightly and make blood flow according to your need.
Deinde liga ipsam nocte una.	Then bind it tight at night with one bandage.
Ipsa enim restauratur uelociter.	It indeed is restored quickly.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Guidegi.	On the lancing of veins according to Guidegi.
Duarum uero Guidegi phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad constrictionem anhelitus, et incaeptionem leprae, et aegritudines melancholicas, et impetiginem et ulcera mala, et corrodentibus, id est, herpetibus estiomenis.	Now the ailment of phlebotomy according to Guidegi is for shortness of breath, and beginning leprosy, and melancholy ailments, and sores bad and ulcers corrosive, that is to say, herpes appearing.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est ut stringat infirmus sub utrisque in collo suo cum ligamento: et stet artifex super caput infirmi, et infirmus sit sedens super sedem.	And the quality of phlebotomy of these is that it tightens the sick man under both in his neck with a bandage: and let the artificer stand over the head of the sick, and let the sick man be sitting upon a seat.
Deinde phlebotoma uenam ad longitudinem phlebotomia ampla parumper.	Then the lancet cuts a vein to the width of a large incision for a short length.
Deinde extrahe ex sanguine quantitatem temperatam, aut secundum illud quod uides ex necessitate quae est ad illud.	Then draw out from the blood a measured amount, or according to what you see is necessary for it.
Deinde fac similiter de uena alia.	Then do likewise with another vein.
Postea solue ligamentum, et stringe duas uenas strictura media: ut non praefocetur infirmus.	Afterwards solve the ligament and tighten two veins with a middle constriction so that the patient does not bleed profusely.
Et dimitte eam usque mane.	And let her be dismissed until morning.
Sanatur enim uulnus.	A wound is healed.
¶ De phlebotomia uenarum Algeberich.	On incision of veins, Albucasis.
Venae autem Algeberich phlebotomiae iuuamentum est: quia confert ad alcolam in ore, et corruptionem gingiuae: et ulcera mala: et fissuras labiorum, et ulcera mala, etiam quae sunt in naso, et in circumitu eius.	The veins of Albucasis are beneficial for phlebotomy because they help with hoarseness in the mouth, and corruption of the gums, and bad ulcers, and fissures of the lips, and bad ulcers, also those that are in the nose and around it.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae earum est, ut facias sedere infirmum coram te: et stringe collum eius cum uitta.	And the quality of bloodletting is, that you make the sick person sit in front of you: and bind his neck with a bandage.
Deinde reuolue labium eius, et aspice ad duas uenas: quarum una est a dextera labii, et secunda a sinistra eius: et demonstratio utriusque est per nigredinem ambarum.	Then turn over the lip and look at the two veins: one is from the right side of the lip and the second from the left side: and the demonstration of both is by the blackness of both.
Et illud uerum est: quia in circumitu earum sunt uenae minutae, nigrae.	And that is true: because on their circumference there are small, black veins.
Incide ergo utramque incisione incidente.	Therefore, cut both with a cutting incision.
Si autem dubitatio est super te, et non scis quae earum est: tunc intende ad incisionem maioris earum, et ipsarum manifestiorem.	If there is doubt about you, and you do not know which of them it is: then attend to the incision of the larger of them, and make them more manifest.
Et similiter fac de duabus uenis quae sunt in labio superiore: et plurimum quidem currit consuetudo cum eo: et incide duas uenas quae sunt in labio inferiori.	And similarly do with the two veins that are in the upper lip: and very much indeed is it customary to do so: and cut two veins that are in the lower lip.
¶ De phlebotomia Venae sub lingua post Cephalicae phlebotomiam.	On phlebotomy. The vein under the tongue after cephalic phlebotomy.
Duarum uero Venarum quae sunt sub lingua phlebotomiae iuuamentum: est, quod phlebotomia Cephalicae est ad praefocationes quae sunt in gutture, et aegritudinem uuulae, et aegritudines oris.	As for the two veins which are under the tongue, the usefulness of phlebotomy is this: that cephalic phlebotomy is good for affections which are in the throat, and pains of the gums, and pains of the mouth.
Et qualitas phlebotomandi eas est, ut sedeat infirmus inter manus tuas coram sole: et eleualinguam eius, et aspice sub lingua a latere eius uno uenam, et a latere eius alio uenam: et color utriusque decliuis ad nigredinem.	And the quality of bloodletting is that the sick person should sit between your hands facing the sun: and lift his tongue, and look under his tongue on one side a vein, and on the other side a vein: and the color of both sloping towards blackness.
Phlebotoma ergo utramque: et custodi, ne ultimes manum tuam in phlebotomando eas.	Therefore cut both veins and guard yourself so that you do not use your hand too far in cutting the veins.
Nam sub eius sunt arteriae, et fortasse accidet fluxus sanguinis ex illis arteriis.	For under it are arteries, and perhaps there will be a flow of blood from those arteries.
¶ De tribus Venis in cubito.	On the three veins in the elbow.
Venae autem tres quae phlebotomantur in cubito, sunt in quarum phlebotomia cucurrit consuetudo in omnibus hominibus.	The veins which are let in the elbow, there are three of which the cutting has custom in all men.
Et phlebotomia earum fit secundum duos modos.	And bloodletting of these is done according to two modes.
Aut pungendo cum phlebotomo myrtino lato: aut oliuari ad subtilitatem decliui: aut secando cum phlebotomo cultellari, et est Alnesil.	Either by pricking with a broad myrtle knife blade: or olive-wood to the fineness of a slope: or cutting with a surgical knife and it is Alnesil.
Et haec est forma eius.	And this is its form.
Sic Alnesil est, quod conuenit ad sectionem.	Thus Al-Zahrawi is, that which is convenient for the section.
Et ex eis sunt species latae, et subtiles secundum amplitudinem uenarum et stricturam earum Forma phlebotomi myrtini sit lata, sicut uides.	And among these are broad and subtle kinds, according to the width of the veins and their strictness.  The form of the phlebotomy knife should be broad, as you see.
Et conuenit ad aperiendas uenas concauas, plenas, procedentes, apparentes, grossas, et illas quae continent sanguinem grossum, turbidum.	And it is proper to open the hollow veins, full, coming forth, appearing, thick, and those which contain thick, turbid blood.
Et iste phlebotomus est minoris latitudinis, et subtilioris extreminatis.	And this lancet is of less width and more delicate point.
Et conuenit ad phlebotomiam uenarum subtilium, quae continent sanguinem subtilem citrinum	And it is fitting for bloodletting of the veins that contain fine, yellow-tinged blood.
¶ De phlebotomia Basilicae.	On bloodletting at Basilicas.
Basilicae autem quae est una harum trium uenarum phlebotomiae iuuamentum est.	The basilica vein of these three is helpful for bloodletting.
Quia extrahit sanguinem ex aegritudinibus, quae sunt sub gutture et collo, ex eo quod sequitur pectus, et uentrem: et conuenit phlebotomatori cum phlebotomat eam, ut caueat, et sit super timorem ex ea nam sub ea est arteria.	Because it draws blood from ailments that are in the throat and neck, because it follows the chest and abdomen: and it is fitting for the phlebotomist to take care with the phlebotomy, so that he may beware and be above fear from it, because under it is an artery.
Si ergo errat, et addit in punctura phlebotomi, incidet illam arteriam, et accidet fluxus sanguinis.	If therefore he errs, and adds in incision of the vein, he incites that artery, and there occurs a flow of blood.
Quapropter oportet, ne phlebotomet eam cum phlebotomo pungente: imo sit secans cum Alnesil.	Therefore it is necessary that she be bled not with a sharp lancet: but rather with a cutting one like Alnesil's.
Quod si non apparet Basilica apparitione manifesta, tunc oportet, ut alienes ipsam, et permuteris ad aliam, aut quaeras aliquem ramum eius: aut phlebotomes loco eius Funem brachii.	If the basilica does not appear with a manifest appearance, then it is necessary that one takes another basilica, and change it to another, or seek some branch of it; or in place of the phlebotome, a rope of the arm.
Ipsa enim est manifesta, et seca eam cum phlebotomo Anesil, sicut diximus.	For it is manifest, and dry it with a lancet named Anesil, as we have said.
Si autem uis phlebotomiam ipsius eiusdem, tunc oportet ante stricturam brachii, ut tangas locum, donec cognoscas locum pulsus.	If you wish to perform phlebotomy on the same person, then before the stricture of the arm, you must touch the place until you know the location of the pulse.
Deinde signa super locum cum encaustro, postea brachium, et seca uenam sectione concaua cum phlebotomo Alnesil, sicut diximus.	Then signs over the place with a cauterizer, then the arm, and the vein dry cut with a concave incision with the phlebotome Alnesil, as we said.
Et caue ne cadat percussio per spacium a loco arteriae.	And take care lest the blow fall through the space from the place of the artery.
Et quando uides, cum tu stringis ligamen, inflationem in loco quem signasti cum encaustro, tunc illa inflatio est inflatio arteriae: deuita ergo eam.	And when you see, when you tighten the ligature, an inflation in the place which you marked with wax, then that inflation is the inflation of the artery: therefore avoid it.
Quod si uides sanguinem apud phlebotomiam salire, sicut urina pueri, et est sanguis subtilis, rubeus: tunc scias, quia est ex sanguine arteriae.	If you see blood rising during bloodletting like a boy's urine, and it is fine-grained, red; then know that it is from the artery's blood.
Tunc ergo propera, et pone digitum tuum super ipsum spacio longo, deinde aufer digitum tuum.	Then therefore hasten, and place your finger upon it, long space, then take away your finger.
Si ergo abscinditur sanguis (multotiens namque abscinditur) tunc stringe brachium, et dimitte ipsum: et caueat infirmus a motione eius: et sit super timorem eius.	If therefore the blood is cut (for many times indeed it is cut), then bind the arm, and release it; and let the sick person guard against movement of it; and let him be over fear of it.
Et non moueat ipsum diebus aliquot, donec sanetur.	And let it not be moved for several days, until it is healed.
Si autem non abscinditur sanguis, et uincit te: et non est tibi praesens in momento tuo medicina, tunc incide arteriam, si apparet tibi.	If blood does not cease flowing and overcomes you, and there is no medicine present to you at the moment, then cut the artery if it appears to you.
Nam extremitates eius contrahuntur, et abscinditur sanguis.	For the extremities are contracted, and blood is cut off.
Aut accipe corticem fistici, et finde eum: accipe medietatem unam, et stringe eam super locum uenae strictura decenti, cum ligamento et puluillis usque ad diem alium.	Or take the bark of ficus and soften it: take half of it and bind it over the place of the vein constriction with a bandage and cotton wool until the next day.
Tunc si abscinditur sanguis, est bonum.	Then if the blood is cut off, it is good.
Et si non: tunc cura ipsum cum eo cuius praecessit rememoratio ex loco puluerum abscindentium fluxum sanguinis: et abscisio sanguinis eius non est difficilis in pluribus dispositionibus, propter locum paruum uulneris, et possibilitatem ligamenti ex brachio.	And if not so: then treat the one with it whose preceding remembrance from the place of powder cutting flow of blood: and the cutting off of its blood is not difficult in many dispositions, because of the small place of the wound, and the possibility of a ligament from the arm.
¶ De phlebotomia uenae Fuscae.	On the bleeding of the vein called Fusca.
Venae autem Fuscae phlebotomiae iuuamentum est, quod trahit sanguinem ex superiori parte capitis, et inferiore corporis: propterea, quia est composita ex ramo Basilicae, et ramo Cephalicae, sicut diximus.	The veins of the Fusca are helpful for phlebotomy, because it draws blood from the upper part of the head and lower part of the body, because it is composed of the Basilica branch and the Cephalic branch, as we said.
Et conuenit phlebotomanti eam, ut sit super timorem ex phlebotomia eius, nam sub ea est neruus.	And it is fitting for the phlebotomist that he be above fear from his phlebotomy, for under it is a nerve.
Si ergo addit in punctura phlebotomi, et inuenit neruum, accidit in ea stupor, et difficilis fit sanatio eius, et fortasse non sanatur penitus.	If therefore he adds in the puncture of phlebotomy, and finds a nerve, it happens in that numbness occurs, and healing becomes difficult, and perhaps it is not healed completely.
Et iste neruus multotiens apparet sensui.	And this nerve appears often to the sense.
Si autem occultatur in quibusdam hominibus, et est subtilis, et non ostenditur: tunc oportet ut ponas phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas, sectionem cum Alnesil, et deuita neruum cum fortitudine tua.	If it is hidden in some people, and it is subtle, and does not appear: then you must place your phlebotomy where you phlebotomize, a section with Alnesil, and sever the nerves with your strength.
Quod si uena est inter duos neruos, tunc finde uenam in longitudine.	If the vein is between two nerves, then cut the vein lengthwise.
¶ De uena Cephalica.	On the Cephalic Vein.
Phlebotomiae autem uenae Cephalicae iuuamentum est, quia attrahit sanguinem ex capite, et confert ad aegritudines oculorum.	The phlebotomy of the Cephalic vein is helpful because it draws blood from the head and brings relief to eye ailments.
Et oportet in hac uena proprie, si uis, ut phlebotomes eam pungendo cum phlebotomo oliuari, aut cum phlebotomo myrtino: quoniam est saluior uenarum omnium, quoniam non est subea arteria, neque neruus.	And it is necessary in this vein properly, if you wish, that you prick it with a lancet, either with an olive-tree lancet, or with a myrtle-tree lancet; because it is the safest of all veins, because there is no artery beneath it, nor nerve.
Verumtamen conuenit tibi apud phlebotomiam, ut deuites cum phlebotomo caput lacerti tantum, et quaeras locum leniorem: et non nocet ei, si non inuenitur cum percussione prima, ut iteretur super eam cum phlebotomia aliquotiens.	However, it is fitting for you in phlebotomy, that you avoid with the lancet the head of the lacerti, and seek a gentler place: and it does not harm him, if when first struck, it is not found, that it be repeated upon it several times with phlebotomy.
Verumtamen fortasse apostematur in quibusdam hominibus quando non phlebotomatur in percussione prima, sed non nocet ei illud apostema in aliquo.	Nevertheless, perhaps a boil will develop in some men when it is not lanced in the first percussion, but it does not harm him in any way.
¶ De utilitate Phlebotomiae, et cautelis in ea obseruandis.	On the usefulness of phlebotomy, and the precautions to be observed in it.
Qualitas autem Phlebotomiae, et accidentia eius ex ea, in cuius rectificatione oportet te cogitare.	The quality of phlebotomy, and its accidents from it, in which you ought to think about rectification.
Primum ergo illius est de quo oportet ut scias, quod phlebotomia non administratur, nisi in conseruatione sanitatis, et perseuerantia eius, et cautela ab aduentu aegritudinum.	Therefore, first of all, it is important for you to know that bloodletting is not administered unless for the preservation of health and its perseverance, and caution against the advent of diseases.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in una uenarum trium quae sunt in cubito, scilicet Cephalica, et Fusca, et Basilica.	And that a phlebotomy be made in one of the three veins which are in the elbow, namely Cephalic, and Dark, and Basilica.
Et ut fiat phlebotomia in principio Veris super ieiunium, in uere, et aestate: et autumno, et hyeme post comestionem, quando apparent significationes repletionis.	And that venesection should be performed at the beginning of Spring on a fast, in summer, and in autumn and winter after a meal, when signs of repletion appear.
Et fiat phlebotomia in die primo, aut in tertio, postquam praeterierint de die tres horae.	Let a bloodletting be performed on the first or third day, after three hours have passed.
Phlebotomia autem quae administratur in aegritudinibus, non habet horam determinatam: sed quando prouocat conuenientia et necessitas ad illud, in nocte, aut die, et in omni hora, et in omni tempore.	Venesection, which is administered in illnesses, does not have a determined hour: but when convenience and necessity call for it, at night, or day, and in every hour, and in every time.
Et non oportet, ut phlebotomentur pueri, donec ueniant super eos quatuordecim anni.	And it is not right that boys should be bled until they reach fourteen years of age.
Neque phlebotometur mulier praegnans, nisi a mense quarto usque ad septimum.	A pregnant woman shall not be bled, unless from the fourth month to the seventh.
Neque phlebotomentur senes, qui iam pertransierunt sexaginta annos.	The elderly who have passed sixty years should not be bled.
Cum ergo aliquis uult phlebotomari propter quemcumque modum sit: oportet, ut mundificet intestina sua ante phlebotomiam cum clisteri leni, si in eis est stercus multum retentum: ut non attrahant uenae apud phlebotomiam ex intestinis superfluitates putridas nocentes membris principalibus.	When therefore someone wants to be bled for any reason, it is necessary that he purify his intestines before bleeding with a gentle enema, if in them there is much feces retained: so that the veins at the time of bleeding do not attract impurities from the intestines harmful to the main limbs.
Neque phlebotometur patiens toctina, id est, satietatem nauseatiuam: neque crapulatus, neque euadens ab ebrietate, donec remoueatur illud ab eis.	Nor should a patient who is vomiting be bled, that is, full of nausea; nor one who is drunk, nor one recovering from drunkenness, until it has been removed from them.
Neque infirmus cum hydropisi.	Nor one with dropsy.
Et caueatur phlebotomia iterum post colicam passionem, et uomitum, et fluxum uentris, et multiplicationem coitus, et laboris, et exercitii, et uigiliarum, et ieiunii, et omnis quod dissoluit uirtutem ex re corporea aut animali.	And let phlebotomy be avoided again after colic passion, and vomiting, and flux of the belly, and multiplication of intercourse, and labor, and exercise, and vigils, and fasting, and all that dissolves the strength from the physical or animal thing.
Deinde considera in subtilitate humorum ante illud, si sanguis est grossus cum cibis et potibus, et medicinis: si possibile est ei illud.	Then consider the subtlety of the humors before that, if blood is thick with foods and drinks, and medicines: if it is possible for it.
Deinde introeat balneum, si non prohibet ipsum aliquid: aut exercitetur aliquo exercitio, ut subtilietur sanguis.	Then he enters the bath, if nothing prevents him; or he is exercised with some exercise, so that the blood may be refined.
Et pone phlebotomiam eius in pectore, circa tertiam diei, sicut diximus: et conare, ut euacuetur pectus eius illa die ex omnibus accidentibus animalibus malis: sicut angustia, et ira, et timor: et ex omnibus accidentibus corporeis, sicut labor, et poena, et superfluicoitus, et illis similia.	And place the phlebotomy in his chest, around the third day, as we said; and try so that his chest be evacuated on that day from all accidents of evil animals: such as tightness, and anger, and fear; and from all bodily accidents, such as labor, and punishment, and superfluity, and those similar.
Et sedi suae faciat esse praesentes res cum quarum usu cucurrit consuetudo hominum ex aromaticitate, et odoramento, et tripudio et similibus illis per quantitatem possibilitatis.	And let him make present to his seat things whose use men have acquired from fragrance, and scent, and joy and the like, to the extent of possibility.
Deinde sedeat phlebotomator super puluinari, quod sit altius quam puluinar phlebotomandi: postea extrahat brachium suum, et fricet ipsum phlebotomator manu sua bis, aut ter.	Then let the phlebotomist sit upon a stool, that it be higher than the phlebotomist's stool; afterwards he shall withdraw his arm, and rub himself with his hand twice, or thrice.
Deinde stringat ligamentum cum corrigia, et inuoluat eam bis.	Then he tightens the ligament with corrections and wraps it twice.
Et sit strictura temperata, quoniam strictura quando est inaequalis, aut per superfluitatem in strictura, tunc prohibet cursum sanguinis: aut in mollificatione, tunc etiam prohibet cursum sanguinis.	And let the constriction be moderate, because when a constriction is unequal, either through excess in the constriction, then it prevents the course of blood; or in softening, then it also prevents the course of blood.
Deinde post stricturam oportet, ut fricet phlebotomandus manus suas simul adinuicem, donec inflentur uenae, et declarentur sensui.	Then after constriction it is necessary that the surgeon rub his hands simultaneously and again until the veins swell and become apparent to the sense.
Deinde abstergat phlebotomator phlebotomum cum pauco oleo, antiquo proprie.	Then let the surgeon cut the vein with a little oil, as was formerly done.
Deinde ponat digitum suum indicem manus sinistrae super ipsam uenam sub loco cuius phlebotomiam uult, parum: ut non fugiat uena, et cassetur percussio.	Then he puts his index finger of the left hand upon the vein in the place where he wants to perform a phlebotomy, little: so that the vein does not flee, and the percussion is missed.
Quoniam ex uenis est quam inuenis sicut chordam fugientem apud phlebotomiam: et ex eis est quae est plena uentositate: et quando ponis phlebotomum super eam, contrahitur sub phlebotomo, et decipitur phlebotomator, et non aperit phlebotomus uenam: et si aperit eam, est stricta: propter illud ergo oportet, ut firmetur phlebotomator, et sit sollicitus in his rebus omnibus.	Because from veins there is one which you find as a fleeing cord in the vein-letting operation; and from them is that which is full of windiness; and when you put the vein-letter on it, it contracts under the vein-letter, and the vein-letterer is deceived, and does not open the vein; and if he opens it, it is strict. Therefore it is necessary that the vein-letterer be firm, and be solicitous in all these things.
Deinde deponat phlebotomum.	Then he puts down the lancet.
Si ergo aperitur uena ex uice una, tunc bonum est.	If therefore a vein is opened from one source, then it is good.
Et si non, tunc itera illud uice alia sub illo loco parum, aut supra ipsum cum festinatione: si non apostematur locus.	And if not, then repeat that with another incision under it in a small place, or above it with haste: if the place does not suppurate.
Quod si apostematur, aut expauescit infirmus, tunc dimitte eum die, aut duobus diebus: et non stringat ligamentum.	If it becomes suppurating or the patient weakens, then dismiss him on that day or two days after, and do not tighten the bandage.
Fortasse enim attrahet apostema calidum.	Perhaps it will draw a hot abscess.
Neque ingrediatur balneum.	He shall not enter the bath.
Deinde iteret phlebotomiam, si amat.	Then let him return to phlebotomy, if he wishes.
Quod si apertio est parua, aut currit sanguis subtiliter: et times ut non egrediatur ex sanguine quantitas quam uis: tunc itera phlebotomum in foramine ipso secundum rectitudinem, et adde in operatione parum.	If the opening is small, or blood flows subtly: and you fear that the quantity of blood which you desire may not exit; then repeat the incision of the vein in the very foramen according to straightness, and add little in the operation.
Et fac illud cum festinatione, antequam apostemetur locus, apostematus enim locus est in multis hominibus apud operationem paruam.	And do this with haste, before the place becomes suppurated, for a suppurating place is in many people at a small operation.
Si ergo uides ipsum iam apostematum, tunc non iteres super ipsum omnino, non enim excusat apud te aliquid.	If therefore you see the abscess already, then do not return on it at all, for it excuses nothing to you.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex faece olei: quoniam alleuiat cursum sanguinis.	And place upon it something of the feces of oil; because it will alleviate the course of blood.
Et est melior in hoc loco quam oleum ipsum, et quam reliqua olea.	And it is better in this place than oil itself, and than the rest of olive.
Et similiter administra faecem olei in omni phlebotomia tua, qua phlebotomas uenas apud prohibitionem cursus sanguinis: et faciunt illud tyriaca alfarach, et sagzenea, quando ponitur ex una earum super locum.	And similarly administer the feces of oil in all your bloodletting, where you bleed veins at the prohibition of blood flow, and they make it with tyriaca alfarach, and sagzenea, when one of them is placed over the place.
Sanguis enim subtiliatur et resoluitur, quando est grossus.	Blood, when it is thick, becomes refined and resolved.
Quod si accidat in loco phlebotomiae apostema magnum, nam multotiens accidit, praecipue ei qui non est phlebotomatus nisi uice illa, aut est apertio uenae parua, tunc propera et pone super locum spongiam infusam in aqua et sale, calefacta parumper: et stringe eam hora una: quoniam soluitur.	If a large abscess occurs at the site of bloodletting, which often happens, especially to those who are not bled unless absolutely necessary, or have a small vein opened, then hasten and place on the spot a sponge soaked in water and salt, heated for a short time: and bind it for an hour; because it will be dissolved.
Et oportet, ut facias illud post exitum sanguinis ex uena ipsa, cum complemento sui, aut ex uena alia.	And it is necessary that you do this after the blood has come out of the vein itself, with its completion, or from another vein.
Quod si remanet in loco post dies aliquid nigredinis, aut uiriditatis, non nocet illud: et si uis, pone super ipsum aliquid aloe, aut myrrhae solutorum: aut aliquid ex succo menthastri, id est, calamenti aut simile illius.	If something remains in place after days, some black or greenish, it does not harm: and if you wish, put on top of it something of aloe, or myrrh solution: or something from the juice of mint, that is, calamine or something similar to it.
Et multotiens quidem accidunt apostemata et eminentiae apud phlebotomiam Basilicae.	And often indeed abscesses and swellings occur at basilica bloodletting.
Pone ergo manum tuam super ipsam, tunc si inuenis molliciem apud compressionem tuam super ipsam, tunc illa eminentia est mala.	Therefore place your hand upon it, then if you find softness at your compression upon it, then that eminence is bad.
Caue ergo, ut ponas super eam aliquid ex eo quod diximus.	Therefore, beware that you place something upon it from what we have said.
Nam fortasse fluet ex ea sanguis arteriae.	For perhaps blood will flow from it of an artery.
Sed fac emplastrum ei cum eo in quo est stipticitas, ut induretur locus.	But make a plaster for him with that in which there is stypticity, that the place may be covered.
Deinde cura ipsum cum reliqua curatione, donec sanetur.	Then care for it as with the rest of the treatment until it heals.
Et oportet, ut extrahas omni homini ex sanguine secundum quantitatem uirtutis suae.	And it is necessary that you extract from every man from his blood according to the amount of his virtue.
Et quod apparet ex colore uincente super sanguinem.	And that which appears from the color winning over blood.
Nam sanguis si est niger, tunc dimitte ipsum exire, donec rubeat: et similiter si uides ipsum grossum: tunc dimitte eum, donec subtilietur: et similiter si est acutus, donec auferatur acuitas eius.	If the blood is black, then let it flow out until it turns red; and similarly if you see it thick, then let it flow out until it becomes thinner; and similarly if it is sharp, until its sharpness is removed.
Et oportet ei qui est plenus, fortis, et indiget extractione sanguinis uice una, ut amplificetur phlebotomia uenae, et sit phlebotomus latus: et in eo qui est debilis, sit econtrario illius.	And it is necessary for one who is full, strong, and needs bloodletting with one vein only, that the incision be made wide and broad, and for the weak person, let the opposite be done.
Et oportet, ut extrahat ipsum in uicibus, et ut sit foramen strictum: et melius quod administratur in phlebotomia uenae est, ut sit transuersa sectio, non punctura.	And it is necessary that he extract it in incisions, and that the opening be narrow: and better which is administered in phlebotomy of the vein is, that a transverse section be made, not a puncture.
Et iste modus phlebotomiae est saluus a fluxu sanguinis, et ab incisione nerui: et est laudabilior, et saluior quam phlebotomia per latitudinem et longitudinem.	And this method of phlebotomy is safe from the flow of blood, and from the incision of the nerve: and it is more praiseworthy, and safer than phlebotomy by breadth and length.
Et cui consueuit peruenire apud phlebotomiam syncopis, oportet ut cibes ante phlebotomiam modico pane infuso in aqua granati muzi: aut secaniabin, si est calefactus: et extrahas ei ex sanguine in tribus uicibus, aut quatuor.	And to whom it is customary to come among the bloodletters with fainting, let it be that food before phlebotomy is given moderately with bread infused in pomegranate juice: or boiled rice, if it is heated: and draw out of his blood in three or four times.
Et si est infrigidatae complexionis, tunc accipiat ante phlebotomiam panem infusum in syrupo miua, aut in syrupo de melle aromatizato cum speciebus, aut in syrupo aromatizato odorifero.	And if it is of a cold constitution, then let him take before the bloodletting bread soaked in syrup of myrrh, or in syrup of honey flavored with spices, or in aromatic and fragrant syrup.
Quod si accidat syncopis apud phlebotomiam, et est caussa eius exitus sanguinis multi: tunc oportet, ut sumat in potu aquam carnis, et syrupum odoriferum subtilem: et utatur aromaticitate cum algalia, et liniatur pectus eius cum ea: et utatur reliquis quae diximus in diuisione in capitulo syncopis ex euacuatione.	If syncope should occur during phlebotomy, and the cause is the exit of much blood, then it is necessary that he take a drink of water with flesh, and a subtle fragrant syrup; and use aromatics with algae, and liniment his chest with it; and use the rest which we said in the division in the chapter on syncopes from evacuation.
Qui autem uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo: oportet ei cuius phlebotomia est propter euacuationem multam, et uirtus eius est debilis, ut soluat sanguinem paulatim per quantitatem uirtutis in diebus continuis.	But whoever wants to let blood from his arm, and release his blood a second time: it is necessary for him whose phlebotomy is because of much evacuation, and whose strength is weak, that he should release the blood gradually by the amount of strength in continuous days.
Qui uero uult euentare brachium suum, et soluere sanguinem suum secundo, et est corpus eius forte: tunc faciat illud post septem horas, aut nouem a phlebotomia sua prima.	He who wants to let blood from his arm, and loosen his blood the second time, and his body is strong; then he should do it after seven or nine hours from his first incision.
Qui autem uult attrahere sanguinem ex corpore suo ad contrarium partis ad quam declinat: oportet ut euentetur ei in die secundo, aut in tertio.	Whoever wishes to draw blood from his body to the opposite part to which it inclines: it is necessary that he be bled on the second or third day.
In cuius uero corpore est sanguis multus iam calefactus, et acuitur, et facit accidere febrem: oportet, ut egrediatur ex eo sanguis in uice una, et extrahatur ex eo quantitas multa: et amplificetur apertio usquequo accidat syncopis: postquam tu fueris conseruans omnes conditiones phlebotomiae: et ut ponas manum tuam super pulsum eius apud cursum sanguinis, ut non accidat mors loco syncopis.	In the body of which there is much blood already heated and sharpened, and it causes fever to occur: it is necessary that the blood go out from it in one vein, and a large quantity be extracted from it: and the opening be enlarged until fainting occurs: after you have been conserving all the conditions of phlebotomy: and that you put your hand over his pulse at the course of the blood, so that death does not occur instead of fainting.
Multotiens enim accidit illud, quando ignorat phlebotomator, et cadit negligentia.	Many times indeed it happens that the phlebotomist is ignorant, and negligence falls.
Et non oportet quando uis soluere brachium, et soluere sanguinem secundo, cum iam clausum sit orificium uenae, et fiat difficilis exitus sanguinis, ut prematur super ipsum cum uehementia, et curuatum extendatur uelociter.	And it is not right when you wish to loosen the arm and loosen the blood a second time, since the orifice of the vein has already been closed and difficult exit of blood is made, that one should press upon it violently and quickly stretch the cut.
Nam illud est malum ualde, imo dimitte ipsum, donec phlebotometur secundo.	For that is a very bad evil, indeed let it alone until it is bled second.
Aut remoue cum acuitate phlebotomi illud quod coagulatum est ex sanguine in orificio uenae, et pone super ipsum aliquid salis dissoluti in aqua.	Either remove with the sharpness of a lancet that which is clotted from the blood at the opening of the vein, and place something salt dissolved in water above it.
Et pone super ipsum aliquid ex tyriaca alfaroch, aut sagzenea, et pone ipsum compressione leni, donec egrediatur sanguis.	And place upon it something of alfarach ointment, or sazzena, and place it with a gentle compression until the blood departs.
Si uero iam apostemata est uena, tunc dimitte eam, et non tegas eam, donec sedetur apostema.	If a vein has already been affected by an abscess, then let it go and do not hold it until the abscess sits.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad soluendum sanguinem secundo, et non est excusatio, tunc aut phlebotoma ipsum supra illum locum, aut in brachio alio in uena alia.	If necessity compels blood to be let for a second time and there is no excuse, then either the phlebotomist should make the incision above that place, or in another arm in another vein.
Funis autem brachii phlebotomatur loco Fuscae, et Basilicae, cum non inueniuntur, et sunt occultae, quoniam est composita ex eis.	The cord of the arm is cut by the vein where the Fuscous and Basilica are located, when these veins are not found and are hidden, because it is composed of them.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus manum suam in aqua calida, donec rubeat focile, et appareat uena manifeste.	And the quality of bloodletting is that the sick person should put his hand into hot water until the vein becomes visible and prominent.
Deinde stringatur super ipsam cum ligamento parum constrictione media.	Then it is bound over itself with a bandage with slight constriction in the middle.
Deinde phlebotoma secundum transuersationem paulatim, non latitudinaliter, neque secundum longitudinem: et sit apertio ampla, et sit phlebotomia tua qua eam phlebotomas super iuncturam manus parumper.	Then make the incision with the lancet second to the transverse direction, gradually and not laterally or lengthwise: and let the opening be wide, and let your incision be such that it cuts across the joint of the hand for a short distance.
Quod si prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera manum in aqua calida, et dimitte sanguinem currere in aqua, donec consequaris necessitatem tuam.	If the exit of blood is prevented, then repeat your hand in warm water, and let the blood flow in the water until you achieve your need.
Si autem fueris in diebus aestatis, tunc excusaris ab iteratione manus in aqua calida.	If you are in the days of summer, then you are excused from the repetition of hands in hot water.
Et plurimum quidem ponitur cursus sanguinis in aqua calida in tempore hyemis.	And most especially the flow of blood is put in hot water in wintertime.
Et phlebotomia huius uenae est saluior omnibus uenis, quoniam non est sub ea uena pulsatilis, neque neruus.	And vein incision of this vein is safer than all veins, because under this vein there is neither pulsating nor nerve.
Phlebotomia uero Saluatellae manus dextrae, est conferens aegritudinibus epatis.	A bloodletting on the right hand of Salvatella is beneficial for diseases of the liver.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut stringas mahason manus cum ligamento, aut manu tua, postquam tu intromittis eam in aquam calidam, donec infletur uena, et demonsteretur sensui ualde.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that you should tie the vein with a bandage or your hand after you have put it in warm water until the vein swells and becomes apparent to the touch.
Deinde phlebotoma eam transuersando.	Then the surgeon cuts it transversely with a lancet.
Et si incidis eam totaliter, non nocebit ei illud in aliquo.	And if you cut it entirely, it will not harm him in any way.
Et conserua, ne ultimes manum tuam cum phlebotomo.	And take care, lest you last use your hand with the lancet.
Sub ea enim sunt nerui digitorum denudati ex carne.	Under it are the nerves of the fingers laid bare of flesh.
Deinde itera manum ad aquam calidam, et dimitte currere sanguinem in ea.	Then apply your hand to the hot water, and let the blood run into it.
Nam si tu non iteras eam in aqua calida, coagulatur sanguis in orificio uenae, et prohibetur a cursu.	For if you do not run it in hot water, blood clots at the opening of the vein and is prevented from flowing.
Cum ergo extraxeris ex sanguine quantitatem necessitatis, tunc pone super uenam oleum et sal: ut non consolidetur uelociter.	When therefore you have extracted from the blood the quantity of necessity, then place over the vein oil and salt, that it not solidify quickly.
Et similiter oportet, ut facias cum omni ramo stricto.	And similarly you must do with every tight branch.
Iuuamentum uero phlebotomiae eius ex manu sinistra, est: quoniam est conferens ad aegritudines splenis: et similiter fac in phlebotomia eius, sicut fecisti in secunda aequaliter.	Now the incision for phlebotomy from the left hand is this: because it is helpful against spleen diseases: and do similarly in phlebotomy of it, as you did in the second equally.
Saphenae autem phlebotomiae iuuamentum, est ad aegritudines quae sunt in inferiori parte corporis, sicut aegritudines matricum, et retentionem menstruorum, et infirmitates renum, et ulcera coxarum et crurium antiqua, et similia ex aegritudinibus.	The benefit of cutting the saphenous vein is for illnesses that are in the lower part of the body, such as pains in the womb, and retention of menstruation, and infirmities of the kidneys, and ulcers of the hips and legs, old ones, and similar ailments.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut intromittat infirmus pedem suum in aquam calidam: et faciat super ipsum fricationem, donec exuberent uenae: et liga supra iuncturam pedis cum corrigia.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that the sick person shall put his foot into hot water and make friction upon it until the veins swell up, and bind above the joint of the foot with a ligature.
Et uenae quidem locus est apud calcaneum, apparens uersus pollicem: et ramificantur ex ea in facie pedis rami multi.	And the veins are indeed located near the heel bone, appearing towards the thumb: and they branch out from it on the face of the foot into many branches.
Phlebotoma ergo eam in ampliore ramo eius, aut apud calcaneum in aggregatione eius: quoniam est melius et saluius.	Therefore, let the phlebotomist make the incision in the larger branch of it, or near the heel in its collection: because it is better and healthier.
Quod si phlebotomas eam in facie pedis, tunc caue a neruis qui sunt sub ea super faciem pedis.	If he opens a vein on the face of the foot, then be cautious of the nerves which are below it on the face of the foot.
Et pone phlebotomiam tuam qua eam phlebotomas ex transuerso, quasi tu uelis incidere eam: et sit phlebotomus Nesil.	And place your incision for phlebotomy as if you want to cut it transversely, and let the lancet be named Nesil.
Si autem prohibetur exitus sanguinis, tunc itera pedem eius in aqua calida: et dimitte sanguinem currere in eam, donec euacuatur.	If the exit of blood is prevented, then immerse his foot again in hot water; and let the blood run into it until it is evacuated.
Quod si errat uenam phlebotomator in prima uice, tunc iteret cum phlebotomia ad superiora parumper, nam locus est saluus, et non times ex eo maliciam, quando tu caues a neruis, sicut diximus.	If the phlebotomist errs in the first attempt, then he should return with phlebotomy to the upper region for a short time, for that place is safe, and you should not fear evil from it, when you are careful of the nerves, as we said.
Et similiter cum Saphena pedis alterius aequaliter.	And similarly with the saphenous vein of the other foot equally.
Venae autem Sciaticae locus, sicut diximus, est apud calcaneum ex latere syluestri.	The location of the sciatic veins, as we have said, is at the calcaneum from the left side.
Et iuuamentum phlebotomiae eius est, ad dolorem anchae, quando est propter sanguinem calidum.	And the remedy for this incision is to the pain of the hip, when it is due to hot blood.
Et qualitas phlebotomiae eius est, ut ingrediatur infirmus balneum, et festinet: et stringe crus eius a latere anchae usque supra calcaneum quatuor digitis, cum uitta subtili longa: non enim apparet nisi propter illud.	And the quality of phlebotomy is that he who is sick should enter the bath and hasten; and wrap his leg from the side of the buttock to above the heel four fingers' width with a slender long bandage: for it does not appear unless for this reason.
Quando ergo apparet, tunc phlebotoma eam secundum quodcumque ingenium est tibi possibile, aut secundum transuersionem: et est melius, aut ut incidas eam incisione, aut seces eam sectione.	When therefore it appears, then the phlebotomist shall open it according to whichever art is possible to you, or according to the transverse cutting. And it is better, either that you cut it with an incision, or separate it with a section.
Locus enim eius est saluior, et ipsa est in pluribus hominibus occulta ualde.	The place of it is safer, and it itself is hidden in many people's bodies.
Quod si non inuenis eam, et non apparet sensui omnino: tunc phlebotoma aliquem ramum eius, et est ille qui apparet in dorso pedis, et uersus auricularem: et caue a neruis, et fac currere ex sanguine quantitatem quam uis.	If you do not find it and it does not appear at all to the sense, then let a phlebotomist take some branch of it, and it is the one which appears on the back of the foot, and towards the ear; and beware of the nerves, and make it run from the blood as much as you wish.
Deinde solue stricturam, et pone super locum phlebotomiae corium, et stringe locum.	Then loosen the constriction, and place leather over the site of the incision, and tighten the area.
Uelociter enim sanatur.	It heals quickly indeed.
¶ De Ventosatione, et qualitate usus eius.	On Wind Evacuation and its Use.
Caput XCVIII.	Chapter XCIII.
Uentosae fiunt ex cornibus, et ex aere, et ex uitro.	Surgical instruments are made from horn, and from bronze, and from glass.
Et Ventosatio quidem fit secundum duos modos.	And ventosaion is indeed done in two ways.
Cum scarificatione, et extractione sanguinis: et alter est uentosatio sine scarificatione.	With incision and bloodletting: and another is ventosaion without incision.
Et haec Ventosatio quae est sine scarificatione, est secundum duos modos.	And this type of cupping which is without incision is according to two modes.
Aut enim est cum igne.	Or else it is with fire.
Aut est absque igne.	Or it is without fire.
Et uentosis quae administrantur cum scarificatione et extractione sanguinis sunt quatuordecim loca corporis.	And there are fourteen places in the body that receive treatment with scarification and bloodletting.
Quorum unus est, Ventosatio Alnocrati, et est postremum capitis: et Alkehel, et est medium colli: et uentosae Alhagdahim, et sunt duae laminae colli a duabus partibus simul: et uentosae menti, et est sub mandibula in inferiori oris: et uentosae duarum spatularum: et uentosae Alachosos super finem caudae: et uentosae duorum focilium, et sunt medium duorum brachiorum: et uentosae duorum crurium: et uentosae duarum cauillarum.	There is one called Ventosatio Alnocrati, and it is at the back of the head: and Alkehel, and it is in the middle of the neck: and  Ventosatio Alhagdahim, and these are two plates of the neck from two parts together: and Ventosatio menti, and it is under the jaw in the lower mouth: and Ventosatio duarum spatularum: and Ventosatio Alachosos over the end of the tail: and Ventosatio duorum focilium, and these are in the middle of the two arms: and Ventosatio duorum crurium: and Ventosatio duarum cauillarum.
Et Ventosatio quidem non extrahit sanguinem tibi ex uenis minutis sparsis in carne, et propter illud non cadit uirtus ex eis, sicut est casus eius ex phlebotomia.	And cupping does not draw blood from the small veins scattered in the flesh, and for that reason there is no loss of strength from them, as there is in the case of phlebotomy.
Neque oportet, ut administretur uentosatio siue cum igne, aut absque igne in aliqua aegritudinum quae fiunt ex repletione, donec euacuetur totum corpus.	It is not proper to administer cauterization, whether with fire or without fire, in any ailment that arises from fullness, until the entire body has been evacuated.
Quod si necessitas prouocat ad Ventosationem ex aegritudine, aut propter consuetudinem, administramus eam in omni hora in principio mensis, in fine eius, et in medio ipsius, et in quocumque tempore fuerit.	If necessity compels us to bloodletting from sickness or out of habit, we administer it at any hour, at the beginning of the month, at its end, and in the middle of it, and at any time whatsoever.
Quod est, quia ex hominibus est qui quando multiplicatur in eo sanguis, donec indiget extractione eius per uentosationem, inuenit in capite suo grauedinem, et sodahan.	This is because among men there are those who when blood multiplies in them until it needs to be extracted through venesection, find heaviness and pain in their head.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit repletionem et rubedinem in facie sua, capite suo, et collo suo.	And of these there is one who has found a fullness and redness in his face, head, and neck.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit pruritum in facie sua, et fronte sua, et tenebrositatem, et hebetudinem in oculis suis.	And of these there is one who found itching on his face and forehead, and darkness, and dimness in his eyes.
Et ex eis est qui scalpit locum uentosationis suae.	And among these is one who sharpens the place of his ventilation.
Et ex eis est cuius risus multiplicatur.	And of these there is one whose laughter multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui inuenit gustum sanguinis in ore suo: aut apostematur lingua, et expuit sanguinem.	And of these is he who finds a taste of blood in his mouth; or the tongue becomes inflamed and discharges blood.
Et ex eis est cuius somnus multiplicatur.	And there is one whose sleep multiplies.
Et ex eis est qui uidet in somno suo sanguinem et rubedinem, et interfectos, et plagas, et quae sunt similia illis.	And there are those who see in their dream blood and redness, and the slain, and wounds, and things similar to these.
Quando ergo uidemus aliquid ex illis, et proprie si est in tertia media mensis: praecipimus tunc uentosationem fieri, postquam praeterierunt de die duae horae, aut tres.	When therefore we see something of these things, and properly if it is on the third day of the month: we prescribe then for ventilation to be done, after two hours or three have passed.
Iuuamentum autem Ventosationis nuchae, est: quoniam ipsa confert ad grauitatem in capite, et quod effunditur ad oculos.	A wound of the neck, namely, because it contributes to gravity in the head and that which flows out towards the eyes.
At uero oportet, ut sit illud post euacuationem totius corporis.	But it is necessary that it should be after evacuation of the whole body.
Et haec quidem Ventosa est loco phlebotomiae Cephalicae.	And this certain one is called Ventosa in place of cephalic phlebotomy.
Et non licet, ut utatur ea qui est frigidae complexionis, aut in quo est catarrus.	And it is not allowed to use it by someone who has a cold constitution, or one who has a catarrh.
Nam infert ei nocumentum magnum.	For it inflicts great harm upon him.
Et propter illud non oportet, ut utantur ea senes, et in cuius capite sunt aegritudines frigidae.	And therefore it is not necessary that they should use these things (the elderly), and those who have cold pains in their heads.
Qui autem super eam fit assiduus, generatur super eum obliuio.	He who is diligent over it, forgets it upon himself.
Et propter illud oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut deponat manum suam cum uentosa parumper ad inferiora, timendo ex generatione obliuionis.	And for this reason, it is necessary that you instruct the Operator to place his hand with a somewhat wind-carrying instrument below, fearing the production of oblivion.
Ventosatio aut Alkehel, est loco phlebotomiae Fuscae, et phlebotomiae Basilicae, et propter illud confert asmati, et constrictioni anhelitus, et fissurae instrumenti anhelitus, et tussi, et repletioni.	Ventosation or Alkehel is in the place of phlebotomy Fuscae and phlebotomy Basilicae, and because of this it brings on asthma, and constriction of breathing, and fissure of the instrument, and coughing, and repletion.
Et oportet, ut impellatur Ventosa Alkehel parumper, quoniam si ponitur inferius, generat debilitatem in corde, et stomacho.	And it is necessary that the pessary be driven by a gentle wind, because if it is put below, it generates weakness in the heart and stomach.
Ventosatio uero alhagdahim, confert doloribus accidentibus in capite, et obtalmiae, et hemigraneae, et perforationi, et dolori in radicibus dentium: et est loco phlebotomiae Basilicae.	Bloodletting in the head relieves pains due to accidents, ophthalmia, migraine, and perforation, and pain in tooth roots; it is in place of bloodletting in the basilica.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne premat manum suam cum scarificatione: ut non incidat arteriam, et accidat fluxus sanguinis.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Wind-drawer not to press his hand with the cutting so that he does not cut an artery and cause a flow of blood.
Ventosatio autem sub mento, confert alcolae in ore, et corruptioni gingiuae, et similibus eis ex aegritudinibus quae sunt in ore: et stat loco phlebotomiae alieherich, quae sunt in duobus labiis.	Bloodletting under the chin is helpful for ulcers in the mouth and for similar ailments that are in the mouth; it takes the place of other types of bloodletting which are on both lips.
Ventosatio autem spatularum, confert ad alchafacham, quae fit ex replexione, et caliditate.	The application of a spoon, however, contributes to the softening, which is made by rubbing and heat.
Ventosatio uero interiorum partium duorum focilium, confert iuuamentum phlebotomiae uenarum trium, Basilicae, et Fuscae, et Cephalicae: quoniam ipsa attrahit sanguinem ex omnibus illis uenis minutis, quae sunt in carne: et attrahunt illae uenae minutae ex uenis aliis grossioribus eis, donec peruenit attractio ad uenas tres.	Bloodletting of the internal parts with two leeches aids phlebotomy of the three veins, Basilicae, Fuscae, and Cephalicae: for it draws blood from all those small veins that are in the flesh: and those small veins draw from other larger veins until the attraction reaches the three major veins.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ne multum procedat in scarificatione: quoniam locus est denudatus carne, et sub eo sunt nerui et arteriae.	And it is necessary that you instruct the Wind-sucker, so that he does not proceed too much in the cutting; for the place is laid bare of flesh, and beneath it are nerves and arteries.
Ventosa autem quae uentosatur super alchausos, confert hemorroidibus Ani, et ulceribus inferioribus.	The suction cup, when applied to the affected areas, relieves hemorrhoids of the anus and lower ulcers.
Et oportet, ut praecipias Ventosatori, ut sit uentosa magna, et ut sit ex aere: quoniam locus indiget suctione forti, et fortasse franguntur Ventosae subtiles: et scarificetur scarificatione magna.	And it is necessary that you instruct the wind-catcher to be large and made of metal; because the place needs strong suction, and perhaps thin wind-catchers break. And let it be scarified with a large incision.
Ventosae autem crurium minuunt diminutione manifesta: quoniam attrahunt sanguinem ex toto corpore, et conferunt doloribus antiquis in renibus, et matricibus, et uesica: prouocant menstrua, et conferunt bothor, et ademenul: et stant loco phlebotomiae duarum saphenarum, et alhorcobeni.	Bloodletting of the legs diminishes by obvious manifestation because it draws blood from the whole body and brings relief to old pains in the kidneys, wombs, and bladder; it causes menstruation and alleviates fever and dyspnea; and stands in place of phlebotomy of the two saphenous veins and  the external jugular vein.
Verumtamen debilitant corpus multum, et faciunt accidere syncopim in pluribus hominibus.	Nevertheless, they greatly weaken the body and cause fainting in many people.
Et Ventosarum alhorcobeni iuuamentum est propinquum iuuamento Ventosarum duorum crurium.	And the treatment of wounds in the arm is similar to the treatment of wounds in two legs.
Qualitas positionis Ventosarum est, ut ponas uentosam in primis uacuam, et sugas suctione temperata: et non prolonges positionem uentosarum, sed pone eas uelociter, et remoue eas uelociter, ut ueniant humores ad locum aduentu aequali: et non cesses iterare illud et continuare, donec uideas locum iam rubere et inflari, et appareat rubedo sanguinis: tunc ergo scarifica, et itera suctione paulatim.	The quality of the position of the syringes is that you put the syringe in first empty, and suck with moderate suction: and do not prolong the position of the syringes, but put them quickly, and remove them quickly, so that humors come to the place with equal arrival; and do not cease to repeat this and continue it until you see the place already red and swollen, and the redness of blood appears; then therefore scarify, and repeat suction gradually.
Deinde considera in dispositione corporum.	Then consider the arrangement of the body.
Nam qui ex hominibus est tenerae carnis, rarorum pororum, oportet ut scarifices ipsum semel, non plus: ut non ulceretur locus.	For one who is of tender flesh and few pores, it is necessary that he be scarified once, not more; so that the place may not ulcerate.
Et praecipe Ventosatori, ut amplificet scarificationem, et profundet parum: et temperet suctionem in facilitate, et uelocitate, et motu suaui.	And tell the Ventor (suction apparatus), to increase the depth of incision and make it shallow; and moderate the suction in ease, speed, and its own motion.
Quod si in sanguine est grossitudo, tunc oportet, ut scarifices ipsum bis.	If there is a thickening in the blood, then it is necessary to scarify it twice.
In uice quidem prima aperitur uia subtiliationi sanguinis, et aquositati eius: et in secunda quidem perscrutationi exquisitae extractionis sanguinis grossi.	In the first opening, the way is opened for the refinement of blood and its liquidity; and in the second, for the examination of the exquisite extraction of thick blood.
Si uero sanguis est faeculentus ualde, tunc fiat scarificatio uice tertia: ut consequatur ultimum.	If, however, the blood is foul, then let a third type of scarification be made so that it may follow to its end.
Et ad ultimum, quando uolumus extrahere sanguinem paulatim, uel parumper, sufficit nobis scarificatio una.	And lastly, when we want to draw blood gradually, or a little, one incision is enough for us.
Quod si uolumus extractionem sanguinis multi, scarificamus scarificatione plurima.	If we wish to make many incisions for bloodletting, we make many incisions.
Et si nos mensuramus, quod sanguis est grossus: tunc oportet, ut scarificetur scarificatione profunda: et terminus aequalis in scarificatione, est profunditas cutis.	And if we measure that the blood is thick, then it is necessary that it be scarified with a deep incision, and the equal term in the incision is the depth of the skin.
¶ Quid sit illud quod oportet administrari ex oleis apud positionem Ventosarum, et quid caueat uentosandus.	What that thing is which ought to be administered from oils at the positioning of  Winds and what the Wind-setter should beware.
IN illo quidem cuius cutis est grossa, dura, fusca, et pori eius sunt stricti, oportet ut ungantur loca Ventosare cum oleis apertiuis, lenitiuis, resolutiuis: si est in tempore aestatis, sicut est oleum alkeiri, aut oleum uiolatum, aut oleum de amigdalis dulcibus, aut oleum de semine cucurbitae.	In that case, if the skin is thick, hard, dark, and its pores are narrow, it should be anointed with ointments of Ventosare, using open, soothing, and dissolving oils: If it is in summer time, such as alkeiri oil, or violet oil, or almond oil, or oil from pumpkin seed.
Et si est in tempore hyemis, tunc oleum narcissinum, aut oleum de lilio, aut oleum camomellinum, aut sarbatinum: et eis similia.	And if it is in wintertime, then oil of narcissus, or oil of lily, or oil of chamomile, or syrup: and similar things.
Si uero superfluitas est grossa, frigida: tunc oleum sit amaracinum, aut oleum de balsamita aut oleum alben, aut oleum anetinum: et eis similia.	If however the superfluity is gross and cold, then use bitter oil, or oil of balsamita, or alba oil, or anise oil, and similar ones.
Si uero uentosandus est amplorum pororum, tenerae carnis: tunc oportet, ut prohibeatur ab oleo, et oportet ut isti abluant loca Ventosarum earum post uentosationem cum aqua rosata, aut cum aqua frigida, aut cum aqua solatri, aut cum aqua cucurbitae, aut cum aqua portulacae: et similibus eis.	If a wide and porous wound needs to be treated, of tender flesh: then it is necessary that it be prohibited from oil, and it is necessary that these places be washed after the cleansing with rose water, or with cold water, or with water of saltwort, or with gourd water, or with purslane water: and similar ones.
Ille autem cuius sanguis est multae humiditatis, abluat uentosas cum aceto, aut cum aqua myrti, et sumach: et similibus eis.	He whose blood is of much moisture, shall wash wounds with vinegar, or with myrtle water, and sumagh, and the like.
Cuius autem superfluitates sunt grossae, abluat uentosas suas cum uino antiquo, aut cum aqua samsuci, aut decoctione aneti, aut camomillae: et eis similibus.	Those whose superfluities are coarse, he should wash their windy parts with old wine, or with water of Samsocia, or with a decoction of fennel, or chamomile: and the like.
Et oportet, ut caueatur uentosatio in balneo, aut in uestigio balnei, imo oportet, ut administretur post exitum ex balneo per horam, aut per horas duas.	And it is necessary that ventilation be avoided in the bath, or in the place of the bath, indeed it is necessary that it be administered after exiting the bath for an hour, or for two hours.
Et non oportet, ut dormiat aliquis post uentosationem.	And it is not necessary for someone to sleep after an incision.
¶ Quid est quo oportet ut regatur Ventosandus, aut Phlebotomatus ante uentosationem.	What is that which must be regulated, a Vento-sandus or a Phlebo-matus before venesection?
ET post eam oportet, ut consideres in primis: tunc si Ventosatus, aut Phlebotomatus sit cholericus, et uincunt super sanguinem eius acuitas et inflammatio: tunc oportet, ut accipiat infrigidantia, sicut granatum muzum: et etiam endiuiam cum aceto et lactuca, et secaniabin, et iuleb: et eis similia.	And after that, it is necessary to consider first: then if it is windy or phlebotomized, and the heat and inflammation dominate over his blood: then it is necessary for him to receive cooling things, such as pomegranate syrup, and also endive with vinegar and lettuce, and scanabine, and iuleb, and similar ones.
Et pone cibaria eius pullos, et carnes ouium sekebiget, et cibos conditos cum agresta: et eis similia.	And place his food chicks, and meats of sheep cooked, and foods prepared with herbs: and similar to these.
Et cuius complexio est frigida, oportet ut sumat in potu syrupum de melle, aut de almiua, aut alsecaniabin de seminibus factum: et sumat uinum odoriferum medium, quod est inter uetus et nouum: et praecipiatur, ut utatur paucitate cibi.	And if its complexion is cold, it ought to take in drink syrup of honey, or of almiua, or alsecaniabin made from seeds: and let it take medium scented wine, which is between old and new: and let it be prescribed that it use little food.
Et pone cibum eius pullos, et canebir: et passeres, id est, paruas aues: et pullos columborum issiadebet.	And put food for him chickens, and sparrows: and small birds: and young pigeons he should give.
Et oportet, ut potus die uentosationis et phlebotomiae plus sit quam cibus: et oportet, ut detur in potu in quibusdam hominibus in horis tyriaca alfaroch, aut medicamen de musco, id est, muscata, aut alesselithe ante uentosationem: et ante phlebotomiam, aut post: ut confortentur membra principalia, et subtilietur sanguis.	And it is necessary that the drinking on the day of venesection and phlebotomy be more than food; and it is necessary that in some men in the hours before venesection, tyriaca alfaroch be given in drink, or medicine of musk, that is, muscatel, or alesselithe before venesection: and before phlebotomy, or after: so that the principal limbs may be comforted, and the blood made finer.
Et non oportet, ut sumant eam in potu calefacto.	And it ought not that they take it in a heated drink.
¶ De Ventosis sine scarificatione.	On Varicose Veins Without Scarification.
Uentosae autem quae sunt sine scarificatione, sunt Ventosae quae ponuntur super epar, et splenem, et podagram, et super uentrem, umbilicum, et loca renum, et pixidem anchae: quoniam ista membra non sufferunt scarificationem super se.	There are also incisions that are made without incision, namely those that are placed on the liver, and spleen, and foot, and on the abdomen, navel, and places of the kidneys, and the hip joint: because these members do not tolerate incision upon themselves.
Et non quaeritur per eas, nisi aut attactio ex membro sanguinis ad membrum: sicut ponimus Ventosam super mammillas in aegritudine fluxus sanguinis narium.	And it is not sought by means of these, unless it be either a touch from one limb to another, as we place a leech on the nipples in the grief of blood flow in the nose.
Et utimur eis, ut soluamus a membro uentositatem frigidam inuiscatam in membro: sicut ponimus uentosam super uentrem, et umbilicum.	And we use them to loosen coldness from the invisible wind in a limb; such as placing a pessary over the abdomen and navel.
Ipsa enim rarificat membrum, et calefacit ipsum, et remouet dolorem propterea, quia resoluit illam uentositatem.	For it indeed thins the limb and warms it, and removes pain because it dissolves that inflammation.
Etiam ponitur super renes, quando accidit in eis opilatio, aut lapis.	It is also placed over the kidneys when there is a swelling or stone in them.
Uirtute enim attractionis suae fortasse aperit opilationem, aut eradicat lapidem ex loco suo.	By virtue of its force perhaps it opens a wound, or removes a stone from its place.
Et similiter facit quando ponitur super epar, et splenem apud uentositatem terendam in eis utrisque.	And similarly it is done when placed over the flank and the spleen must be treated with poultices on both of these.
Et istae Ventosae administrantur uacuae cum sectione tantum.	And these suctions are administered with a cupping only when there is a cutting.
Et quandoque administrantur cum igne.	And sometimes they are administered with fire.
Et quandoque administrantur plenae aqua tepida in aegritudinibus pleuresis: et illud est, ut impleatur Ventosa, et sit magna, aqua calida sola, aut aqua in qua decoctae sint herbae quae conueniunt.	And sometimes full warm water is administered in ailments of pleurisy: and this is done so that the suction cup be filled, and be large, with hot water alone, or with water in which herbs that are suitable have been boiled.
¶ Forma Ventosae administratae cum igne.	The form of a cupping glass administered with fire.
Sit amplitudo orificii eius duorum digitorum apertorum, secundum quod formauimus: et quantitas eius in profundo sit medietas palmi: et sit in latere eius in loco qui est circiter medium eius, foramen paruum, secundum quantitatem quod ingrediatur ipsum acus: fiat ex aere simul, aut citrino, grossorum marginum, lenium, aequalium, tersorum: ut non laedat membrum apud positionem suam super ipsum: et sit in medio eius uirga transuersa ex aere, aut ferro, ubi ponitur candela cum igne.
